PROCTEXT.PARA: Clause 67, page 38, after subclause (2) insert the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(2A) The Minister may not enter into arrangements under subsection (2) that expose, or could expose, the Commonwealth to a liability totalling more than $1,000,000.".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment to the ANL Sale Bill 1995 made in the Senate sets a cap on the expenditure that may be appropriated for the purpose of clause 67(2). This clause appropriates money which may be necessary to meet the needs for working capital of any Commonwealth company that is to hold assets, rights, liabilities and obligations transferred out of ANL prior to its sale to P&O in accordance with the draft sale agreement.

PARA.TAB: The amendment was moved by the government in the Senate to meet concerns that this appropriation was unlimited. In fact, the original appropriation was only to be available to provide working capital for the 1995-96 financial year. But the government is prepared to set an upper limit of $1 million on the amounts that may be appropriated for this purpose. The amendment inserts into clause 67 section 2A, which sets a ceiling of $1 million on the amount that may be provided under clause 67(2). I commend the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very pleased to see the amendment moved. I addressed the question of that appropriation together with the other much larger appropriation of $15 million during my speech on the second reading debate and in consideration in detail. We had many concerns about both appropriations. I was pleased to get an early undertaking in the open parliament concerning this $1 million limit being placed. The $15 million, which was of far more concern, was then subject to undertakings given to me by the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) personally on the eve of the Senate hearing. On that basis, the bill has been agreed to. I am pleased to see this amendment now.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Law Reform Bill 1994 passed this House on 9 November 1994. One year and five days later the bill passed the other place with 95 amendments, to which this House's agreement is now sought. The majority of these amendments were moved by the government following further consultation which occurred during that time. All government amendments were accepted by the other place.

PARA.TAB: The most significant feature of the bill is the changed approach to children in the new part VII of the Family Law Act. I am pleased that both here and in the other place speakers in the debate have enthusiastically supported the new approach. The bill provides for principles on which the new part VII is based, including the child's right to know and be cared for by both parents and to have contact with both parents and with other people significant to his or her care, welfare and development.

The government proposed an amendment to provide a best interests qualification to the principle recognising the child's right to contact with both parents. However, the government accepts that qualification of all the principles underlying the part by reference to the best interests of the child may assist in strengthening the message to parents that they cannot seek to subvert these principles to argue for their own rights rather than those of their children. The government, therefore, supported in the other place an amendment to provide this qualification to all the principles. As amended, the principles therefore establish a presumption of shared responsibility by parents for caring for their children. This sharing of responsibility can only be altered by agreement between the parents or by the court if it is not in the best interests of the child.

The original intention of the late Senator Murphy was that the Family Law Act would create a rebuttable presumption of shared parenting, but over the years the Family Court has chosen to largely ignore that. It is hoped that these reforms will now call for much closer attention to this presumption and that the Family Court will give full and proper effect to the intention of the parliament.

One amendment which I particularly commend to the House is the amendment of section 69C, which deals with applications to the court in children's matters. This section will now include a specific reference to grandparents as persons who may apply for orders in relation to children. Grandparents are in some cases the major point of stability for children during the breakdown of their parents' relationship. While grandparents are able to make application under the current provisions, and have done so, this express reference to grandparents will reinforce the bill's message to parents that they must focus on what is best for their children by including grandparents and other members of the extended family important to the children when they are settling arrangements for the care of children.

The amendments strengthen the requirement upon the Family Court generally to make orders which are consistent with any family violence orders and to ensure that the terms of its orders do not expose people to risk of family violence. The encouragement of the use of primary dispute resolution processes is tempered by a more overt recognition that these processes are not always appropriate.

A large number of the amendments effect a change from the term `special purpose order' to `specific issues order' in reference to those parts of a parenting order which deal with specific aspects of parental responsibility. The new term is more descriptive and will avoid any possible inference that such orders should be made only in special circumstances.

The bill lists the factors that the court must take into account in determining the best interests of the child. These factors are expanded by a number of amendments. One of the government amendments requires consideration of any need to maintain a connection with Aboriginal peoples or Torres Strait Islanders. In addition, a new paragraph has been inserted to require the court to consider the practicalities of contact and whether there are practical difficulties and expense which will affect the child's right to have contact with both parents. The government will accept this amendment which may be of assistance in ensuring that full consideration is given to the effects of, for example, parents living a long way apart. Another amendment which improves the bill ensures that the best interests of the child are given paramount consideration by the court, regardless of whether or not an order is made by consent, and that the court is provided with a discretion in the case of consent orders as to the factors which are to be taken into account.

A significant feature of the new part VII is parenting plans. The purpose of these provisions is to encourage parents to agree together, or with assistance from a counsellor or mediator, on matters affecting children rather than to have them judicially determined. Again, parents are directed to give the best interests of the child paramount consideration in working out their agreed plan.

The government believes that the requirements of a parenting plan should simply be that it be in writing and that it be made between the parents. In general, a parenting plan corresponds with a parenting order. Accordingly, it may deal with child residence, contact or maintenance or any other relevant issue. We recognise that parents should be able to make decisions on such issues without interference from external sources. However, registration with the court is necessary if the agreement is to be enforceable.

Unfortunately, consideration of this matter in the other place has led to significantly increased formality and cost in registration. It will probably make this aspect of the proposals less attractive to parties. Nevertheless, the government will accept the amendment to achieve the primary benefits of the major reforms which are to encourage parents to reach agreement as to how they will care for their children.
In addition, there are a number of improvements to the detail of the bill and technical matters dealt with by the amendments. The government will accept all amendments passed by the other place.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments to the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 which are before us arise as a result of very detailed consideration by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. We do not oppose the broad principles of this bill. We did have a number of concerns about it. The bill deals with a number of issues relating to mediation and children. It contains some philosophical changes relating to custody and, in particular, access. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) has dealt with those matters. As I understand it, the Senate committee produced two reports. There are still some matters relating to a separate bill—the Family Law Reform Bill (No. 2) 1994—which need consideration, but my comments relate to the Family Law Reform Bill 1994.

PARA.TAB: I observe that there has always been a very healthy interest in family law matters in this parliament. I was here when the Family Law Act was first enacted. The parliament debated the contents of that bill over a very much longer period than we would normally see accorded to legislation today. Interestingly enough, in relation to those deliberations, there were views expressed across the normal partisan party political boundaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you were on the side of the angels.

—I had some views on the matter. I certainly followed the matter with an interest when the Fraser government sought to review the Family Law Act. I was chairman of the first select committee reviewing the Family Law Act. It was a joint committee. We still have a joint committee today. It is interesting that when I look at the Notice Paper I find that it has a current inquiry which relates to administration and funding of the Family Court of Australia.

PARA.TAB: From my own experience in my own electorate, I have to say that I am frequently faced with parties who are concerned about the operations of the Family Law Act and the court. It is well known in relation to other matters that have flowed, particularly in relation to child support, that there is a very wide and significant degree of interest in the community as a whole, which we all face in our electorates day after day.

What interests me here is that it is only one house of this parliament that is devoting itself to consideration of important issues on which I think members of this House equally have a view. We are going to adopt amendments today—the opposition will not be opposing the proposals that have come forward from the Senate any more than the government has—in order to get the bill, and there will be some compromises. But the fact is that those compromises are being formed and determined in another chamber involving our colleagues, who obviously would be approached on these matters by their constituents within the states they represent. But I would hazard a guess that they are probably not as frequently approached by constituents anguished about the Family Law Act and its operations as we in this chamber are.

I would like to encourage the parliamentary secretary to, when we are looking at bills of this sort, again look at the role of this chamber in relation to these matters. I do not mind it being a joint billing, but I am concerned that, at the end of the day, the matters we are looking at are matters in which it is only senators whose compromised views are being accepted.

The matters I will discuss relate to the parenting plans, the imprisonment of registrars, family violence and grandparents. The most notable failure of the government was its difficulty with the implementation of committee recommendations with respect to parenting plans. The parliamentary secretary foreshadowed concerns about the complexity. These parenting plans do deal with welfare of children, residents, contacts and schooling matters—a whole host of issues in which parties do try to reach some agreement.

It was an issue in which the role of the Family Court with respect to parenting plans was going to have to be addressed. Parenting plans as registered can become orders of the court. At present there are, I understand, 1,000 such agreements, compared with something of the order of 100,000 consent orders in 1993-94.

The Law Council did raise some concerns with the committee about the lack of scrutiny of parenting plans. They were not to be examined by the court to ensure that the best interests of the child were addressed. The Law Council suggested that there should be a level of what they call minimal scrutiny, such as a form 12A procedure that is already in place in relation to court orders on other matters, such as property, which often seem to be more important than children. The concern of cost was raised, but the Law Council submitted that that procedure was not expensive.

In respect of parenting plans, while the Chief Justice of the Family Court indicated that he did not think it was really necessary, he also indicated that he would have no objection to a registrar being required to scrutinise the parenting plans. So the committee recommended that the Family Court monitor parenting plans when filed within the registry and that a court ought to be able to make orders specifying information required to be addressed in the plan. The government rejected this approach on the basis that scrutiny would defeat the intention of this bill to facilitate greater use of non-litigious methods of settlement.

In addition to the court scrutiny issue, the point was made that there is significant likelihood that the parenting plan procedure would significantly disadvantage what are seen as the weaker parties in various marriage situations. I guess weaker parties, in a non-sexist way, could be men or women.

It was argued that upon registration the plan is enforceable as a court order and there should be a requirement that the parties seek independent advice on their rights and obligations. Without it a weaker party could be disadvantaged—they could be railroaded in those negotiations.

We in the opposition believe that the impact of the registering of parenting plans is such both as to have an effect on children and, as a means of defining the rights and obligations of the parties to the marriage, there should be a requirement that both parties receive independent advice and at least some form of scrutiny.

We accordingly proposed an amendment in the Senate following negotiations with the Australian Democrats and the government and the Senate then sought to have passed these amendments to the parenting plan provisions. The amendment requires that, before a parenting plan is registered, the parties must either have received independent advice or have developed the plan in consultation with a family or child counsellor. In addition, the amendment requires that, for registration, the plan must be accompanied by certain information that will be prescribed by the rules of the court. In determining whether to register the plan, the court must have regard, in addition to the plan itself, to the information accompanying the plan. The intention is that there be a checklist of factors for consideration by the court to highlight to the court potential problems with the plan.

The issue of imprisonment of registrars was of interest to me. I thought it rather interesting that registrars could be subjected to imprisonment. The first committee report recommended that that provision be deleted. The government rejected this recommendation. The coalition believes it is not appropriate that registrars be subjected to the penalty of imprisonment and, accordingly, we supported an amendment from the Greens (WA) to substitute for the imprisonment penalty a financial penalty of up to $12,000.

In the second round of committee hearings family violence was a significant issue of concern in relation to a lack of focus in the bill on family violence and violence against women in particular. The National Women's Justice Coalition has been at the forefront of expressing these concerns. That coalition makes the point that the legislation, on its face, does not give nearly enough focus to issues of family violence. The concerns extend to all aspects of the bill and focus on primary dispute resolution and parenting plans, amongst others.

That coalition suggested 12 key policy proposals which attracted the support of a wide range of community and legal organisations and women's groups. In this respect the committee recommended that, first, part III, primary dispute resolution, be amended to qualify the object of the part to encourage primary dispute resolution provided the mechanisms are appropriate in the circumstances of the case and proper procedures are followed. That is included in amendment 5.

Second, the object of part VII, children, articulates the principle underlying the object of the part and is to be amended to include the proviso `except when it is or would be contrary to the child's best interests', and that is amendment 11. Third, section 68K, requiring courts to avoid inconsistency with family violence orders, will be redrafted in more positive terms so that the court must have regard to the safeguards in order to avoid exposure to family violence.

The government accepted those recommendations in the amendments implementing those recommendations moved by the government and thus supported in the Senate by the coalition. However, a number of other coalition suggestions were not taken up by the government. Some of these were taken up by the Democrats. Generally speaking, the coalition was of the view that the government's response appropriately addressed those concerns.

One suggestion, however, was not accepted by the government but was moved as an amendment that, on balance, we supported. The amendment in question, amendment No. 10, added an additional factor to section 43 of the Family Law Act. Section 43 sets out the principles to be applied by the court in the exercise of its jurisdiction under the act. The amendment specifically includes a reference to the need to ensure safety from family violence. That amendment was endorsed by the Family Law Council and the family law section of the Law Council of Australia.

Finally, in relation to grandparents, and amendment No. 73, during the committee hearings a number of grandparents organisations strongly argued that the act should make specific reference to the rights of grandparents. They do play a vital role in the lives of their grandchildren. That role can be particularly important at a time of breakdown. To the extent that the bill helps facilitate agreement between parents in relation to their children, it is hoped that it will also facilitate agreement with respect to contact with grandparents.

The bill before the parliament gives neither parents nor any other persons rights in relation to children. The bill looks at what is in the best interests of the child. It states explicitly that a principle underlying that object is that children have a right of contact on a regular basis with both their parents and with other people significant to their care, welfare and development. Of course, grandparents fall within that category.

The coalition supports the thrust of the bill in this respect. The legislative scheme facilitates, either by agreement or court order, contact or residence arrangements that are in the child's best interests. That will be best served often by regular contact with grandparents and, in some cases, by the child living with the grandparents. The bill allows persons concerned with day-to-day care, welfare and development of the child to apply for parenting orders in relation to children, and this will give most grandparents standing to be heard before the court.

Although grandparents will have standing in fact, grandparents organisations wanted specific reference to grandparents in the bill. The committee recommended the government consider including grandparents in the standing provision, section 69C. In its response to the committee recommendations in this respect, the government indicated an amendment would not be appropriate because grandparents already have standing under the broadly worded provision. Subsequently, however, the government did agree to introduce an amendment to specifically refer to grandparents in the standing provision, and the coalition is happy to support this amendment which recognises that grandparents do play a significant role in children's lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) in relation to the amendments that are being moved to the Family Law Reform Bill. At the outset, can I also endorse his comments in relation to the role of this chamber in relation to legislation. All too often we see legislation brought back to this House amended in ways that have been suggested in this House after committee consideration in the Senate. The intransigence of the government in refusing to refer bills to committees or to invite the attention of House committees to legislation is to be deplored. We are all too often saved by the Senate, and it does this House no credit that that occurs.

PARA.TAB: There are just two amendments to the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 to which I want to make special reference, and then I will refer to another matter. They relate, firstly, to the need to ensure safety from domestic or family violence and, secondly, to the formal recognition of the significant role played by grandparents in their grandchildren's lives.

During the hearings before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee there was significant concern expressed about the failure of government to legislate in relation to violence within the family. As indicated by the honourable member for Berowra, the principal proponent of these views was the National Women's Justice Coalition. As a result of the concerns expressed by the NWJC, the committee made a number of recommendations that included the provision of positive safeguards to protect the parties from family violence. Amendments incorporating most of these recommendations were moved by the government in the Senate and supported by the coalition.

One suggestion made by the NWJC was moved as an amendment by the Australian Democrats and carried with the support of the coalition, despite the government's opposition. This is an amendment to the section of the Family Law Act that sets out the principles to be applied by the courts in the exercise of their jurisdiction under the act. The Democrat amendment adds a principle in terms of the need to ensure safety from family violence. This amendment was endorsed by both the Family Law Council and the Law Council of Australia. While it is only a small step in dealing with an extremely difficult but widespread problem, it is hoped that the attention of the court will be more directly focused upon family violence as a problem.

In relation to grandparents, there has been a lot of pressure from groups representing them to amend the act to include a specific reference to the rights of grandparents in relation to the children of a marriage. In the second reading debate on 8 November last year, I commented on parenting plans by referring to grandparents. I indicated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the right of the child to have the continuing involvement of both parents in the child's care and upbringing. It is a pleasing reform that this is expressly recognised in the bill. There can be no doubt that it is a great advantage to a child to have the love and care of both parents and, through them, involvement with the parents' respective families—the grandparents, aunts, uncles and cousins.

Amendment No. 73 deals with grandparents explicitly. The bill states that the principle underlying the object of what is best for the child is that `children have a right of contact, on a regular basis, with both their parents and with other people significant to their care, welfare and development'. Grandparents, of course, will fall into this category.

PARA.TAB: The committee dealt with this issue, and, as indicated by the member for Berowra, the government opposed as inappropriate an amendment that would have given specific reference to the grandparents, the argument being that the grandparents already have standing under the broadly worded provision. Subsequently, however, the government did agree to introduce an amendment to specifically refer to grandparents in the standing provision. I for one am very happy to support this because it gives greater recognition to the significant role that grandparents play in children's lives.

A child's concept of who the child is and its esteem can be very significantly influenced by its being the focus of attention of relatives. In this respect, grandparents can be very important. I believe this amendment will assist in ensuring that a child maintains contact with its grandparents, aunts, uncles and others, even if the marriage between the parents has entirely broken down.

A further matter to which I wish to refer relates, in effect, to children's rights. In a recent decision, the full court of the Family Court of Australia referred to a number of circumstances—there were 14, from memory—in which it is appropriate that a child be separately represented before the court in proceedings relating to the family of which the child is a member. This is a very important decision. It means that there is a greater recognition, within the unfortunately litigious process by which families' breakdowns are resolved, of the interest of the child being quite separate in many ways from those of either or both parents.

While the decision is to be applauded in that respect, it is not without its practical consequences. I recently met with the directors of the various legal aid and legal services commissions when they were meeting in Perth and in Margaret River. An informal estimate by the directors of the cost to legal aid alone for representation of children in Family Court proceedings is about $6 million to $7 million per annum. In the context of very tight legal aid budgets, that represents a very significant proportion of the total funding provided by the Commonwealth in respect of what is a Commonwealth matter.

Obviously, given the already sparing allocation of legal aid to those seeking legal aid for the purposes of their own proceedings, not all of the needs of the children are going to be met in cases where it is appropriate. This is something that needs very close attention from the government, just as the question of the cost of representation of those accused of serious criminal offences needed attention following the decision of the High Court in the case of Dietrich.

I urge the government to recognise that there is a need to deal with legal aid funding of children's representation separately from any previous consideration of that issue. It is an urgent issue that the legal aid commissions are having to deal with on a day-to-day basis already.

I support the amendments proposed by the government. It is a matter of regret that the government did not suggest that this bill be referred to the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues for consideration. Instead, it was dealt with by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. In future with any such legislation which is of great concern across the community and to all members across all parties, I urge the government to consider that it be referred to a House committee in the first instance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of brief points particularly with regard to amendment No. 73, which is the inclusion of the recognition of grandparents and their role in the domestic situation of family break-up. The reason I want to do this is that one of my constituents, Mrs Di Underwood, has made this her personal crusade over the last 12 months with a number of different organisations across Australia. It was born out of her particular and individual experience with her own son and grandchild and the access that they have been denied and that they believe is necessary for the balanced upbringing of that child.

PARA.TAB: Since I have maintained a close contact with Di over the last 12 months she has certainly brought to the fore a very unnerving sort of relevance to this issue as far as the depth and breadth of this problem within society is concerned. I do not think there would be anybody in this House or in the other place who would not at some point in their extended family have encountered this situation and I believe it has probably touched every extended family in Australia.

So it is with great import that these amendments come back to the House of Representatives—as I think a previous speaker indicated, some 12 months or more after the Family Law Reform Bill passed through this place and went to the Senate—and are being supported by the coalition, in particular amendment No. 73 which, as I have said, is particularly important.

I take this opportunity to note the work that has been done by Di Underwood and her support group—Grandparents Rights Need Support, the GRaNS group—and I am sure the majority of government ministers that have been involved with this bill and this whole issue are aware of Di Underwood and that support group. They have done an important job, particularly in lobbying a lot of the senators who have been involved in the process of developing these amendments.

I will read a couple of paragraphs from a newsletter that Di Underwood circulates to the people in this organisation who have been involved in getting this amendment to the stage where it is today where it is about to pass through this chamber. The newsletter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: We have been brought together at this point of time because we share a similar dilemma, the destruction of the lifeline to our Grandchildren and the denial of access in many cases. Not content to accept the interpretation of the Family Law and the system by which it operates, I set out on a journey to seek answers and to question many of the decisions reached.

This led me to Canberra on three separate occasions a distance over 600 kms from my home town and over the past ten months I have travelled in excess of 12,000 kms, linking up with as many Grandparents as possible.

. . . I had organised a petition for my GRaNS to circulate recording thousands of signatures. The next step was to write to all the Federal Senators stating their difficulties for access to their beloved Grandchildren and a fear of abandoning these little people who, these days more than ever, need the reassurance of being loved. Most of all protecting their rights to maintain contact with their grandparents.
Probably the most salient paragraph in this newsletter that Di has circulated is:

Each one of us has a role to play and something to offer, together we can make a difference. It is all about how best we can gain assistance from those who are able to attain the changes that are necessary to protect the children.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I just want to close the debate by making a couple of comments. Firstly, I listened with interest to the comments made by a couple of members about their concerns about having proper debate of important bills like this bill, the Family Law Reform Bill, with suitable approaches for amendments and the like. From my point of view, whenever people have raised reasonable amendments with me I have always taken them into account, and I will continue to do so. I do not think that the charge that was levelled in general terms can be levelled against me.

PARA.TAB: The other point I want to make is in relation to the issue of parenting plans being not only lodged with the court but also scrutinised by the court. I would simply make the point that, whilst the government has accepted this amendment—the large proportion of children who are not in any way subjected to the Family Court may be 80 or 90 per cent of children—society, of course, does not seek in any way to scrutinise the parenting arrangements between their parents. I simply think that we have injected a degree of bureaucracy into the parenting plan arrangements for no valid purpose.

That is a tragedy because it may be that the parenting plan arrangements for which many people hold high hopes will not be as effective as they might otherwise have been. I think registering them with the court is entirely appropriate but, where the two parents have been able to reach an agreement, why we then need the court to scrutinise them is open to serious doubt. With those few comments, I commend the amendments to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CARER PENSION AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1995Cognate bill:SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 November, on motion by Mrs Crosio:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —When important bills such as the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill we are debating today are introduced with such haste and in such a slapdash manner, it seems only wise to speak later rather than earlier. The government has produced here two weak and complicated pieces of legislation. It should come as no surprise that they have been changed. The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill is already significantly different from the draft version that was circulated for discussion. The coalition's campaign against the removal of women under 40 for eligibility for the wife pension scared the government backbench into revolt, forcing changes to the bill.

PARA.TAB: The government has also been embarrassed by our foreshadowed amendments to the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill and announced a package to assist Meridian Investment unit holders—a package, I might add, that is mean-spirited when compared with the coalition's proposals. This bill has already created a great deal of concern over its lack of detail. I trust that the coalition will be able to force a few more changes on it so that the pensioners the legislation affects will enjoy some real certainty, as opposed to the vagueness of what the government is offering.

I do not want to speak for long today. However, I do want to canvass some of the aspects of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill and the extended deeming provisions that have caused the greatest worry for the coalition and the community. The shadow minister, the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), has foreshadowed an amendment condemning the government for its cavalier treatment of the House by providing insufficient time for consideration of the detailed provisions of this bill. The amendment goes on to condemn the government for its failure to include details of the timing and regularity of valuation of financial investments under the extended deeming rules; for its failure to adequately warn people affected by these new measures; for its failure to assist investors in Meridian Investment Trust from unfair penalisation under the unrealised capital gains provisions; and, finally, for its failure to properly deal with the potentially adverse impact of extended deeming on the holders of investments in friendly societies. They are all points worth making, and the government should stand condemned on all counts.

We are debating measures foreshadowed in the budget six months ago but, as the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) rightly observed earlier in this debate, the devil is often in the detail. It is scarcely responsible of a government to introduce two bills containing more than 40 amendments—including the vitally important extended deeming measures—and adding up to almost 400 pages, with only eight days for detailed examination and consultation.

As the shadow minister has remarked, we hear frequent complaints about the complexity of social security law from independent groups such as the Ombudsman and Welfare Rights. Too much social security law is bad law—law where one needs to be an expert to decipher the complexity of policies that should help, not confound, ordinary people in need.

Complex social security law creates difficulties every day for the people who have to administer it and for the people it attempts to assist. It ties down departments and confuses and worries social security recipients. Only last month the Auditor-General commented on how many hundreds of millions of dollars could be saved if Social Security improved its work practices and liberated its staff from the demands of paper work. Some of these were truly remarkable, such as the finding that $5 million could be saved if staff spent only five minutes less each day reading instructions. I cannot imagine that today's measures will be the first step to improve this situation. They are a perfect illustration of the way the government has created the problem.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) like to tell us that expenditure has been cut to the bone, yet they and their colleagues are happy to dump complex legislation such as this on the House with insufficient time for consultation and improvement, regardless of the wasteful bureaucratic sclerosis that a poorly formed end product will cause.

The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 is not just a slapdash piece of legislation. It is also incomplete. It does not contain all the details necessary to introduce extended deeming. Under the new deeming rules a single pensioner will be deemed to earn a return of five per cent on financial investments worth up to $30,000—$50,000 for couples—and the balance of investments will be deemed to earn seven per cent. The government claims that this system will create certainty as pensioners' payments will not be affected by market volatility as the value of their investments moves up and down.

However, the government has failed to provide any information on how often assets are to be valued.At the moment, pensioners are required to notify the Department of Social Security each time the value of their assets changes so that their pension can be adjusted accordingly. With the legislation in its current incomplete form they will not know what to do. One form of uncertainty is merely replaced with another.

This bill not only fails to solve the whole problem of uncertainty but also creates a real fear that the government will take advantage of this vagueness to further disadvantage pensioners. Pensioners' deeming rates will move up and down with the value of their assets. However, the government will not let us know when these official revaluations are going to occur. It seems appropriate to ask if pensioners will be able to choose if and when they want the value of their investments revised or if revaluation will occur at a time when it will benefit the government.

It seems remarkable that the government should not have finalised these measures before presenting today's legislation to the House. It is only proper that the bill be referred to the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee as the coalition has suggested. There is a clear need to consider issues such as the timing and regularity of valuations and the amendments necessary to institute the appropriate scheme.

The incomplete nature of this bill suggests an ad hoc approach to law making and a disregard for the parliament, let alone the pensioners who may have their incomes altered as a result. We should remember that this is an issue that can cause very significant concern, if not actual worry and distress, to pensioners.

It was interesting to find hidden away in the budget papers the government's own estimation that 207,000 pensioners will suffer a decrease in pension if they do not rearrange their assets. As the shadow minister rightly observed, Social Security was able to successfully explain changes to the wife pension to its clients with some clear and helpful letters and brochures. It would have been a simple matter to do the same with this measure to pensioners with shares. If the government intends to propose changes such as these it should have the courtesy to pass on the fullest possible amount of information to the people who will be affected by its final outcome.

Of course, it should also be noted, when considering the numbers of people affected by this move, that the government did not receive the savings originally anticipated from its treatment of unrealised capital gains. This, presumably, is one of the reasons why the government is moving to a new scheme. The revised budget forecasts that the Treasurer has said will be released some time before Christmas are already expected to show that the government's financial strategy is in tatters. One can only wonder how effective the extended deeming proposals will prove to be.

I wish to briefly touch on two more matters that the coalition has raised in its amendment to these bills. The government has failed to take into account the plight of investors in Estate Mortgage who have been adversely affected by the unrealised capital gains measures. When the coalition announced its intention to exempt investors in the trust who had been disadvantaged by these rules, the government attempted to match this with an ex gratia payment—a poor substitute for our original proposal.

The issues of friendly society bonds is another matter for concern coming from the haste in which this legislation has been prepared. The Australian Friendly Societies Association has suggested that prepaid investments such as friendly society bonds should be treated differently from financial products where tax is not prepaid and investors pay tax at their own marginal tax rates. The association has argued that returns from tax prepaid products will necessarily be lower as the tax has been paid before the distribution to investors and that its investors will be unfairly affected by extended deeming. For this reason we believe the Senate community affairs committee should also examine these implications of today's bills.

I was not here when the original unrealised capital gains and deeming measures were debated, but I quickly learnt from my mail bag and talking with my constituents just how controversial they had been. The coalition has long promised to repeal the unfair unrealised capital gains provisions. We have criticised the government for the way in which pension incomes can alter so much depending on the vagaries of the share market and the uncertainty and hardship that this system can cause. Today's patchy bills, and the review they will need, show that the government still has a lot to learn before it produces something workable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: I rise to speak in this cognate debate and to expand on some of the comments made by my colleague the member for Sturt (Mr Pyne). I also indicate that the way in which the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill have been introduced raises one's eyebrows. They have been introduced at a time when many people who rely on either the age pension wholly or partly or have their own investments and still qualify for an age pension spend most of their waking hours worrying themselves sick that the government is going to change the rules again and take their pension away.

PARA.TAB: As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous), who is at the table, would know, we live in constantly changing times. People's perceptions of change are grossly exaggerated at times by the amount of change that appears to be going on around them at any particular time. The types of changes in the bills before us do nothing to reassure those who feel that their lives, their incomes and their opportunities for maintaining their standard of living are under challenge once again.
I was interested to read the press release of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) in which he indicated, on 19 October:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments respond to the concerns of pensioners themselves about the complexity of investment rules, the frequent changes caused to pension payments and the effect on incentives to earn more from investments. . .
The new rules are simpler, fairer and more predictable and will encourage people to make the most of their resources.

These comments arise from the extraordinary scenario created by the introduction of the deeming provisions in the first place. As we know from experience, and having been a campaigner against the way in which these deeming provisions were introduced in the social security legislation, there are instances where they will impact unfairly on one particular group of people who have a particular type of investment.

PARA.TAB: We now find that, in order to allegedly simplify these arrangements, the changes have been made whereby the total value of a pensioner's financial investments will be used to calculate his or her income from those investments. A deeming rate of five per cent will apply to the first $30,000 of investments for a single pensioner, or the first $50,000 for couples. Thereafter a deeming rate of seven per cent will apply. Pensioners will receive a full pension where income from financial investments is less than $43,000 for a single pensioner or $75,000 for a couple.

As the member for Sturt, who has obviously received representations—as I have and as, I imagine, many other members have—has indicated, the friendly societies have indicated some serious concerns with these changes, serious enough to cause their members some disquiet and to be destabilised or to find themselves feeling insecure about their retirement income. I must say, while we have the parliamentary secretary at the table, that this destabilisation, this constant change, has been a feature of government policy throughout its life and it has accelerated in recent times.

I am sure that, as individual members with their own electorate offices, they would be getting the same sorts of representations that I and others are getting about this sort of insecurity—the insecurity that gnaws away—which, combined with other facets of modern life, leads pensioners, self-funded retirees or those who perhaps rely on a combination of incomes from the pension and self-funded investments to become more and more destabilised or insecure. The complaints of people or organisations like the friendly societies are reflecting this basic rise in insecurity on the part of people who are pensioners or self-funded retirees.

The United Ancient Order of Druids have indicated in their letter to me that the present or proposed deeming rates in the bill make no allowance for tax paid investments. In other words, the flat rates are set at five per cent up to 30 per cent, as I said, and seven per cent beyond. They are based on tax unpaid returns provided by banks, building societies, credit unions, et cetera. Investments like safe friendly society bonds are given no chance to compete because they are obliged to pay 33 per cent tax before bonuses are credited to the bond. That is hardly a level playing field in the competition to offer retirement income investments to likely customers.

Some 400,000 pensioners have about $2.8 billion invested with friendly societies which are asking on behalf of their members why they should be treated unfairly. What they are asking for in this case is a fair go for their members. They have indicated in their submission two ways in which they believe the matter could be resolved. The first is the setting of a tax paid equivalent deeming rate; in other words, five per cent, less 33 per cent, equivalent to 3.35 per cent. The second is giving friendly societies the option to provide their pensioner members with a tax unpaid cash paying bond, leaving the liability for tax in the pensioner's or recipient's hands.

The societies have asked me—and others—to make representations on their behalf. I am conscious of the fact that there is comment abroad that the friendly societies perhaps ought to be looking at offering other sorts of products to their likely members or their likely customers instead of tax prepaid bonds. That is a fair comment to a certain extent because, in many cases, pensioners are not taxpayers. They are not likely to be paying tax and, therefore, the product may not necessarily be the most suitable in their case. However, as I indicated earlier, we are dealing with people who have made investment decisions for their long-term retirement income in the hope that those decisions will be concrete decisions that will provide them with a fair standard of living throughout their retired lives.

As the member for Sturt has indicated, this almost dog's breakfast of legislative changes was brought in at a very late point. There has been very little opportunity for members and others to be able to examine the changes in detail and to assess how they are likely to affect people's lives. This sort of legislative process does little to nothing to contribute to a set of circumstances in which our senior citizens can lead their lives with at least some semblance of security and ability to plan ahead.

A change that will have a fundamental effect is being proposed in relation to the retirement income of a substantial number of people. It will in one fell swoop make the friendly societies, with their tax prepaid products, uncompetitive in the retirement income competition, which involves providing products to likely customers and those seeking retirement that will give a fair return on their investments.

I will now comment on the income test treatment of Meridian Investment Trust. I refer to the press release of the Minister for Social Security on 25 October. He announces that the government decided to apply concessional income tax treatment to pensioners affected by the failure of Estate Mortgage in 1990. He points out that Global Funds Management took over the funds of the Estate Mortgage group in 1990 and consolidated them into one trust called the Meridian Investment Trust. This trust was listed on the Stock Exchange in December 1993. The listing meant that the trust comes under the rate of return rules for valuing managed investments under social security income tests.

Until recently, the price of the stock was such that there was little impact on pensions. However, recent increases in the Stock Exchange price are now being reflected in a pension reduction and many of those concerns of the Minister for Social Security. This problem will cease to exist next July when the government's extended deeming measure will replace the rate of return rules. However, given the circumstances of the Estate Mortgage failure in 1990, there are particular features of this situation that justify concessional treatment in the meantime. The minister announced that the government has therefore decided to apply concessional income tax treatment to these investments.

This is precisely the type of circumstance that many of us predicted in relation to the application of deeming rates in the first place. We have the somewhat invidious position that, where an investment incurs a loss during the particular period of its treatment under the deeming rate rules, there is no provision for the person who may have had a gain in the previous financial year and suffered a loss in the next financial year to get a replacement or transfer of that loss back into their retirement income. Having lost the pension as a consequence of the deemed rise in income under the deeming provisions, that pensioner would not be eligible to claim back or in any way claw back the loss from the performance of their invested income over the next ensuing financial period.

In relation to Meridian, I make a plea to the minister. The investors who invested with Heine Management have understandably reported on the adverse effects to the social security benefit entitlements of many unit holders in flexi property trust. They have asked the minister for a similar extension of this treatment that Meridian Investments have enjoyed to the people who are flexi unit holders. In other words, it will allow them to obtain a change to the current unreasonable treatment of their unit holders by the DSS.

In the first instance, during that campaign many of us undertook to try to alert the government to the likely consequences of its deeming rate provision regime. These types of anomalies are precisely the result of those changes that we predicted and they give rise to the insecurity that, as I mentioned earlier, gnaws away at the lifestyles of pensioners and those who are desperately trying to preserve their standard of living by juggling their investments so they do not affect their pension income.

We as younger people probably find it very hard to understand how much this type of change can eat away at the security of people who are of retirement age. But, when you think about it carefully, for people who are almost on a fixed income these types of changes can be almost the end of the world. These changes are of such magnitude in their lives that, combined with all the other things that are going on around them in the community these days, they make life miserable.

People who have worked throughout their lives, paid taxes and contributed to the Australian standard of living and to the way in which we have developed this magnificent country of ours find themselves in a situation where every other month there appears to be another change to the way in which their retirement incomes are being treated, one way or the other. If it is not the way the DSS is treating their incomes or their returns from their investments, it is the Taxation Office requiring them to pay provisional tax.

Of all the things that we are seen to have lumped onto our senior citizens, these changes seem to be the most insidious because they contribute to that sense of almost feeling cut off from the rest of the community. These changes appear to them to be nonsensical, bloody-minded and bureaucratic, requiring them to go through another set of hoops that have been placed in their way by the government and the government bureaucracy.

It probably would suit government ministers and some of the senior bureaucrats to try to mentally place themselves in the position of people in this predicament. Together, the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), who has just entered the chamber, and I were campaigners when these deeming provisions were first introduced. I can recollect going to meetings where he and I would speak to groups of pensioners or people who were part-pensioners. We listened first-hand to these fears being expressed, often in a way that left us in no doubt as to how much these types of changes affected their lifestyles.

We all know that the administration of the social security system is a complex and, at times, difficult process. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mrs Crosio), who is sitting at the table, is probably sick to her back teeth of hearing me make observations about the local office of Joondalup, although I know that she does try to conscientiously help out when these things are brought to her notice. We have a system now that is so complicated you would almost have to be a Rhodes scholar in order to understand it.

One of the changes that has been proposed in the legislation that is before us today is in relation to the pensioner loans system, which is quite a lengthy piece of paperwork. That scheme is a first-rate scheme. Of all the things the government has done in recent times, that is one of the good ones. If the parliamentary secretary has had anything to do with that scheme she ought to be congratulated because it is a scheme that many have found to be most useful. It is a great idea because it allows pensioners to draw down extra income, or perhaps extra funds, from the asset value of their homes. Of course, that liability is not repayable until they pass away.

I think that is a tremendous scheme to which this legislation proposes some changes. But I was quite staggered to find that many people were unaware of the scheme. I found that this unawareness was a little more widespread than I had thought. I urge the parliamentary secretary to redouble the government's effort in informing those who are eligible or likely to be eligible of what is a tremendous idea. This scheme allows people to improve their lifestyle using the asset value of their home to take a loan which is not repayable until they pass away. That is a good idea. From time to time, one can congratulate the government for good ideas. They are entitled to accept the congratulations of those who have taken advantage of it. However, the government should redouble its efforts in ensuring that everybody is conscious of what is a tremendous idea.

Finally, I refer to the carers pension, which is one of the many changes proposed in the bills before us today. I want to point out a particular dilemma in which a constituent found herself. Her husband suffered from chronic Alzheimer's disease and needed 24-hour supervision. Neither Mrs S nor her family wanted to send Mr S, the person suffering from the disease, to a nursing home or a big town. Mrs S is eligible for a carers pension, but she cannot cope with her husband's needs all the time. They looked around for somebody who would be prepared to come to Wiluna, which is where they live, to help care for Mr S. After four or five tries, they found a woman who was suitable and who wanted to stay in this remote location and help. Unfortunately, she was on a working visa, which meant that she could not hold down a job for more than three months at a time. To make matters worse, Mrs S could not claim a carers pension or benefit for the carer who was willing to go there because the CES required that they advertise Australia-wide to ensure that no other Australians were available to take the job. Of course, that would have required tremendous effort and would have taken many months.

That is the type of thing you find in the grey area of social security and related legislation which requires change. I know that the parliamentary secretary will listen to my concerns and, hopefully, she will make sure that the type of dilemma facing my constituent is changed in the future. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I would like to commend every speaker who has contributed to this debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill both before the break and since we have come back. I wish to respond to a number of points before we consider the bills in total.

PARA.TAB: In listening to the contributions of those opposite to this debate in the House, I noted that one of the points that kept coming out time and time again was the eight days for consideration of this bill in detail. When the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) got up and made his first contribution to this debate, he mentioned the eight days for consideration in detail of the bill, as did every other opposition member who followed him thereafter. I thought that was quite extraordinary. With all due respect, it got to the stage where I thought that someone had written a speech and then distributed it around. We indicated what we were going to do during the May budget. I do not know how many more months we need to do that.

I thought it was very interesting when the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) got up earlier and said, `But wait a minute, eight days for consideration of this bill in detail is disgraceful.' Yet I find that the original one that was circulated has amendments and changes to it. So we cannot have it both ways. Obviously, he had been given an opportunity to look at the information, along with all other opposition members, but then he came back and said that eight days was not enough. I really think that was a bit of a furphy. Those opposite should have commended and congratulated the government on the number of steps that it has taken in respect of the bills before the House to make sure that what we do is at all times give account and consideration to the people whom we want to benefit from it—that is, the pensioners and those who are disadvantaged within our society. I understand that and I can appreciate that.

There are a couple of other points that I would like to raise. One of the criticisms, if I could put it that way, of the opposition, which was again mentioned in a repetitive style, related to deeming. Just about every opposition speaker got up and condemned deeming. I do not know whether they condemned it because they do not understand it or because they just wanted to make political points from it. Obviously, if they condemned it from a political point of view, they did not give any consideration to the comments of many pensioners within our society and organisations far and wide who have commended and congratulated the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) and the government on the steps that have now been taken in the simplification of deeming.

Others are saying, `It is some new invention.' I think one of the opposition spokespersons said, `Why have we got to have it and what are we doing with it?' We have called it extended deeming because we are building on what is already in place. In so doing, we have simplified it. We have been circulating that message to all pensioners and pension organisations for something like five months now and we will continue to do so with information going out through our pensioner newsletters and also other methods of circulation, particularly Age Pension News.

I was leading up to a couple of points on deeming. Why has the government done it? This is the ongoing point made by the opposition. We did it because we had been approached by many organisations—our pensioner income and assets test review came out of that—and people saying, `We want a deeming approach, and it is certainly preferable.' We had that reviewed and it has come into being because it is simpler. It replaces the numerous rules that originally applied to different financial assets with one set of rules. That makes it easier for people to understand and appreciate it.

This system is fairer because it ensures that our clients with the same level of financial assets receive a similar assessment, no matter how their assets are invested. It is very predictable. This predictability encourages our clients to increase their total income by eliminating the risk of large changes to entitlements. By that I mean the short-term fluctuations in the market value of managed investments and shares.

It also simplifies the choice of investments. Treating all financial assets in the same way encourages those clients with whom we are dealing, day in and day out, to choose investments on their merits instead of their likely effect on entitlements. Also, it really puts the means test system as our pensioners understand and appreciate it on a more sound, long-term footing. Of course, we need to have this in place as the population ages. One of the comments made was, `Why are we having extended deeming?' We have called it extended deeming because, as I have said, we are putting it into place and building on what is already there.

Other concerns were raised by the opposition regarding financial investments, such as what deeming is going to include and what it is going to exclude. That, too, has been circulated. The information is readily available to any member on either side of the House who has a concern about that.

One of the things I reiterate, to make sure it is on the record for this debate today and so that we do not have these alarming statements going out to our pensioners and all of those people living on limited income, is that the financial investments do not include the individual's house or contents. It does not include the car, the boat or the caravan. It does not include the stamp or coin collection, if that is what they have. It does not include the standard life insurance policy or the holiday home, farm or other real estate. Income will not be deemed on any of these.

Financial investments also do not include superannuation, allocated pensions, immediate annuities or allocated annuities. Actually, under the pension and allowance income test, the income from all financial investments will be assessed under one simple set of rules. That is why I continue to reiterate the fairness of the system this bill is now covering, the fairness of bringing into place a deeming that will allow people to have all of their assets fairly treated. We will not have a great differentiation between one particular group that has small savings and another that has shares, because in this legislation I believe we are looking after the interests of all of our clients—whether the opposition believes us or not. It is a fact and it has been accepted. We are creating a level playing field for people to make those investment choices. I can only reiterate that treating investments equally does encourage all of our people to select investments on their overall merits.

I do not have with me the list of those people who participated in the debate, but I say generally that a number of other comments were made that our pensioners do not understand the impact of extended deeming. Our government has directly written to all pensioners and, through the Age Pension News and other means, widely publicised the new deeming rules—well before their introduction, which, I might add, will be 1 July 1996.

Through our publicity we have stressed that our financial information officers provide a free service to all of our clients going through our Department of Social Security offices and, if there is any concern out there at large, `Don't listen to rumour, contact those people; they'll be only too happy to sit down, explain and provide the information and set out the rules for you free of charge as part of a service from the Department of Social Security.' We have found considerable interest amongst pensioners approaching our financial information officers. We have had a good community response to that information.

It is also important to reiterate that deeming itself does not affect the majority of our pensioners. I would like to put an example on the record. If a single pensioner has no other income, then they can have as much as $43,000 worth of financial investments before their pension is reduced. Of course, it goes up for married couples. But the opposition is being alarmist by continually saying that people will have to stop their savings, withdraw them and change and, therefore, they are flustered and do not understand. Let me tell you: the response is that they more than understand. In fact, they are saying, `We very much appreciate what you have been able to do.'

The member for Moore (Mr Filing), just before I rose on my right of reply, said again that no-one has advised the pensioners of deeming. I think I have covered that point. I would also like to reiterate that we sent out a personal letter to some 2.3 million pensioners. Within a few days of the budget, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) sent out a similar information letter to 350,000 Department of Veterans' Affairs pensioners explaining 12 months in advance the changes that were going to occur.

The June edition of the Age Pension News also contained information about extended deeming and other budget changes, which we have covered here in these bills. In the December edition of the Age Pension News, just before Christmas, we again hope to have more articles on extended deeming. The opposition claims that no information has been provided on these bills, particularly on deeming. So, in condemning the particular parts of the bills that they choose to attack, the opposition is thus claiming that it neither understood nor appreciated what was intended.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am mindful of the time. We are going into consideration of the bill in detail when I would like the opportunity to cover some of the other points. I would also like to refer to Meridian Trust. A number

SPEECH.PARA: of speakers expressed concern as to why we are doing what we are doing, claiming that perhaps we have not gone far enough.

PARA.TAB: Global Funds Management, the manager of MIT incorporating the old Estate Mortgage Trust, approached the government requesting that consideration be given under the social security income test to the particular difficulties faced by the unit holders in this area. That is why we responded, particularly after investigation, to this request.

In fact, I was very pleased when the Minister for Social Security announced on 25 October that concessional income test treatment would apply to pensioners and allowees affected by the failure of Estate Mortgage. That concessional treatment will now bring forward the extended deeming rules for MIT investments for social security customers who held them on 24 October 1995. Fortnightly social security payments will be adjusted from 24 October—in fact, they have been—to July 1996 when extended deeming will be introduced for all financial investments.

At present, of course, the legislation requires that the rate of return be assessed on the managed investments, such as the MIT units but based on distribution of the change in value of the investments during the previous 12 months. Although there has been no distribution to MIT unit holders since the trust was first listed on the stock exchange, which was in December 1993, the price of the units has increased significantly over the past 12 months such that the rates of return in excess of 40 per cent are now causing substantial reductions in payments to some of our clients.

Again, we were approached to give consideration to a unique case. In this particular area the steps taken were quite in order. In fact, I commend and congratulate the minister on the steps that he took in this regard. I believe that consideration has to be given—
Mr Ruddock interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I cannot, actually. I was going to bring out another letter, but I will do so when we come to the consideration in detail stage. I have to reiterate that nothing has been swept under the table. What we are doing has been broadcast very loudly and clearly. We have informed all of those people to be affected as to why, for example, deeming is coming in and as to the other amendments to the bill.

PARA.TAB: As I have said previously, in dealing with social security legislation, which deals with people, the legislation is never set in concrete. We have to be concerned about change because people change and circumstances change, and I do not believe at any time that we can have legislation dealing with social security matters where we can say, `Here is how it is today; here is how it will be next year or the year after.' Of course we have to have amendments and of course we have to have flexibility, because without flexibility we are not taking on board—as a government rightly should do—the concerns of the people. We have to make sure that the present-day commitment is being serviced, and we have to make sure that those people we should care about at all times have accessibility and are getting what they rightfully deserve. I commend these bills to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Administrator recommending appropriation announced.
Clauses 1 to 3—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Schedule 1 agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move opposition amendment No.1:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Schedule 2, Part 2, pages 21 and 22, omit paragraph 9.
The matter we are dealing with first is the amendment to delete paragraph 9 of schedule 2. Paragraph 9 says:
After the end of each financial year, each agency must give the Privacy Commissioner a report including matters relating to the data-matching program that are carried out . . .
And:

After the 3-year period ending on 30 June 1998, and after each successive 3-year period, each agency must give the Minister responsible for the agency a report for presentation to the Parliament including all the details relating to the data-matching program . . .

The reason for moving to delete that paragraph is that the opposition is of the view that the existing sunset clause ought to be maintained and that the parliament ought to be in a position to be adequately informed, particularly as to the way in which the data-matching program is being carried out. These provisions, of course, require for the data-matching program to be carried out under supervision and for certain reporting requirements to the parliament. They were part and parcel of the schema that was developed first by the Senate for ensuring that these provisions were adequately reviewed by the parliament on the basis of regular provision of information.

PARA.TAB: I have certainly found the information that has been provided to me relating to the data-matching program comprehensive and helpful. It has enabled people to have a better understanding of how it is operating. The reason that we seek to maintain the clause relating to terminating the operation of data-matching is that we still have doubts as to how efficacious it has been. That is the reason for the approach that we have taken on this matter.

If you are going to come to a concluded judgment that it has shown to be extraordinarily effective, as the government often claims, then that information ought to be available for the parliament to come to that view. The fact that we have come to a view at the moment that suggests that it has not been efficacious but we are prepared to give it extra time to ensure that it is able to work is a compromise on our part. As part of that compromise, the government ought to accept the continuation of the sunset clause and the reporting requirement.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I thank you for allowing us to have the amendments considered separately. I am sure that the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) and the opposition will agree when I explain why. I completely agree with the sentiments that have just been expressed. The amendments before us now concern two parts, which is reflected on page 21, paragraph 9, of the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill. One is a deletion; the other is an addition. The addition is the reinstatement of the sunset clause, bringing it back to 1999. We have no trouble with that. In fairness and to get the bills through, if this is what is required we are quite prepared to accept it.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the other clause, the honourable member for Berowra has just stated in his argument that he finds it very informative and that we should have the facility for the extension of the activity. But, in moving the amendment, he has eliminated completely the role of reporting. By eliminating paragraph 9 and not substituting anything else, he is basically saying that the participating agencies in tabling the reports in the parliament are in accordance with the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act.

To reiterate for the honourable member, the present requirement states that agencies report annually and separately. We admit that it is costly in terms of resources, and it is probably no longer necessary to demonstrate the value of the program. But, with that in mind, and to ensure that the parliament is adequately informed about the operation of the data-matching program, the bill provides for the data-matching act to be amended to require agencies to present reports to parliament every three years.

The honourable member for Berowra, in moving the amendment on behalf of the opposition, has basically indicated that he does not consider that the three-year reporting regime is sufficient. I have just heard the debate, accordingly, to support that amendment. We on the government side are a little puzzled by the amendment which the member for Berowra has circulated. Far from requiring annual reporting by agencies, if the amendment goes through in its form now, it will dispense with the mandatory reporting requirement altogether. I do not think that he wants that, and nor do we.

All of the previous reporting requirements under the data-matching act have been met. Unless further amendments are made to the act, there will be no future need for agencies to report. Paragraph 9 of schedule 2, part 2, of the carer bill seeks to amend the data-matching act so as to require agencies to report to the parliament every three years, with the interim reporting provided to the Privacy Commissioner annually. I am sure that the member for Berowra did not mean by his amendment simply to omit paragraph 9 without providing any alternative reporting requirements and to dispense with the reporting requirement.

I am sure that many officers in the Department of Social Security, including me, would welcome that, but I do not think that is the intent of his amendment, and I do not think that is the intent of the government.
