TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments that I seek to move relate essentially to the Meridian Investment Trust issue in both cases. The proposal that we have advanced, in contradistinction to the situation that the government has addressed essentially through payments of an ex gratia nature, is to in fact put the trust unit holders in the position that they would have been in were it not for the fact that Estate Mortgage Trust failed and was later relisted. The implication of that is that the approach we wish to take would see them defined as saved investments in the same way that other trusts were saved if they were established before September 1988.

PARA.TAB: Our proposal is to ensure that those folk who have these forms of market-linked investments, or Estate Mortgage trusts, are not disadvantaged by the government's unrealised capital gains test, which treats any increase in value as income for the purposes of the income test for pension eligibility. The government was obviously persuaded that these folk who owned the Meridian Investment Trust units were being disadvantaged. Otherwise, it would not have come up with the proposal for an ex gratia payment. There is no question that the case is justified. The only question is the way in which you address it.

I think the government chose to treat the holders of Estate Mortgage units, now Meridian Investment Trust units, quite appallingly. They have sought to apply to them, at this point in time, the new extended deeming arrangement, which will apply to no other holder of units or saved investments, so that the unrealised capital gains test does not apply to them. It is a distinction which clearly cannot be justified other than on the basis that it is a compromise. The government is saying that they are trying to address the problem these people face, but they really do not want to give them everything. They will deem them to have had a five per cent or seven per cent return on those holdings.

That is very grudging and quite inappropriate. In our view, the only proper way for this matter to be addressed is for the Meridian Investment Trust to be treated as all other investments that had a continuing existence and were saved investments. The only distinction in this case is that these people had already suffered a very significant loss as a result of the failure of the trust. The government has ensured that they suffer a double jeopardy.

There was no justification for that. It is certainly something that I do not think the government is now trying to justify, but it is trying to say, `Our ex gratia payment is enough.' I say to the government that the better way of dealing with this is to treat them as saved investments and to ensure that these people were not disadvantaged at any point in time and were not disadvantaged further by this gratuitous application of the extended deeming arrangements for the several months in which they have had capital growth.

DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (1995-96 BUDGET MEASURES) BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 26 October.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer for Superannuation)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the second veterans' affairs 1995-96 budget measures bill. It gives effect to the remaining government budget initiatives that need legislation. Many of the measures in this bill address the particular needs of our older veterans, most of whom are now in their 70s and served in World War II. In this year, while we have commemorated their achievements and sacrifices in that conflict, it is important that we continue to look at ways to improve our caring for their immediate and future needs. The initiatives in this bill, and other related measures that do not require legislation, demonstrate once again that my department is at the cutting edge of aged care.

PARA.TAB: Before I address the specific items in this bill, I want to mention some of the government's 1995-96 budget initiatives that do not require legislation. The first is the extension of the free advisory and referral services of the very successful veterans' home maintenance helpline. This service will now be available to all veterans, war widows and war widowers. It provides a valuable support to those who own their own home by providing advice on a broad range of matters, from replacing a fuse to installing a new bathroom. Wherever possible, the helpline links the client to government subsidised services.

The second valuable supporting initiative is the development of a program for discharge planning. This program will ensure that appropriate care continues after an eligible veteran, war widow or war widower is discharged from hospital. The program recognises that attention to the special needs of patients in the post-acute phase of an illness is important to their successful rehabilitation.

People who provide full-time care for our veterans play an invaluable role. They allow many veterans to continue to live in their own home or in the community when they would otherwise be unable to manage. The carer's task is often a difficult one. My department is continuing to look at ways to assist the carers. Recently I was pleased to launch a practical guide for carers of people with dementia. Other initiatives to provide practical assistance to carers are being developed.

Part of the support for those providing care in the veteran community is through the provision of carer service pensions. This bill includes a number of measures that extend access to carer service pensions and it also puts into place a number of changes that reflect the needs and situations of many carers.

Carer service pensions are now available only to those who are caring for veterans who receive a service pension. The bill extends eligibility for a carer service pension to those who are caring for certain veterans who do not receive an income support payment from either my department or the Department of Social Security. If the carer meets other existing eligibility criteria, a carer service pension will become payable to a person providing care for a veteran whose family income is less than $61,020, with assets of less than $559,250. These limits will rise in line with increases in the family payment income and assets tests.

A similar extension of carer benefits will be made to war widows and war widowers who provide care for another person. These carers will be eligible for an income support supplement if the person under care does not receive a service pension from my department or a pension or benefit from the Department of Social Security but does meet the basic family payment income and assets tests.The bill removes the current requirement that allows a carer service pension to be paid only where the carer lives in the same house as the person receiving care or adjacent to that house. As long as the person provides the necessary level of care, it will not matter where the carer lives.

Another important budget measure in this bill is the continuation of the carer service pension for 14 weeks after the veteran is admitted permanently to a nursing home or other institutionalised care. The carer service pension currently ceases as soon as the veteran permanently enters a nursing home. The continuation of the payment to the carer will allow that person time to adjust to changed responsibilities and to make arrangements for their future income and possibly a new place to live.

The bill ensures that those receiving or providing community care are not financially disadvantaged by entering into that arrangement. If a person leaves their home to provide care for a veteran, the value of their home will be disregarded under the service pension assets test for two years. Similarly, if the veteran leaves his or her home to receive care in some other place in the community, the value of the veteran's home will not be included as an asset for two years. In addition, those leaving their home to provide or to receive care will be immediately eligible for rent assistance if they are paying rent for their new residence.

In addition to the change in rent assistance I just mentioned, this bill contains a number of other rent assistance measures. From March 1996, the maximum rates of rent assistance for families with children will be increased by $5 a fortnight. This increase reflects the higher cost often associated with renting private accommodation that meets the needs of families with children. The government also recognises the extra costs incurred by a single pensioner raising a child and, in this bill, increases the rate of guardian allowance by $4 a fortnight. The bill increases rent thresholds by $5 a fortnight to coincide with the March 1996 CPI increase. This increase ensures that rent assistance continues to target pensioners who pay relatively higher rents.

There are currently a number of pensioners who retained eligibility for rent assistance, or for a beneficial rate of rent assistance, that they were receiving at the time of rent assistance reforms in 1989 and 1993. These people have continued to receive a higher rate of income support than others who are assessed under current provisions.

The bill makes two specific provisions relating to these pensioners. First, it ensures that those income support pensioners eligible for one of these retained rent assistance payments who transfer back to my department from the Department of Social Security can continue to receive that payment. Second, the retained payments are to be gradually phased out. From March 1996, any CPI increase in the total service pension payments will be offset against those rent assistance payments until the total amount payable is equal to the total amount payable to others in the same circumstances. This change will achieve equity in income support payments without reducing the total amount paid to the pensioners.

The bill provides for the payment of a residential care allowance to certain pensioners in a nursing home or hostel. The allowance replaces any rent assistance now paid to these pensioners. It will be paid at the same rate and subject to the same threshold, indexation and all other provisions as are now applied to rent assistance. The bill also includes two measures to assist veterans and other income support beneficiaries under veterans' affairs legislation in the management of their living expenses.

The bill will allow certain specified classes of deductions to be made from service pensions at the request of the pensioner. This will allow payments, such as rent to government housing authorities, to be deducted and paid direct to the authority. This arrangement will provide a valuable service to veterans and other income support recipients, particularly our aged and infirm pensioners.

The second measure will allow certain service pensioners access to an advance of their pension of up to $500 to assist them to meet unexpected living expenses. The government recognises that many service pensioners have limited cash reserves and can have difficulty obtaining access to lump sum amounts to help them meet costs associated with, say, emergency repairs and replacements. The lump sum advance of pension will have no interest or other charges. Repayments will be at a level the pensioner can afford, and can be spread out over six months.

The budget provided for an adjustment to be made to the bereavement payment to the partner of a person who was also receiving a war widow or war widower pension at the time of death. The adjustment removes the limitation on the amount of the war widow or war widower's income support pension from the calculation of the bereavement payment to the surviving partner. The bill gives effect to this adjustment within a major rewrite of the veterans' affairs legislation relating to bereavement payments. This rewrite includes some minor policy changes to remove superfluous provisions or to correct inconsistencies. The new provisions significantly simplify what had become very complex legislation.

The bill makes a number of minor changes to other acts. The Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 is to be changed as a consequence of the introduction of the residential care allowance and the rewrite of the bereavement payment provisions in this bill. That act will also include changes that follow on previous veterans' affairs legislation amendment acts. These changes include the introduction of income support supplement, and the repeal of the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940. There are also minor changes to the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Act 1986 as a result of the repeal of the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940. The Social Security Act 1991 is to be amended to incorporate a provision relating to rent assistance to social security pensioners or beneficiaries that is now included in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, but is being repealed.
In concluding, I believe this bill provides sound and positive measures that respond to the changing needs of the veteran community. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to speak on behalf of the opposition in response to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (1995-96 Budget Measures) Bill (No. 2) 1995. Before I do so—I am not sure I have had the opportunity to do so before—I congratulate the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) on his life membership of the RSL, which I am sure was well deserved. Indeed, as we have celebrated Australia Remembers this year, it has been a very good year for the minister. I think he perhaps might regret having taken on the mantle of Minister Assisting the Treasurer for Superannuation. He has already found that that is rather more complex and fraught with danger than being Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

PARA.TAB: In safeguarding the interests of veterans and our older citizens, one has to realise how important their savings are to them. I think the suggestion that some pressure should be applied to superannuation funds to do other than act in the best interests of their policyholders and shareholders is one that would be of great concern—not only to people who are already retired and are living off their savings but perhaps also to those who are planning to do so in the future.

It is a pleasure in these veterans' affairs debates to actually have the minister in parliament. We very rarely see the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) in here—he is always represented by his parliamentary secretary. We have just dealt with complex social security legislation, but we never get a chance to actually deal directly with the minister on such legislation. In fact, we never even get a letter from the Minister for Social Security. In every representation I make on behalf of constituents to the minister, I get a letter back from his parliamentary secretary. So I do not even know whether he can sign his name. But, to the credit of this Minister for Veterans' Affairs, he comes into the parliament when his legislation is debated, takes part in the debate and makes a contribution to it.

The opposition does not oppose this particular legislation. We understand it is the second and final bill covering the 1995-96 budget measures for veterans. I will not go through the provisions again as the minister spelt them out in detail, but we accept that the vast majority of the provisions in this legislation do benefit veterans. The legislation is intended to bring the Department of Veterans' Affairs' beneficiaries into line with those who receive their benefits from the Department of Social Security. That, generally, is a principle with which we also agree.

There are some savings in this legislation and they result from a small increase in the rent threshold. When this matter came up in the debate on the social security legislation, we expressed some concerns about that. I am not sure whether the minister alluded directly to that change in his remarks, but that particular change will disadvantage some people while it will advantage others. However, the net effect of that change, as represented by the savings which the government projects as a result of that change, clearly makes the point that some people in receipt of rent assistance will actually receive less assistance while others will receive more.

The principle of bringing DVA beneficiaries into line with DSS beneficiaries raises an important fundamental issue about benefits for veterans. Whilst I would not argue that veterans should not get equal benefits with DSS beneficiaries where they are not getting those benefits, the point needs to be made time and again in debates on veterans' affairs in this place about the special treatment to which veterans are entitled.

Over many years there has been a concern that veterans' entitlements have been diminished little by little—a trend I would like to see stop. I do not entirely blame this last 13 years of Labor government for that because I think it started before that, but it has certainly continued. Like today, very often it is only minor changes with which we are confronted. However, the net effect of them all over a long period of time has been a dramatic lessening of the benefits that our veterans get. Talking about benefits for veterans, these are `earned' benefits—things that they have given for, that they have sacrificed for, and therefore they are benefits that in many ways should be regarded as sacrosanct and not diminished. I had a constituent write to me just recently who made the point, very poignantly, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: When the war ended in 1945, a 100 per cent war pension was equivalent to the average wage paid to a clerk in the Commonwealth Public Service.

Obviously a benchmark was intended at that time. But he goes on in some detail to illustrate that now, over many years—and he mentions both Labor and conservative governments—those particular entitlements are very much less than that benchmark.

PARA.TAB: He asked me what I was going to do about it. I was not able to say that we on this side would be able to return the benefit, or any of those other benefits that they originally had. But I certainly did say to him that I could give him assurances that a coalition government will be committed to maintaining veterans' benefits and that I would continue to do my utmost in the parliament to ensure this happens.

The point I am making there is that whilst this legislation is intended to bring DVA beneficiaries into line with DSS beneficiaries—and, as I say, that is a principle which one cannot agree with—if you turn it around the other way, the important point I want to make, the point I make at every opportunity when I speak on veterans' affairs matters in parliament, and not only the government but all members of this parliament should keep making the point, is that veterans are special, that their entitlements are special and that they should not be diminished lightly or capriciously. Over the years we have sometimes seen this being chipped away, little changes here and there which, over a long period of time, have had the effect of diminishing benefits to veterans.

These people, of course, have earned those entitlements through the service they have given to this country. That is what this particular year of Australia Remembers has been all about. We in this place do not pay credit lightly to a member on the other side, but certainly the Minister for Veterans' Affairs at the table today is largely responsible for the fact that it has been a very good year, that Australia Remembers has been a success and that it has highlighted in many respects the concerns of veterans. Hopefully it will have created a climate whereby veterans' affairs will continue to be regarded as very important, not only by the members of this parliament but by the people in the community at large, and particularly by younger people.

After all, the emphasis of Australia Remembers has been on educating young people in Australia, and many young people I think have had the benefit, during the Australia Remembers year, of perhaps understanding more fully than they have ever understood before what actually went on in Australia in those dark years between 1939 and 1945. To the extent that the minister has overseen this particular year and largely been responsible for the success of it, he deserves congratulations.

But the important point that needs to be made in the context of this legislation is that we in this place ought always be concerned to ensure that benefits for veterans are in no way diminished. In fact, in opposition it is easy to argue that they should be enhanced, but the important thing that we ought to accept as a starting point is that they should be no further diminished. By and large, this particular legislation advantages veterans to the extent that it brings them into line with Department of Social Security beneficiaries, and for that reason the opposition does not oppose it.

One other matter in the broad context of veterans' affairs that I want to raise while the minister is here is the concern that still exists in New South Wales about the downgrading of care to veterans and war widows as a result of proposed changes to the domiciliary nursing service. Some time ago I raised this matter in a veterans' affairs debate, and the minister at the time kindly picked up the point and corresponded with me in some detail about it. I raise the matter again because, despite the assurances he gave me in the particular letter he wrote, I am not yet convinced that there is not still a real concern here. Certainly the nurses in the private sector in New South Wales are still telling me that they are concerned, and I share their concern about the potential impact that this may have on 7,000—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are concerned for themselves.

—I think that is an aspersion, Mr Speaker, that the minister has cast on the nurses concerned that I would not be a party to. I believe their concern is for veterans. After all, they are serving 7,000 veterans and war widows. Their concern is that under the new arrangements the patients they have are no longer entitled to be showered more than twice a week. I expect that everyone in this place has at least two showers a week. But I am now informed by the nurses in New South Wales that this service to veterans has actually been—
—We all shower many times.

—All of us on this side shower many times, at least once a day, yet here I am being told by the domiciliary nurses in New South Wales that in fact veterans are now not able to be showered more than twice a week. So I raise this matter with the minister again, and I ask him, in the spirit he has adopted in the past, to have another look at it. I want to make the point that veterans are entitled to a high quality of service to meet the special needs they have. I commend this particular issue to him so that he may have another look at it and perhaps, as he has done in the past, get back to me and let me know that the matter is being properly addressed.
—Order! It being 3 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Do you agree with the self-styled `Minister for Superannuation', Mr Sciacca, who yesterday claimed that $180 billion of net foreign debt could be paid back in four or five years? Do you support his proposal to take the superannuation savings of Australians and use them to pay back the foreign indebtedness of Australia's private and public sectors?

—I think the issue that was raised yesterday by the minister assisting me on superannuation is an important one—that is, that foreign debt has to be seen against a growing pool of superannuation assets. Of course, we all know that superannuation assets are going to grow very strongly in the future. They will probably double in the next five years and grow to about a trillion dollars by 2010 and a couple of trillion by the year 2020.

PARA.TAB: We know that we have rapidly growing superannuation funds coming through the system which this government has put in place. That certainly will do wonders for improving our savings performance. We know that that kind of delivery of savings will give us a boost of 1 1/2 per cent of GDP on top of the half per cent that we are currently getting by the year 2000. We will have two per cent of GDP by then, three per cent by the year 2005 and some four per cent by the year 2020. These are very considerable increases in savings.

It should especially be noted that they will come in very substantially in the next decade. It is not something that is off in 2020 or 2040 or something, as the opposition continually tries to make out. It is something that is going to have an impact in the next decade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the Treasurer has been asked whether or not he agrees with the claim of his junior minister that foreign debt can be paid back in four or five years and whether superannuation should be taken to do it. He should state clearly whether he agrees or he should walk away from the minister, as he is in effect trying to do.

—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition knows, in terms of responses given within this place, that if it is relevant it is acceptable. The minister has been asked a question about superannuation. He is responding directly to that question.

—Order! This is not a point of order.
—On that basis—
—No, no. The member for Flinders—
—If I may just finish, Mr Speaker—
—You will not debate it. You will just put the point of order.
—I only put the point to you that it is a very grave matter, and therefore on this occasion this question should be specifically answered.
—No, there is no point of order.
—You should not allow the broader gambit—

—Resume your seat! I again simply say to the honourable member that if he believes in some way that the House would be assisted by a tighter definition of relevance then he should go to an amendment to the standing orders. The Treasurer is in order, as I have said.

—I will finalise the answer. In his speech the minister assisting me for superannuation made the point that under us there would be no direction of investments. He made that point specifically in the speech and, as I have made clear many times over the course of this year, it is not government policy to give directions as to where superannuation assets should be invested. That is a matter for the funds themselves to decide in terms of what they see as an appropriate investment under the obligations that the trustees have to invest to the best benefit of the members. That is the overriding obligation on the trustees and we will not be directing them in a way that would interfere with that overriding right; we will not be directing them at all in terms of where to invest their funds.

PARA.TAB: That is not to say that we cannot encourage them to invest in certain ways, and various statements have been made about that. Whether superannuation funds want to invest to take up particular debt instruments that might be available through a refinancing arrangement is a matter for them to decide. If they believe that is an appropriate form of investment, that is open to them. It would be one possible form of investment, but there is a multitude of possible forms of investment. If they want to invest that way, that is open to them.

It is important to note that over the next five years the growth of savings through superannuation will be greater than the current amount of foreign debt, and I think that was the point that the minister assisting me for superannuation was essentially making.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Can he advise the House on the latest developments in the home loan market and outline the benefits that these developments are providing to home buyers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. It raises an important issue. As members are aware, interest rates, particularly home mortgage interest rates, are something that the community generally takes a great interest in. Of course, since the end of last year there has been a downward drift in the average mortgage rate of interest paid, as shown by the fact that on the stock of loans the average rate at the end of December last year was 10.01 per cent and in September this year, the latest figures we have, it was 9.67 per cent. So we have seen this downward drift. People might say, `How can that be with the variable rate at 10 1/2 per cent?' That is because there are other rates, which are increasingly important in terms of the total volume of mortgages, which are not on the bank variable rate.

PARA.TAB: In that respect, fixed rate loans are of growing importance. They account for about one-quarter of outstanding mortgages, and the rate of a three-year fixed mortgage fell from 10.3 per cent in December of last year to 9.6 per cent in September, reflecting falling interest rates in the bond market. So we have had a considerable decline in the rates of fixed rate loans. The loans need not be fixed for just three years; they can be for two years, three years or five years. But all of them have been coming down based on that falling interest rate in the bond market. At present, home buyers on a three-year fixed rate mortgage can get a loan at 9 1/4 per cent, so considerably less than the 9.6 per cent in September.

Another major influence on this decline in interest rates has been the impact of new entrants to the home lending market. These include mortgage originators such as Aussie Home Loans, which I am sure most members are familiar with, as well as new lenders backed by superannuation funds, life insurance companies and even the RACV in Victoria.

The development of strong regional banks and the conversion of some building societies into banks have also added to the level of competition. The mortgage originators are offering variable rate mortgages at on average around 1 1/4 percentage points below those of the major banks, so they are on average around 9 1/4 per cent instead of 10 1/2 per cent, and some individual lenders are offering loans at rates below nine per cent. The superannuation members home loan scheme established by the National Mutual company with a number of industry funds is lending money for home loans at 8.7 per cent.

These new lenders are posing a major threat to the market position of the major banks. The first reaction of the banks has been to try to remain competitive in the new home loan market while protecting the margins on their existing stock of loans. You have the so-called honeymoon rates, which apply to about 20 per cent of the outstanding mortgages—essentially the first year of a loan. Those rates are around 2 1/2 per cent less than the 10 1/2 per cent variable mortgage rate. At present they are around 7.9 per cent. Just a couple of days ago, Advance Bank announced that it would reduce its honeymoon rate to 7 3/4 per cent. Through this way, through the honeymoon rate, we can see a considerable reduction in mortgage interest rates for those new home buyers coming in in their first year. It is possible for people—perhaps through threatening to go off to a mortgage originator—to have the bank continue that loan or some other discounted loan to keep them in their books. I am sure members are not unfamiliar with circumstances in which that has happened.

An article in today's Financial Review reports that the major banks are launching new mortgage companies offering no-frills, budget-priced home loans. Once again, this is an attempt to compete directly with the mortgage originators in the new home loan market, while protecting the margins on their loans to existing customers. This policy has been one of trying to compete with the mortgage originators in respect of the new home buyers, whilst protecting the rates that they are charging on the existing stock of mortgages.

That becomes an increasingly difficult tactic to pursue. We finally saw a breakthrough in that yesterday with the announcement by St George Bank that they are going to cut their variable mortgage rate by 0.5 per cent for customers who have had mortgages for over five years, taking that rate to under 10 per cent. That, of course, is a very significant move. I think that is the beginning of a number of cuts that we will see in variable mortgage rates. Other banks will be forced by competition to make similar cuts.
Today we have Mr Haydn Park of the National Australia Bank saying that his bank `could not rule out similar loyalty rate cuts'. We have Westpac saying:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . rewarding customer loyalty is important and this [cutting rates] is one of many good ways to do it. We are also looking at ways to do so.
We have seen a couple of banks going on the record today to say that they are looking closely at cuts in their rates.

PARA.TAB: What we have therefore is a situation where competition in the banking industry, which is itself much more competitive than it ever was before this government came into office, plus the new players in the game—the mortgage originators and other companies like superannuation companies and life insurance companies that are getting into the mortgage business—are putting enormous pressure on the banking industry to reduce its overall home loans. We have seen that in respect of the honeymoon rates in particular but now we are starting to see it in respect of the stock of loans. We can clearly expect that there will be further cuts in variable mortgage rates as this competitive factor continues to bite.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. What motivation was there for your former ALP colleagues to fabricate evidence against you?
—Order! The question is out of order. It does not go to the minister's responsibilities. I call the honourable member for Werriwa.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: under standing order 145 I would submit that that question is, firstly, within the standing orders with regard to her jurisdiction and responsibility to answer here at the dispatch box. Secondly, it is within a series of questions which have been raised with regard to the royal commission over the course of this spring session of federal parliament and, as such, the parliament is entitled to know her answer, especially as the parliament has before it legislation to pay her bills on this very matter.

—Order! No, the question went to an issue about former colleagues of the now Minister for Human Services and Health. In my view, it does not go to issues of her responsibilities as a federal minister.

PARA.TAB: The point surely is that in reply the minister said that she rejected the findings of the royal commissioner, and therefore she rejected the testimony of all her former colleagues. There were 14 people against one minister. Eight of her former colleagues—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the point of order, having now put that preamble, is?

—The substance of the point of order is that if the minister's defence is that her former cabinet colleagues fabricated evidence against her—which was her defence yesterday—why on earth is it out of order to ask a question about their motivations on the fabrication of that evidence?

—Mr Speaker—

—I have heard argument now from both the Leader of the National Party and the Leader of the Opposition in respect of this. I propose to move on unless there is some substantive motion which dissents from my ruling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COSTELLO
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Speaker's ruling be dissented from.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, this parliament has been addressing matters arising from the Marks royal commission for months. You have allowed every single one of those questions. You have given rulings making it in order for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to stand up and berate, in answers to questions, a royal commissioner who conducted a properly constituted royal commission.

PARA.TAB: You ruled that it was possible for the Prime Minister to go to matters that were before that royal commission, and it must have been on the basis that the royal commission and the questions that it was directed to went to the very heart of this minister's fitness for office. There is obviously a connection with asking questions in this parliament which go to a minister's fitness for office. To rule out any question which goes to the credibility of this minister, to rule out any question which is designed to elicit information on the basis of which she could possibly displace the finding of a royal commission that she lied, and is a liar, and is therefore unfit to hold office—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will not go to language which has been ruled successively as unparliamentary. There are other words that may be used. Let us set the standard now.
—Oh, we are going to set the standard now, are we?
—For this debate.
—We are going to set the standard now, after you have allowed the Prime Minister in this parliament—
—For this debate. I have just told you what will be acceptable. Keep going.
—to engage in the most blackguard conduct against the royal commission in Western Australia—

—On a point of order: this is a narrow technical debate on whether or not a particular question conforms with standing orders. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is not entitled to canvass previous debates in this place in the course of his argument. That is irrelevant to the pure technical point of whether or not this is valid.

—Order! Whilst there is some validity in what the Leader of the House has said, this matter which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition now wishes to go to concerns whether or not the ruling I gave was in fact appropriate. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has the call, but again I simply say to all members in this debate that there is parliamentary language which is not acceptable.

—Mr Speaker, I rely on the findings of the royal commissioner himself. The royal commissioner has found that this minister did not tell the truth: did not tell the truth to the Western Australian parliament; did not tell the truth at the National Press Club; did not tell the truth to the Australian public; and, ipso facto, has not told the truth to this parliament because she has stood by all of those untruths which she gave at the National Press Club and in this parliament and was not capable of telling the truth in the royal commission itself. —I raise a point of order. Mr Speaker, this is a narrow technical debate and I go to the point: did you rule correctly when you dealt with the question of whether or not the minister's portfolio or her conduct of office was the subject of the question? You ruled that it was not. We have here a set of arguments about what the minister had to say in a speech to the National Press Club about five or six months ago—a long, detailed argument about that—which cannot possibly go to the question of whether or not the question is relevant within the framework of the standing orders.

—Once again I say to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that I am trying to give some fairness here. —I note in passing that the government argues that no minister can be confined to the substance of a question when he is asked a question, as you saw with the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in relation to the first question. Yet when a motion comes on, you have to have the most strict and narrow construction on it, don't you? It's funny, isn't it, how you argue the standing orders in this place. It's very funny, isn't it, how when a question is asked of that side of the parliament it gives rise to a general speech about anything, regardless of the terms of the question. Yet when we take on a Speaker's ruling, you argue for the most narrow constriction that's possible. It's funny, isn't it, that you rely upon the Speaker to try to advance that case.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that this is a ruling which the Speaker cannot maintain on the basis of the past conduct in this House. This Speaker has allowed question after question in relation to the royal commission. He has allowed question after question as to the matters that were traversed before that royal commission. Now that you have the finding, now that the actual facts are in, now that all the evidence has been heard and now that the judicial officer has actually reported, the Speaker wants to rule that you cannot traverse any of those matters. That indicates that there are—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. We are getting a load of unction here, but absolutely no argument on the technical point. The member is getting up and saying, `The world is unjust.' That is not an argument to the point.
—Order! There is no point of order. The deputy leader is canvassing issues. I call the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

—The argument, quite simply, my friend, is that, by reason of the previous rulings and the previous questions and the previous answers that have been given, this is a totally inconsistent ruling. PARA.TAB: So plainly it is absolutely inconsistent today for the Speaker to move of his own notion that a question which was allowed yesterday on a number of occasions, and answers which were given yesterday on a number of occasions, cannot be traversed again today. The Leader of the National Party today wants to take up the very nub of the question because she says, as she said yesterday, and as allowed by the Speaker in answer to a validly put question yesterday—which he wants to rule out today—that she was entitled to reject the findings. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. —Order! Again I remind the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that that is the circumstance and he might come back to that, specifically.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Beazley

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The question relates to standing order 142:

INTERJECT.PARA: Questions may be put to a Minister relating to public affairs with which—
is officially connected, to proceedings pending in the House, or to any matter of administration for which—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I did say in ruling the question of the Leader of the National Party out of order that the matter which he asked for a response to did not go to the matters of ministerial responsibility of the minister in this House. That is the matter which is being dissented from. I would ask the deputy leader to confine himself to that.

—There can be no clearer matter that goes to a minister and their relation to public affairs than their credibility. There can be no clearer matter because if a minister cannot be believed, a minister really cannot in this House answer any question with any assurance that any person can rely on it. There is no question that this goes to fitness for office and, therefore, that it goes right to the heart of ministerial responsibility.

PARA.TAB: The whole of question time in this place operates on the assumption that when a question is asked and an answer is given, the answer will be truthful. If there is a minister who has no record for telling the truth, the whole of question time falls apart, the whole of ministerial accountability falls apart, the whole of the Westminster system falls apart. TALK.START.PARA: —He said, `We are working on it.'

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. —Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has the call on this motion of dissent against Mr Speaker's ruling. I ask him to come to that matter.

—I point out to the Acting Prime Minister that he will get an opportunity to put his case. He can stand up and argue his case. There is no reason to get up on spurious points of order in trying to argue his case in relation to this matter. —Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will come back to the technical aspects of this debate.

—We can only attend to all of those things if you are allowed to put questions in order to get answers. There can be no closer connection with the ministerial obligation of a minister under the Westminster system in question time than the obligation to tell the truth. There can be no clearer duty than the one a minister has when giving an answer to make sure that they do not mislead the House.

PARA.TAB: Since the Westminster system began—it has been recognised in this country during the history of this parliament—misleading the House has always been considered an axiomatic ground for dismissal. There is no clearer principle of ministerial accountability than the one which states that any person who misleads this parliament is not fit for office. PARA.TAB: If it were irrelevant to canvass these matters, and if it were irrelevant to put them to the Minister for Human Services and Health, how could it be relevant for the Prime Minister in an answer to engage in the blackguarding of the commission that he did? SPEECH.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. Now that the Marks royal commission has found that you have been untruthful about your knowledge and involvement in the Easton affair, is it your position that lying when holding high public office does not matter?

Questions may be put to a Minister relating to public affairs with which the Minister is officially connected, to proceedings pending in the House, or to any matter of administration for which the Minister is responsible.

SPEECH.PARA: I have here a legal opinion which you thought suited your convenience. It is a legal opinion prepared on this very point. It has actually been tabled in this chamber. It is dated 22 August 1995 and it is from none other than the Solicitor-General, Gavan Griffith. Let me refer you to the fourth paragraph of this legal opinion. I will read the whole thing so that the point is not lost on anybody. It says:
To avoid this difficulty, and in order to enable payment to be made . . .

Let me pause there. This is the payment to be made out of taxpayers' funds for the minister's legal expenses—the expenses specifically relating to her challenge to the jurisdiction of the Marks royal commission. The advice goes on:

To avoid this difficulty, and in order to enable payment to be made out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance for legal expenses as they are incurred (with that payment subsequently confirmed by formal appropriation), reliance may reasonably be had on the alternative source of legal authority in paragraph 4(4)(b) for the payment as a benefit `afforded by the Government to a Minister for the purpose of carrying out functions as a Minister'.
It continues:

Given the public acknowledgment by those initiating and supporting the Marks Commission, as well as those opposing it, that the matters being inquired of are directed to the issue of Dr Lawrence's continuing fitness for public office as a Commonwealth minister, these matters are open to be regarded by Cabinet as directly relevant to her continuing to carry out her functions as a minister.

This is the government's legal advice. This is part of their defence of the appropriation of public funds for the minister's legal expenses. In the light of that legal opinion, how can you then claim, as you do, Mr Speaker, in support of your ruling, that this matter is beyond those public affairs with which the minister is officially connected? The whole basis of the argument in support of the paying of her legal fees is in fact that those affairs are directly related to her functions as a minister.

PARA.TAB: Quite frankly, Mr Speaker, this is a complete and absolute repudiation of the basis of your ruling. You do not have a leg to stand on. Quite frankly, if you wanted to do the right thing, you would now ask me to take my seat and you would admit that you are wrong. Unless this was a High Court judgment, there is no more conclusive repudiation of your claim. Given that fact, we are therefore entitled to ask: on what basis could this ruling possibly be made?

Mr Speaker, once your explanation for the ruling is made and rejected, I am afraid we are going to have to hunt around and see what other reasons there might be, given that that one is entirely without foundation. When you look at the reasons for that, I would have to say that this whole Lawrence matter has just been a campaign of smear and intimidation by the Labor Party of many of the persons associated with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. He is now spoiling an excellent start by deviating from the technical argument about whether or not your particular ruling is correct and engaging in a sort of general spreading of calumny around the place. He was being pretty good for the first five or six minutes and you ought to bring him back to that style of argument.
—Order! The member for Flinders, in fact, was canvassing the issue before the chair and I ask him to stick on that particular track.

—I am certainly sticking on it, as uncomfortable as it might be for the government. Let us just look at the question because it was a very simple one. In fact, it was so simple that this minister was not prepared to answer it. The question was: what motivation was there for your former colleagues to fabricate evidence against you? It was a very critical question because part of this minister's campaign of defence is to say that this is a matter which has arisen on our side of politics. The truth is that it arose on her side of politics with her colleagues. It is the evidence of her Labor Party colleagues in Western Australia which has damned this minister. It is not the evidence of the Liberals that has been so critical in the decision of the royal commission. In fact, it is the evidence of a long list of her former parliamentary colleagues.

PARA.TAB: I talk of people such as Keith Wilson. When Keith Wilson's views about this started to surface, what was the first reaction of the Labor Party? They went on a campaign of character assassination against a very decent Australian—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: this again is not argument to the topic. The topic is quite clear: have you in fact ruled correctly under standing order 142 on this question, as opposed to previous questions? The debate was being engaged by the honourable member. He is not now. He is now canvassing the royal commission. It is irrelevant.
—Order! Again I remind the honourable member for Flinders that it is a rather limited area. You have been going to the specifics of that matter. I would invite you to stay in that area.

—I have been quite specific in responding to the issue. I must say, though, that we have had a series of spurious points of order from the Leader of the House. This is something, quite frankly, we are rather used to. If there is to be any fair play, then I invite you to deal with him as you so often threaten to deal with us.

PARA.TAB: The way I have remained within the confines of this specific motion is by referring exactly to the question. I am referring exactly to the question. I am entitled to look behind the question and the basis upon which the question was to be asked because it goes directly to the minister for health's fitness as a minister, which Gavan Griffith, the Solicitor-General, says when it comes to her legal expenses is in fact a matter within her official functions as a minister. That is my argument.

Perhaps you do not quite catch the gravity of this argument, Mr Speaker. What I am handing you is a complete denial of what you say. You have absolutely nothing now to sail with. Your argument is completely in tatters. Your argument being in tatters entitles me to be relevant, to read out whose evidence it was that damned this minister: Keith Wilson; Pam Beggs; Jim McGinty, the leader of the Labor Party in Western Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —Time for a point of order.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order—
—Perhaps the member for Mayo might not prompt the Leader of the House.

—It seems we are educating the opposition front bench on standing orders. It is about time they learned. He has again deviated from the technical argument that he started addressing well. He even had a mention or two at the beginning of this particular peroration, but he has again deviated from it.
—The member for Flinders has the call.
—Keith Wilson. Pam Beggs. Jim McGinty. Ian Taylor. Do you know that name, Kim? Judyth Watson. Eric Ripper. Geoff Gallop. John Kobelke. Who are they?
—All mates of mine.
—All mates of yours.
—Mr Speaker—
—The Leader of the House does not have the call yet. Resume your seat.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: how does this actually relate to the question at issue here, which is whether or not your ruling is correct under standing order 142? Again he started with it and then deviated from it. I ask you to bring him back to the argument before him.
—Again, I do remind the member for Flinders of the specifics of the matter and I ask him to come back.

—I need no reminding, I can assure you, Mr Speaker. It is the minister who finds trouble with being reminded of the names of those who have given evidence. What will he say on his next point of order? Will he say that they are all liars? Is that what he will say? Will he say that they are motivated by the desire to see the Liberal Party elected in the federal election? Are they motivated by a desire to see the reputation of this minister shredded between now and the next election? Aren't these Labor people, all of them? Let us just look at this list.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order—

—Order! The Leader of the House will resume his seat. The member for Flinders has been there. Can I invite him now to come back to the specifics of this motion, which deals with me and not what the minister might do or say.

—No. 2, staff officials, 4: Marcelle Anderson, chief executive of the department of cabinet; Bob Willoughby, senior media secretary; Zoltan Kovacs, media secretary; Estelle Blackburn, former press secretary to the Premier. What are they? All liars? Are they all paid-up members of the Liberal Party, Minister? Stephen Imms. Francis Sullivan.

PARA.TAB: What did the royal commissioner say? He said, `Fourteen persons, all of whom supported Dr Lawrence's government and/or worked for it, contradicted her claim—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have already cautioned the member for Flinders that the motion before the chair goes to my ruling. I invite him to come back to that specific matter.

—Mr Speaker, let me conclude. The fact of the matter is that we have been entitled, with your consent, to your acquiescence, your support, if you like, to ask questions on this matter now for weeks and weeks and weeks. That is point No. 1, Mr Speaker—you are inconsistent. This is a pathetic ruling and people will see through it for the politics which they will assume are behind it. That is the first point, and it does you no credit, Mr Speaker.

PARA.TAB: The second point is that the legal basis upon which you have made your ruling, quite frankly, is a fabrication. It must be the strongest case I have ever put. This is game, set and match, Mr Speaker. The fact is, Mr Speaker, you—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The fact is your time has expired.
—ought to be embarrassed by it.
—Resume your seat!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the House)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition tactics committee, Mr Speaker, has made a silly mistake in the question that they put before you. In being careful in the past in the way in which they have asked questions about this when they have actually attempted to relate it to issues of fitness for office, or attempted to relate it to the opinions of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) on whether or not she believes that a certain standard of behaviour is required of ministers in a contemporary context, they have at least kept a fig leaf of connection with standing order 142—and that is why your generous interpretations of standing order 142 in the past on this matter have been totally applicable and properly upheld. Let us remind ourselves of what standing order 142 says. It says this:

PARA.TAB: Questions may be put to a Minister relating to public affairs with which he is officially connected, to proceedings pending in the House, or to any other matter of administration for which he is responsible.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, it is a standing order which has generally been adhered to over the years very strictly.

PARA.TAB: These standing orders were not written by this government, nor might I say—because they were canvassed in the course of debate in a manner critical of you—were the standing orders relating to relevance in answers written by this government. These standing orders were last revised in detail both as to the relevance area and generally on the way in which the questions under standing orders have related by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who sits over there doing those revisions of those standing orders, and we have not altered them. We have implemented them and Speakers, including yourself, have implemented them with a slightly higher degree of generosity than has been the case in our experience of Liberal Party Speakers in opposition—and I still have been here long enough to be able to remember them—but, nevertheless, fairly.

If you actually go to the very questions that were asked yesterday that you permitted under standing orders and the question asked specifically here today, you get both the answer as to why you ruled this one out and not them and you also get the answer as to why that particular set of opinions which goes to fitness to office, which of course does legitimise questions to the Minister for Human Services and Health—you get an argument around the royal commission—that rules some questions in order if you sustain your argument within it.

Dr Wooldridge's question yesterday was referred to by the opposition spokesman on parliamentary matters, the manager of opposition business. I will go to his arguments because at least he made a fig leaf attempt at addressing the standing orders in this regard as opposed to the meretricious player that kicked off the debate, who made absolutely no attempt whatsoever and thought he could get up with his usual 20 minutes of calumny and not be interrupted during the course of this.
But, to go to the questions asked yesterday, the conclusion of question No. 1 from the honourable member for Chisholm was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . is it your position that lying when holding high public office does not matter?
That went to a question, that was obviously immediately relevant, as to the conduct of affairs in the portfolio of the honourable member. Then it goes on:
. . . as the Prime Minister considers lying no disqualification for office in his government, what reason is there to think that any other minister in the government is more honest than you are?

I must say that that was skating on pretty thin ice, but at least it had some element of relevance. Then the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) went on to request of her that she put her interests over those of her Labor colleagues behind her. In descending order, that last one was very close to the edge, but at least they went to questions of contemporary administration.

PARA.TAB: But what was this question? This question said, `Can you explain the motives of a set of members, X, Y, Z'—full stop, end of story—not `Does that relate to your fitness to hold public office; does that relate to whether or not you believe ministers ought to be truthful before parliament; does that relate to whether or not there is some other aspect of the activity of the royal commission that challenges whether or not you ought to be in office?' It was simply this: `What is your opinion of X, Y, Z'—full stop, end of story. There was no remote effort to make a connection between that and the issues that are matters of debate here.

I know it is extremely difficult for people who watch question time in the parliament or who watch parliamentary proceedings generally to understand or contemplate the standing orders under which debate takes place in this place or under which questions are asked in this place. They are in fact the product, over time, of a series of intricately devised standing orders that require certain forms at certain times.

I can recollect, when I happened to be a backbencher confronted with the issues of whether or not questions were relevant, that I would get up and ask a question, and Billy Snedden, the Speaker of the day, would simply say, `Out of order'—no explanation. Criticism went to you, Mr Speaker, for example, that you had failed to give an appropriate explanation for your ruling. I must inform the honourable member, and I thought he would have known this, that you are not obliged to.

I can recollect, at the time I was ruled out of order on a number of occasions by Speaker Snedden, I did not stand up in parliament and grizzle my head off about whether or not Billy Snedden was a fair Speaker. I went to the whip and said, `Why does this outrageous old buzzard rule me out of order?' The response of the whip as to why that outrageous old buzzard had ruled me out of order was that I was. There was a simple, competent performance by the whip and the tactics committee to tell me, `Look, old son, you've got it wrong; you were probably trying to ask a question about something that you were entitled to ask a question about, but you just did it the wrong way and that is all there was to it'.

At least we as an opposition used to sit down and cop it when we were wrong. We didn't get up smarting and puking as the opposition has on this particular matter, saying `Somebody has taken our bat and ball away; let's give the umpire a bit of a whack behind the ear; don't let ourselves go through a bit of self-criticism on this and say, "Hang on, we got away with those three questions yesterday; why didn't we get away with the one today? This has been a Speaker who has been prepared to treat us very generously on this as the months have gone by as far as these discussions are concerned; is it just possible that, in the circumstances where we have been entitled to ask 30-odd questions on this matter and we finally find ourselves not entitled to ask one—the one question being `What is your opinion of the views of X, Y and Z'—full stop, end of story, no relationship to anything—it just might be that for once the question might be out of order?"'

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. The point of order is relevance to this issue. This is a very technical matter, and I would ask you to get the Deputy Prime Minister—who has been very specific on these very technical matters—to get back to the issue, or maybe give up the debate.
—Order! I thought the Leader of the House was being specific to the matter.

—Now you have got to talk to your whips again and get an understanding of relevance here. Take a look at the questions you asked yesterday, which included words like, `Is it your position that lying when holding high public office does not matter?', which goes very close to a question of opinion. You could perhaps well argue that you are entitled to know the views of ministers of the Crown as to what they view as acceptable standards of conduct in regard to their holding of office.

PARA.TAB: Those are questions you have asked of me in relation to the royal commission; those are questions you have asked of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in relation to these matters; those are questions you have asked of the Minister for Human Services and Health in relation to these matters. Has the Speaker prevented you from asking these questions? No. Not once has the Speaker prevented you from asking all those sorts of questions. So what is different with the question today?

Your interpretation is that somehow or other some giant conspiracy has descended upon the Speaker's chair. That is what you suggested—some giant conspiracy has descended upon the head of the Speaker and all of a sudden he has had a new revelation and he intends to completely overthrow everything he has done before. It does not strike the heads of wood opposite that there might just be a possibility that they have actually got a question wrong in the way in which they have formulated it and that they have abused—

TALK.START.PARA: —How was it wrong?

—Your others are teachable, Alexander, but you are not. That we do know on this subject, so I cannot respond to your interjection. I have been explaining how it was wrong for at least the first 10 minutes of the remarks I have made. If you have not picked that up by now, then too bad for you.

PARA.TAB: There is another thing that you ought to comprehend. Speakers do not simply act off their own bat as far as these issues are concerned. A prudent Speaker will consult the clerk regularly on the subject of what is or is not in order, particularly when handling sensitive matters. You are on a fine line as to whether you are breaching standing order 142. You may assume—I say this without knowing—that because there have been these matters which skate along the edges of standing order 142, the Speaker has been diligent in consulting the clerk and those who have the collective memory of this place as to what goes over the line and what does not.

When you have had 30 questions ruled as though they do not go over the line and then one is ruled the other way, the possibility might be that in his head the Speaker holds a very detailed view about what is and is not appropriate in standing orders on this and has thought that through very carefully. If you take it a point beyond that and actually go to the question itself, the answer will strike you like a silver bullet as to why that would be the case.

Even the heads of oak of those opposite will be penetrated by that silver bullet. They will find that a vague question that has been put down in this regard would be out of order and out of order for two reasons. It is, purely and simply, an opinion. `What is the motivation of X, Y and Z before that royal commission?' It just might be possible that the Speaker might get it into his head that that is purely and simply a request for an opinion, which is not permitted outside the person's portfolio. You might just get it into your head that this question was not portfolio related and not standards related or anything else. The dawning of wisdom on this matter might just get through to you.

When you look at the rest of the question for some relationship between any answer on that and, specifically, any matter related to holding high public office, which was the question of yesterday but not in question today, it might just strike you that perhaps the old tactics committee—all the folk that we hugely pay here, the brains trust of our front bench, the collective genius of the Liberal Party—has come to a point where it forgot to add the coda. Perhaps it has got to the point where it might have had something wrong.

This is an absolute waste of the time of this parliament. What would have been sensible for the opposition, when they heard that, would have been for them to have comprehended immediately why the question was out of order. Any person on our front bench could work out at least a dozen ways to get that question up that made it specific in a way that came within the framework of the rulings that you have made to this point. You would have actually gone back and said, `I am sorry, Tim has been made a patsy of again. The Liberal Party people who wrote his question for him a la Sinclair's suggestions about him have sent him over the hill to be shot to pieces yet again, which is becoming a depressing habit on the part of the Liberal Party as far as these matters are concerned.' It might just have grabbed them that perhaps they ought to have gone back and got a National Party bloke to have drafted it so that he was not humiliated.

Mr Speaker, as far as this question is concerned, you are absolutely correct in your ruling. These are smarting, playground tactics, wasting the time of this parliament. The question could have been got up in another way, instead of the spurious way in which it was raised, if they had wanted to do so. No harm would have been done and the parliament could have proceeded. But their idiocy, which they now attempt to cover by a 45-minute debate, deserves the dismissal it will get. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Costello's) be agreed to.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

PARA.TAB: With the significant achievement of the Prime Minister in Osaka at the weekend in lowering external trade barriers, it was important that we also lower internal trade barriers in Australia. —I don't have to read on. I have enough there to know that you do not know what you are talking about. Let me explain why.
