DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR HUMAN SERVICES AND HEALTH

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Howard) proposed:

That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith that this House censures the Minister for Human Services and Health for her failure to resign following the findings of the Marks Royal Commission.
Mr Beazley—We accept the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

PARA.TAB: Mr Tim Fischer—I second the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative, with an absolute majority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House censures the Minister for Human Services and Health for her failure to resign following the findings of the Marks Royal Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I have moved this censure motion when I have for one very simple reason: that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) has been given ample opportunities today and yesterday to explain. She has been indicted in a way that no other minister in post Second World War Australian federal politics has. She is a minister whose reputation has been systematically dismantled by a royal commission and is a person whose political reputation and integrity has been destroyed, not by the actions of the Western Australian Liberal government but by the actions of her own former Labor colleagues.

PARA.TAB: The reason that we bring on this motion when we do is that, during the past couple of days, the minister and the government have had ample opportunity to explain to the parliament and, through the parliament, to the Australian people why it is that Marks got it wrong; why it is that her former Labor colleagues got it wrong; and why, in defiance of all convention and all semblance of the basis of our Westminster system, this utterly discredited minister should choose to cling to office. It is in defiance of one of the most damning findings that any minister could have had brought against her. The real nub of this whole issue—and it is not the nub of the Marks royal commission—about her fitness to remain in office is summed up in a paragraph in the Marks royal commission. Commissioner Marks said in paragraph 4.1.5:
A remarkable feature of the evidence of the fourteen witnesses was that none had an interest in falsifying the essential thrust of what he or she said.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, Commissioner Marks was talking about something that goes to the very substance of this whole debate: that none of the 14 people who gave evidence against Carmen Lawrence in the royal commission had a vested interest in falsifying their evidence. If anything, they had a vested interest in giving evidence that would support her, because they were former Labor colleagues. Minister, you had taken the same oath or affirmation; you had stood shoulder to shoulder in the same government. These were not Liberals who were bringing you down; these were not Liberals who were calling you a liar—an accusation that has been substantiated by the royal commissioner—these were Labor colleagues of your own.

PARA.TAB: It is no wonder that Kim Beazley gets very nervous every time we read out the list. Let's see whether the puppet is still activated. Let's see whether Billy Bunter over there is still sensitive to what is being said. I will read out the names again. Let me make it clear that the context in which I use these names is very important in that it was the words, the evidence and the blowing of her cover by Keith Wilson that really led to the foundation of this royal commission. I have to say to you, Minister, that you have been found guilty of what can only be described as the Watergate syndrome. Everybody in Australia knows that you conspired to lodge that petition. You know it; your former Labor colleagues know it. If you had had the guts to stand up in the Western Australian parliament three years ago and admit that you had made a mistake, your reputation would not now be in tatters.

That is your problem. Not only have you been found guilty of lying; you have been found guilty of monumental political incompetence. If you had had the courage to stand up and say, `We put it together. We thought that we would embarrass Richard Court. We thought that it would take some of the heat away from the fact that I was going to get sprung for keeping $5,000 of my imprest account in my private bank account for a couple of years and pretending that I had forgotten it,' and if you had had the courage to admit that you really did conspire with Halden and all your other mates, you would have done that and said to the Western Australian parliament, `You cannot blame us. We were trying to get something on Richard Court. We were trying to make Richard Court look a bit silly.' You then might have had a bit more credibility, and your reputation would not now be in tatters.

I go again and again to the constant claim that has been made in your defence by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). He has been unwilling to demand of you what Gough Whitlam demanded of Rex Connor and Jim Cairns and what he would have demanded of other ministers who deliberately lied to the parliament. Bob Hawke demanded the same of John Brown, although the latter did not deliberately mislead the public; he did it inadvertently. In other words, the whole basis of the defence that has been mounted of you is that in some way this has been a conspiracy against you by the Liberal Party. The defence is that it is all the fault of Richard Court and John Howard and that we all conspired to give evidence against you.

But I will read those names again: Keith Wilson, Pam Beggs, Jim McGinty, Ian Taylor, Judyth Watson, Eric Ripper, Geoff Gallop and John Kobelke. None of those people belong to the Liberal Party. All of them are members of the Western Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party, although I understand that, as a result of what has happened in this royal commission, Keith Wilson has decided not to renew his membership. None of those people conspired with Richard Court or John Halden. They have never met Keith Wilson. I do not think I have met any of them. I may have met Jim McGinty in passing. I do not remember ever having met any of them before. You have the nerve, gall and deceit, as has your leader, to tell the Australian people that we sat down and conspired with those people.

You know as well as I do that this thing would have been dead and buried if it had not been for the interview that Keith Wilson gave to Paul McGeough of the Sydney Morning Herald in April this year. That is what reignited it. It was all going swimmingly. Nobody had blown the cover. They were all prepared in the name of Labor loyalty to keep quiet and cover up your lie and deceit.

That got a little too much for Keith Wilson. He decided that he could not stomach it any longer. He stayed silent when he was a member of the government and he was not going to stay silent any more. Like the decent, honourable man that he is—and you know that he is—he spoke to Paul McGeough. Out of that little interview unfolded a whole chain of events that led to the establishment of the royal commission.

You and your bullyboy leader can slur and slander Kenneth Marks—you can under the cover of parliamentary privilege traduce the reputation of Kenneth Marks and anybody else you like—but nothing can hide the fact that you have been dobbed in by your Labor mates. They are the people who sprung your cover. They are the people who fingered you for the phoney that you are. It is all because you did not have the stomach to admit that you had made a mistake. You know in your heart that that is your problem. If you admitted your mistake, you would not now, in political terms, have your reputation in tatters.

We all make mistakes in politics—every last man and woman of us does—but your mistake was to pretend that you alone had never made a mistake. If you had had the honesty and the guts to go into the Western Australian parliament and admit it, you would not now have the problem.

But, if you imagine that we in the opposition and the Australian people will stand by and take this without let or hindrance and allow a Prime Minister to decimate the Westminster standard and say, `It is perfectly all right to lie because I am not going to exact any penalty against you,' you have another think coming. The whole edifice of our parliamentary system rests upon the accountability of ministers before this parliament and the bar of public opinion.

You know darned well, don't you, why several months ago you persistently refused to repeat in this House the denial of your involvement in the petition that you had given to the National Press Club? You know why you did that. You did not want that denial which you knew to be untrue on the record of this parliament. There is no other reason why you did not do it.

If you believed the denial that you gave to the National Press Club, why on earth did you not repeat this denial to the parliament? You knew that in technical terms you would be gone for all money because you would have misled the parliament. You did not repeat that denial because you knew that you would be writing into Hansard a statement you knew was untrue. There is no other explanation for it.

If you believed what you told the press club to be true, why on earth did you not repeat it in the parliament? The truth is that you knew then that that statement was untrue just as you knew the statement you gave to the Western Australian parliament was untrue. In those circumstances, you cannot imagine that we on this side of the House or many people around Australia will sit by and say, `It does not matter. It is perfectly all right for this woman to lie through her teeth. The Prime Minister is sticking up for her. We will forget about it.'

Fourteen people said that you were wrong. The only person marching in step with the regiment is Carmen. Every other person is wrong. The whole 14 of them are wrong. Some of them were cabinet colleagues, some of them were cabinet officials and some of them were personal staff. All of them were political allies. Not one of them was a Liberal, yet you allege that this is a Liberal conspiracy. Are you claiming that Kenneth Marks is a Liberal?

What kinds of standards do you have? You carry on as though it is unprecedented for a state administration of one political complexion to have an inquiry into the affairs of somebody of another political complexion. I do not remember Paul Keating, when he sat in this parliament in 1979, attacking the New South Wales government for persecuting the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). I do not remember the right honourable member for New England getting his legal costs paid as a result of that persecution. The truth of the matter is that you have been caught out and destroyed by your own deceit and the honesty of your former Labor colleagues. You have not been caught out and destroyed by a trumped up political kangaroo court or inquisition; you have been caught out and destroyed by your own deceit and your former political colleagues.

The extent to which you have been clinically destroyed in terms of your political integrity is found when you go through this report. I remind the House that the introduction of the report says there is a difference between an untruthful witness and an unreliable witness. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: A witness may not be prepared to tell the truth. More often, however, a witness is honest but unable to give a full or coherent or accurate account of events. It may result from genuine inability to remember, from poor ability with language or from pathology.

4.1.2A tribunal of fact, which this Commission was, must discern as best it can the essence of what may be distilled from the witnesses it finds honest, notwithstanding the existence, as invariably there is, of imperfect memory and loose use of language.
It then goes on to say at 4.1.5:
A remarkable feature of the evidence of the fourteen witnesses was that none had an interest in falsifying the essential thrust of what he or she said.

That really is the gravest load that you carry in this whole debate. These people were your former colleagues—some of them undoubtedly were your friends—yet on oath they were not prepared to substantiate what you said.

PARA.TAB: You will have an opportunity in a few moments when you come to the dispatch box to justify your rejection of what Keith Wilson, Pam Beggs, Jim McGinty and all the others said. You will have an opportunity to establish to this parliament how Kenneth Marks was wrong. You will have an opportunity to substantiate your allegation of a conspiracy between John Howard and Kenneth Marks and between John Howard and Richard Court. I invite you to take your whole 20 minutes trying to establish that link and that conspiracy, because I have to tell you that it does not exist.

You know that it does not exist. The reason it does not exist is that you have been undone not by me, Richard Court or Kenneth Marks but by your old Western Australian Labor mates. What has to be understood again and again in this whole debate is that we did not initiate it. If it had not been for Keith Wilson talking to the Sydney Morning Herald in April this year, you would never have had a royal commission. There was no way on earth that you would have.

The other thing that you know deep down to be the case is that, if you had had the honesty in 1992 to own up to the fact that you had made a mistake, this thing would have been dead and buried years ago. But, because you stubbornly believed that you alone were incapable of making a mistake or that in some way you were constitutionally unable to admit error like any other human being, you thought you could tough it out. It worked for a while. It worked for three years.

You swanned into federal politics. You came here with these shining credentials. You were above everybody else. Your standards were better than anybody else's. You were the shining saviour of the Australian Labor Party. The reality is that you have been revealed as somebody whose work cannot be trusted. The crowning insult to this parliament is that you presume still to stay on the front bench. You presume to say that we have nothing more to say about the matter, as though we and the Australian people are to be brushed aside as being of no account.

Even worse than all of that is that the Prime Minister is prepared to condone this kind of contempt for the Australian people. What sticks in the craw of many is that Keating will have a liar sit by his side until the election. That is what he will certainly do. He will have a liar side by side. If you imagine that this issue is finished just because you and your Prime Minister have toughed it out, it hasn't. It is an issue that is going to go on for a long time and it is going to stick in the craw of many thousands of Australians.

There are a lot of people out there who really think it is important that occasionally people in public life tell the truth. There are a lot of people out there who think accountability of ministers before parliament is the foundation of our system. There are a lot of people who still think teaching the value of candour and honesty in public life is an important principle. There are a lot of Australians who regard it as important no matter what side of politics you are on.

TALK.START.PARA: —You hypocrite; you unbelievable hypocrite!
—The Deputy Prime Minister can interject—
—I called you a hypocrite.
—Order! The Deputy Prime Minister will not do that.
—You can call me anything you like.
—No, he won't.

—Can I simply say for my part on this side of the House that, if the Labor Party wants to fight the next election campaign on personal integrity, bring on the election campaign. That is all that I can say.

PARA.TAB: Let me conclude my remarks by going back to the findings of this much abused, criticised and traduced individual, Mr Kenneth Marks—a man who had a reputation for political impartiality and professional skill in the years that he was a justice of one of the Victorian courts. He said on page 60 of his finding:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.2.9Dr Lawrence clearly fabricated the later discussion thesis as a device for nullifying Wilson's contention without accusing him of lying, which was potentially damaging politically. Wilson commanded a degree of respect. She gambled against the emergence of evidence which put paid to the suggestion that the same conversation occurred after the petition was tabled.

4.2.10Dr Lawrence even more clearly told an untruth to the Press Club at Canberra on 19 April 1995 when she said that she knew on Wednesday, 4 November that she would be exonerated in regard to the imprest account:
". . . . I clearly want to debunk the claim that I seized on this petition as a way to deflect attention from a police inquiry into my imprest account.
This is terrific stuff, a police inquiry into an imprest account of a Premier of a state. Terrific stuff! She continued:

The fact is that by the day before the tabling of the petition I was already aware that the inquiry was completed and that I would be exonerated and I checked that detail with the lawyer involved yesterday."
Mr Marks goes on to say:

4.2.11On the day before the tabling of the petition Dr Lawrence could not have been `already aware' that she would be exonerated because the decision not to charge her was not made by the Police Commissioner until the day following the tabling.

No wonder you were not prepared to confirm that statement to the parliament. You knew when you were asked that question in the parliament that the statement you had made to the press club was wrong, as well you knew the statement you made to the Western Australian parliament was wrong. You knew that if you repeated that statement you confirmed your earlier untruth before that dispatch box, and not even a person who is so insensitive to standards in public life as the Prime Minister would have the barefacedness to defend you and stand beside you as a minister.

PARA.TAB: So on every conceivable count this minister stands condemned. She used things for political purposes in questionable circumstances in 1992 when she was Premier of Western Australia. She would not have been the first person in politics to have done that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know all about that.
—You are irrelevant. Go back to sleep.
—Order! The member for Dunkley will not interject, particularly when he is out of his seat.

—Her real mistake, as she well knows, is that when it all went wrong she did not have the courage, the guts or the decency to say, `Yes, I was involved in talking about that petition. It was a mistake. I shouldn't have done it. I'm sorry, I didn't intend any adverse consequences.' If she had, people would have respected her for that, we would not now be having this debate, her reputation would not be in ruins, and all of her colleagues who will sit behind her and nod gravely as she speaks in her defence would not be as nervous about carrying a discredited liar into the next election campaign as the federal Minister for Human Services and Health.
—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawrence The Hon C.M.

TALKER.NAME: Dr LAWRENCE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Human Services and Health and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—
—Resign!

—It is very important for me to be able to stand here and go through some of the arguments about this matter, to do so clearly and, I hope, with reasonable hearing from those on the opposition benches—something I must say that has not been available to me often even when questions have been asked in this place, most of which I have answered in a due fashion, and when I have attempted to put my position before this parliament.

PARA.TAB: It is very clear, if you go back through the history of this matter—and I will do that very briefly—that the matters that were included in the petition that became known as the Easton petition were first raised by the Liberal Party. There has been no doubt about that, and it has never been denied. It cannot be denied because it is on the public record. They were raised again by Mrs Campbell via a parliamentary committee despite assurances she had apparently given to her former son-in-law that they would not be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a martyr.
—Order! The member for Mayo!
—So the Western Australian parliament had heard on at least three or four occasions from members of the Liberal Party and others about these matters.

PARA.TAB: Mrs Bishop interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not attacking anyone. I am stating the facts as they appear on the public record.

—Order! The Leader of the Opposition has in fact raised a very serious matter. The minister now has the opportunity, as she has been called on by members in this place, to explain herself. She is doing so. She will be heard, and she will be heard without interjection.

—The matter was raised in the Western Australian parliament via two or more separate means well before it ever became the subject of a petition. It subsequently became a matter for petition before the Western Australian parliament after that was judged to be the best way of doing it by the clerk—evidence that was accepted by everybody including the upper house committee which investigated whether that petition was in breach of privilege and found that the member who had presented it was not. That, briefly, is the background.

PARA.TAB: The day after the very sad death of Penny Easton, an attempt was made in the parliament by the opposition—an attempt that has been repeated here on many occasions—to link that petition and, indeed, to make a causal relationship between the death and the petition. We know that that matter has been raised in this House and outside it by some members here.

It was seized upon as an issue, not just recently in the last six months but by Premier Court, although at the time he was the Leader of the Opposition. When asked whether he was going to make it a political issue he said, `Oh, no, not me. I wouldn't do that,' and then proceeded to do so.

Just before the by-election in Fremantle, there was another attempt to raise the issue and, indeed, add to it. There was an elaborate conspiracy theory which resulted in the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, as he now is, having a press conference on the Friday before the election, I think it was—perhaps it was the Thursday—

TALK.START.PARA: —What a good memory you have.
—I have had cause to go back through these issues.
—Absolute disgrace!
—Order! The member for Mackellar might heed the warning.
—He was waving around a report which he alleged contained very serious evidence—

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the member for Mayo!

—of possible criminal behaviour involving a whole range of people such as the Public Service Commissioner, ministers, staffers, et cetera. They handed that over to the Director of Public Prosecutions. So that is the context in which we see this. This has been going on for a very long time. I might just add in parenthesis that that particular report became the subject of a freedom of information request by me—
—You really are appalling.
—I warn the member for Mackellar!

—because we were very suspicious that the report had been concocted by the same dirt team that was used to brief the royal commission staff. Indeed, that was shown and agreed to by the said minister in public.

PARA.TAB: He initially said that they were not involved and that it was only Public Service staff. He was forced to admit just a little while ago to Alan Carpenter on the 7.30 Report that it was a member of the Premier's political staff, Mr Elliott, and another member of his political staff, Mr Papafilis, who had been involved. Somehow the report had got on the private computer of one of those members. It was only at the death knock of the FOI request that they tabled the full report in parliament—complete with the smear and allegation against a large number of people, many of whom were unable to protect themselves.

Incidentally, an accusation was made against me, but they were quite happy to repeat what they were prepared to say publicly was not a desirable course of action and multiply it several hundredfold. The number of people named in that report was extraordinary, yet there was no comment on what the minister and the Court government clearly knew; that is, the DPP had cleared the whole matter. A day later, after pressure from us, they finally tabled the letter from the DPP. This was all a scandalous effort by the Liberal Party to make sure that my reputation was damaged, and this is part of the same exercise.

I have said all along that this was never a matter designed to get at the truth, something which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) claims to set great store by. It was always designed, firstly, to destroy me and, secondly, to attempt to drive a wedge between members of the Labor Party who of course after three years will have differing recollections about what occurs in cabinet meetings. I am sure that any member here who is at all honest about their own experiences in meetings will agree that, in the absence of very clear minuted outcomes—even then there can be disagreement—there is often disagreement about the whens, whats and wheres of them. If you look fairly at the evidence that was put before the commission—something the commissioner did not do—you would have to agree that there are a great many discrepancies in accounts, including amongst those who are said to all agree. But they do not. They do not agree about what was said, whether petitions were mentioned, when it was said—early or later—or how much detail was gone into. Those people who say that there was no such discussion are simply ignored.

It is also convenient for you to ignore that there is another body of evidence here. It is one of the reasons why you will clearly persist in this matter. You think there is mileage to be had certainly in destroying and attacking me and, by inference, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). But, most importantly, in the lead-up to an election, with the absence of policies on your side and with the absence of any framework in which the people of Australia might evaluate you as worthy of office, this is something.
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right are not helping.

—The findings of the royal commission, as I have already said in question time and publicly—I am happy to repeat this—should be ignored for a number of very important reasons. Firstly, as I say, it should be ignored because of its conception and its origin. It was conceived in malice and was established for the most improper of purposes. Its establishment is itself an abuse of executive power, which incidentally is something the commissioner did not find. Although it was entitled `the Royal Commission into the Use of Executive Power', one of the few findings at the opening was that there was no use, let alone abuse, of executive power. To act on its findings, as I have said, would be to condone that abuse of executive power, which was not examined or allowed to be questioned about in the royal commission.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the conduct of that commission was gravely flawed. I have already given some indication of that and I will outline that further. It lacked procedural fairness and the report itself was highly tendentious and virtually devoid of any rigorous analysis. For example, the evidence of the former Western Australian Attorney-General, which basically confirms mine, was dismissed as if he did not know what he was saying. He said very clearly that he does not recall at any cabinet meeting ever this matter being discussed. His evidence is dealt with in approximately half a paragraph. Similarly, other staff who disagreed with some of those members of my staff who said that there had been briefings either were dismissed as having motives or, in the case where they clearly no longer had motives, were simply ignored. The evidence of Ross Love floats off into the ether as if he had not spoken.

There was no analysis. There was no attempt to say this on the one hand and that on the other hand. There was no attempt to account for discrepancies, as my counsel did in their submission. There is basically a desire to believe that either you are telling the truth or you are lying. As you would know, in many of these examples, what you will have, as I said at the outset, are differing recollections. I have not sought to construe the motives of those people who disagree with me as unpleasant in any way. They need not be. I have said on many occasions that of course I am capable of making mistakes. Where it has been drawn to my attention that I have made mistakes, I have apologised to parliament and corrected records and, in many cases, I have done so in public. That is the second point I would make. The third is that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us some examples.
—I have just given you a couple.
—When?
—Order!

—To accept that the royal commission had in any way been a legitimate exercise would be simply to add weight to the argument that Marks himself advanced that the use of commissions generally was receding. If we as a community accept this as a legitimate exercise, we accept that commissions can be used for these purposes. When, for instance, Labor is returned to government in Victoria, they will be able to go back and investigate the sorts of contracts that have been entered into by Mr Kennett involving Mr Walker and others. Will it be legitimate for them to go back to all the cabinet ministers at the time in a matter which is frankly suspect and investigate?

PARA.TAB: One of my colleagues has just mentioned Wanneroo Inc. At the same time as Mr Court has been obsessed by the question of whether my account of various events was accurate, he has not been prepared to have an open inquiry into matters where there have already been two people gaoled for corruption. So we have enormous double standards operating. There is no royal commission into matters of frank corruption when it comes to Liberal Party involvement, but there is a royal commission into matters of disagreement about events in the Labor Party. By the way, you might note that the commissioner made no reference to what was said or not said in the parliament.

I want to set to rest a couple of myths while I have time to do so. The first myth is that royal commissions in some way have authority conferred upon them because they are royal commissions. That is not the case at all. They are a method of inquiry and judgment of them in the end will depend on how well and how properly they are conducted. I am sure members here will know that there are a great many inquiries and commissions whose findings have been thrown into the bottom drawer. I understand that was pretty much the treatment that Mr Fraser gave the meat substitution scandal inquiry when one of his ministers was named adversely. I do not think anything came of that, and they were more serious allegations. In that respect, this commission deserves the same fate.

Commissions are a tool of executive government and they can be misused. I draw attention to the fact that in this case it is very clear indeed that anything that involved the Premier or his staff was simply ruled out of order by the commissioner. There was no investigation, for instance, of a question that was put by my counsel about whether there had been a briefing of counsel staff, counsel assisting and others by the Premier's office, particularly his staff.

It was a very interesting little interchange. What happened was that, in the commission itself, this matter was about to be raised. Mr Court had been asked whether he wanted to continue giving evidence. He said, `Yes, I'm happy. I don't need a cup of tea; I don't need a break.' Then Mr Gyles started to ask him whether or not there had been any briefing by his political staff of the commission, whether they had given any information and who had talked to them, et cetera. Suddenly, Mr Court found it necessary to put up his hand like a school boy and ask to be allowed a break. When he comes back from the break, suddenly the whole matter is discharged and the commissioner refuses to deal with it.

That undermines the commission's independence right from the outset. The commissioner was not even prepared to have that question examined. Mr Court was asked in the parliament whether there had been any briefing by his team of people, like Elliott and so on, who had been putting this material together for three years. Don't worry about the Labor Party; this had been going on for three years, since we left government. The Premier was asked in the parliament whether any members of his staff held discussions with the commissioners, counsel assisting the commission or investigators associated with the commission on issues raised before the royal commission and, if so, when those discussions took place. This was the answer which the Premier provided to the parliament:

SPEECH.PARA: A number of officers from the Ministry—
these are the public servants—
of the Premier and Cabinet, including members of the Premier's staff—
he did not name them—

have had discussions with officers of the royal commission. Such discussions ranged from housekeeping matters relating to the administrative arrangements for the royal commission, through to interviews conducted by investigators, responding to requests for information and appearing before the commission under subpoena.
I draw attention to the last line:
Given the number of people involved and the frequency of contact with officers of the commission both by telephone and in person, it is not possible to identify all such discussions.

That is the way this whole thing has been set up. Today when he was asked the question in a doorstop, the Premier basically left his staff to say that these were administrative discussions. When asked to define what `administrative' was, suddenly they all flew away. From the outset, that is what this has been about. It is not an independent tribunal either in its terms of reference—it does not reach back to the Liberal Party—or in the matters that could be decided upon.

PARA.TAB: I point out too, in case members have not noticed, that this royal commission—this was the reason for our legal protest—was basically trying to deny the rights of a cabinet to integrity, to go back and dissolve that integrity. It was trying to deny the rights of parliament and in so doing was prepared to trample on a great many conventions.

I could go through the evidence in detail, but time does not allow me to do that. In so doing, I would give credence to what I think has been a most appalling exercise—lacking in procedural fairness, refusing to call witnesses that would have given weight to my point of view, having no argument or discussion about the findings, ignoring the evidence of those people whose evidence was close to the view that I had put—and in all of this, doing so at the bidding of the Court government for the most malicious of political purposes, supported by the Leader of the Opposition, who was not able to remember exactly the nature of the conversations he had had with Mr Court. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The House has just witnessed a very important speech by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and a sad and pathetic defence of her position. Not once did she mention in any way, shape or form her response to the evidence given by eight of her former ALP colleagues as part of this royal commission.

PARA.TAB: I think it is timely at this stage to remind the House what Royal Commissioner Marks found with regard to the minister, who has just run out of the House. He found firstly that Lawrence was briefed by Zoltan Kovacs and Ed Russell after they had been briefed by a member of the upper house, Halden, about Brian Mahon Easton's allegations and petition. He found also that Lawrence was briefed by Halden himself late in the week before the tabling of the petition.

The Marks royal commission found that the discussion alleged by Keith Wilson and Pam Beggs to have occurred on 2 November 1992 did in fact take place. The Marks royal commission also found that Lawrence raised the matter later that day with her cabinet office CEO, Marcelle Anderson. In other words, the Marks royal commission found the evidence stacked up—that the evidence from eight of her colleagues and from her staffers stacked up—that it was correct and that the minister lied.

Further, as we consider this very important censure motion I think it is time to reflect on the pattern of behaviour of the Minister for Human Services and Health. You do not have to go back so far. Try the interview between Paul Lyneham and Carmen Lawrence on the 7.30 Report on Thursday, 14 September, which the shadow minister for health correctly points out is one of the key turning points in this whole matter. I remind the House that the minister had been asked a week before whether she had been asked to resign and whether she had the support of her colleagues. Of course, it was only then, when Paul Lyneham asked her directly, that it emerged that she had to come clean:

SPEECH.PARA: So if I asked you, `Did Gary Gray suggest to you that you should stand aside from your portfolio until this matter is resolved?', you would say what?
Of course, she then had to give a correct answer—in that circumstance the complete denial of what she had said just a few days before. That is in the media. That is there for everyone to study.

PARA.TAB: What I think is of more relevance is what happened on another matter, the Notre Dame matter, which the minister has decided to bypass completely in these discussions and debates throughout 1995. This matter is one on which she was tested again. This time it was not a royal commission. This time it was a parliamentary committee of the Western Australian parliament. It was back in September 1992.

What did that committee find with regard to the statements, conduct and action of the then Premier in relation to Notre Dame? The parliamentary committee found that Carmen Lawrence, the then Premier, `lied and repeatedly misled the Western Australian parliament about the government's offer of a $30 million land package to Notre Dame and related financial guarantees given by the government to the university'. Remember: in 1989 Dr Lawrence was WA minister for education and subsequently was to become Premier. The Western Australian parliamentary committee found in respect of the Notre Dame matter that she had lied and misled the parliament. This conduct, sadly, fits a very grubby pattern of conduct.

If the minister had been a Mick Young, she would have stepped aside twice and be gone. If the minister had been a J.J Brown, she would have gone—complete resignation—and departed the government. If the minister had even been Ros Kelly, or half a Ros Kelly, with or without whiteboard, she would have departed this House and resigned her commission and the parliament. But of course she hangs on.

Why does she hang on? Because she knows no other. She knows no different pattern of conduct throughout all these years. And so it was back then with regard to the deliberations of the Western Australian parliamentary committee. It was an absolute finding and the absolute finding was that she had lied and she had misled the parliament. At the time there were editorials calling for her to step down and own up in very categorical terms.
If that is not enough, let us go to WA Inc., as it became known so famously, and some of the very crucial questions she was asked. I will give an extract:

SPEECH.PARA: Q:In July to November 1988 did you believe that the purpose and effect of the government involvement in PICL was fully and accurately explained to the public?
A:Cannot recall.
Q:Did you attend a Cabinet meeting in about July 1988 at which Mr Parker and another minister discussed Rothwell's current financial position?
A:No recollection.
Q:During 1988, SGIC and GESB each supported Rothwells to the extent of $50 million. Please state when you first became aware of such support being proposed or having occurred.
A:No direct knowledge.

The truth of the matter—simple facts—is that Lawrence voted with the government for the motion that the government support Rothwells with a $150 million guarantee. Lawrence voted for the motion put forward to support the government taking an equity investment in the Kwinana petrochemical project. She also voted against the motion to accept the McCusker report, in relation to which an amendment stipulated an urgent need at that time for an inquiry into WA Inc. She opposed opposition calls for a special investigation of Rothwells and she opposed motions for an independent commission of audit to examine government business dealings.

PARA.TAB: This is relevant to the Easton matter because the first time Richard Court, then member for Nedlands, raised the matters way back earlier on in the piece, around 16 July 1986, it had nothing to do with the Family Law Act. It had nothing to do with divorce proceedings. It related entirely to some borrowings, some activities related to WA Inc. Again this minister, when asked, and asked repeatedly, then and now—the famous defence she gave repeatedly in front of the royal commission on a number of occasions—said, `I have no recollection.'

Here at the dispatch box, the highest place to where she might answer in terms of the conduct of the Westminster system, in terms of the responsibility of a minister, she failed again today to provide those answers. She failed to even address the list which my colleagues the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) and others have put before the House during the proceedings yesterday and today.

I want to build on what the Leader of the Opposition said—not with regard to the Reverend Keith Wilson, whose very honest admissions brought about the creation of the royal commission—and refer to none other than her deputy leader for a period of time, the member for Kalgoorlie, the Labor minister and then Deputy Premier, Ian Taylor. Ian Taylor, I think, is a fairly decent sort of guy. Ian Taylor is one who has gone about his portfolio business and has had to weigh his conscience with regard to this matter.

Members might recall exactly what happened in relation to the sequence of events and the build-up to the appointment of the royal commission. Every time the Reverend Keith Wilson, Pam Beggs and others had something to say, Ian Taylor went bush. He got himself out of the media. He was torn by his conscience and by what he might respond to the media inquiries. He decided to take leave from the parliament for a period of time. He decided to step back because he had to weigh these matters very seriously. I suppose that was a fair response in the circumstances. He was deputy leader to the then Labor leader, Carmen Lawrence. He had to sit there and work through this matter to reach a conclusion as to what his correct response should be. I admire Ian Taylor in the context that he did weigh very carefully what his response should be. And it was the truth.

Subsequently, Ian Taylor went before that royal commission and, in spite of that great mateship we get preached about by the Labor Party time and time again, he said, `Forget the mateship. It is time the truth came out. This is exactly what happened.' He gave evidence which led to the conclusion that Carmen Lawrence had lied with regard to these matters, so found by the royal commission.

In other words, with no motivation whatsoever, when fronting the royal commission, after a careful period of deliberation, he decided to tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth. He decided to give the evidence in that context, in very clear-cut terms, and remind Carmen Lawrence and the commission of a number of meetings and briefings which took place at that time.

Do you condemn Ian Taylor? What motive do you ascribe to Ian Taylor? It is about time we heard the real views of the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) with regard to these eight who have given evidence. It is about time we heard whether he accepts that they acted in good faith. It may even help if the Deputy Prime Minister explains to the House what he thinks their motive might have been to give that evidence. Because they were not on our side, they were with a conscience and they were determined that the truth came out. Even if that was going to be acutely embarrassing to their former leader, they knew they had an obligation, on oath, to tell the truth.

In that context, I salute not only Ian Taylor but all the others who have given evidence, especially the Reverend Keith Wilson and Pam Beggs who, as the former Minister for Transport, was so outraged that she also categorically denied Carmen Lawrence's version of events with regard to the tabling of that infamous Easton petition.

So we had Keith Wilson. We had the former deputy leader, Ian Taylor. We had Pam Beggs. Then we had Graham Edwards, the former Minister for Sport and Recreation. We had the press secretary, of course, Zoltan Kovacs. We had the other press secretary, Bob Willoughby.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Joe Berinson?
—Berinson has a past. We remember him when he used to be here in politics at another level.
—You weren't here, sport.
—No, but I used to read Hansard at great length and I happened to be not far away, actually, in the state parliament—and Berinson's reputation preceded him.

PARA.TAB: We had the evidence from the other ministers as well—pretty categorical evidence. You have to put this back in context: these were longstanding, financial members of the Australian Labor Party, Western Australian branch. They had all gone through preselection processes. They had all put their hand up to serve with the Burke Labor government as ministers, with the Dowding Labor government and then with the Lawrence Labor government.

If these people had any temptation at all to go the other way, they might have been so tempted because their links were with the Labor Party first and foremost. It was an acid test that, when the crunch came, when the point of evidence came before the royal commission, that group of ministers, that group of key staffers, resolved in very categorical terms that Carmen Lawrence's evidence had to be turned over, that Carmen Lawrence's stated events, reported events, summation of events, as was the case with Notre Dame, as was the case with the Easton petition, was not correct and had been fabricated, that she lied and had a totally incorrect recollection of events.

In those circumstances the editorial of the Australian Financial Review is interesting. There they were months ago saying it was time for her to face up to her responsibilities and resign. But, very sadly, the pattern goes back even further to another quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Carmen has always hated to be proved wrong and she would go to great lengths to tell why she did it. In her eyes it wasn't actually wrong. She had a motive for doing it that way. She was a tricky little person to understand.
Those are sad words. That was an assessment given by a person of Carmen Lawrence's pattern of conduct. It was published and it is available.

PARA.TAB: That pattern has finally been exposed. We have said enough is enough. That pattern has gone on for far too long. Now that she has transferred from the state parliament, and from the standards that might apply at the state parliamentary level of one kind or another, to the federal parliament, we say that enough is enough, the game is up, it is time that she was held absolutely accountable for her conduct then over a range of matters. She no longer enjoys the right to hold the office of a federal minister of the Crown. It is for that reason that the House should support this censure motion against this minister who too often has told untruths, too often has lied, too often has fudged, too often has fabricated and has now been caught out comprehensively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, you cannot deal with this issue without going to the causes which set it up, the way in which the government devised it, the procedures which it undertook, the deeply unfair, deceitful way in which witnesses were organised before it and, at the end of the day, a set of judgments which at the beginning of the process, or at least midway through the process, the royal commissioner simply said he could not come to with any sense of certainty.

PARA.TAB: Royal commissions are very interesting bodies. They are assumed to have a saintly status, a judicial status. They have none of that, of course. They have a place in our society, but it is a place that has to be regarded with very great caution. I quote an eminent authority on this subject who said:

SPEECH.PARA: I find it remarkable that the public accept the conduct of Royal Commissions as a means of obtaining evidence, bearing in mind that our forebears revolted against the Star Chamber, which was a standing Royal Commission of its day. Press and politicians alike seem quite anxious to call for Royal Commissions into all manner of activities, not pausing to consider that the powers of a Royal Commissioner are easily abused. Indeed the public spectacle of witnesses squirming under questioning by the Commissioner or by his assisting counsel provides dramatic copy for the daily press, to the delectation of many of its readers.

That was Garfield Barwick's view of royal commissions. It is not necessarily the last view that needs to be put on royal commissions; nevertheless, it is one that needs to be taken some notice of. Because of that particular character of royal commissions, the motivation which underpins their establishment and the fairness with which they are conducted are absolutely critical issues in making judgments about their findings.

PARA.TAB: It has to be absolutely understood that people do not go before royal commissions with protection. They go before royal commissions in which hearsay evidence is admitted. They go before royal commissions that do not in fact operate on a proper adversarial basis with a capacity to answer charges that are broad. Charges are allowed to remain vague in the course of a royal commission's consideration. The materials that are handled by a royal commission are not necessarily ordered in some fashion that leads to a conclusion. They tend to be entirely anarchic and impressionistic. Those are the problems with royal commissions. So when you are going to assume some sort of sanctity in the findings of a particular royal commission they are not to be dismissed out of hand; nevertheless, they are to be viewed with caution.

As much as those findings are to be regarded, therefore, in those sorts of circumstances, so must the motivations that go to the underpinning of it; the selection of the people who appear before it and the order in which they appear. The processes by which people who appear before it are entitled to fairness in their treatment before that royal commission. The terms of reference of a royal commission, above all of course, are to be looked at as to whether or not they do permit a consideration of all the matters that may be relevant to the case, and at the end of the day the motivations of the government that established them.

That is not to say that all royal commissions ought to be regarded with calumny and all the rest of it. But when you have a royal commission with the basis of this royal commission you are absolutely entitled to ask questions about that. This royal commission emanated from a couple of years of hate work that proceeded on a broad front against Carmen Lawrence by the denizens of the Court government—one of the most deceitful governments that has ever been in existence in Western Australia that attempts to pass judgment on its opponents when it harbours within its ranks a promotion of an individual to a ministerial status who used inside information on the introduction, for example, of the workers compensation act to phone his legal practice prior to it becoming public to ensure a ludicrous situation emerged where, on the day the whole process of workers compensation changed, there were 14 applications for compensation arrangements, 12 from one legal firm—his!

`What do we do with this sort of individual?' Says Mr Court, `We stick him in the cabinet'. If you have a tricky little fellow like this around the place, why not let him rock on in the broader field?

Then of course we have the performance of Richard Court regarding his own peccadillos. Carmen Lawrence named the two members of the Liberal Party for their behaviour in the Wanneroo Inc. affair. This is a man we are supposed to regard as a person who takes royal commissions seriously, who views these things in a dispassionate and fair-minded way and who sets them up because he is seriously disturbed about public conduct and public morality.

What does the West Australian have to say about him when it comes to whether or not he is prepared to set up a royal commission into something that really matters, that shrieks out for a royal commission and for some attention from a person of some standing in the community? After examining the fact that they set up another inquiry, albeit with a good person to head it but without the powers that a royal commissioner has, the West Australian said this:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government—which had to be dragged by community opinion to the point of reopening the Kyle inquiry—must now be able to see that hearings repeatedly interrupted by suppression orders are totally unsatisfactory—
which is what of course is happening to this inquiry. The article continued:

The Government will be open to accusations of crass hypocrisy while it continues to smother the possibility of full public disclosure of the Wanneroo allegations—but strikes postures of pious self-righteousness over the Easton royal commission which ran its course in the full glare of publicity.

PARA.TAB: Mr Court is applying a double standard. He is clearly at odds with Mr Kyle—a respected and accomplished lawyer—over what the commission needs and how it should be run.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the man whose motives we are supposed to applaud for his establishment of this royal commission. This is a man, as I said, who elevates deceit into an art form. There is only one reason why Wanneroo Inc. is not subject to the sort of analysis before a royal commission as Dr Lawrence was: it is because it contains the most intimate involvement of the entire northern suburbs of the Liberal Party. The lot are caught up in the process, invariably, as their chief fund-raiser goes to gaol.

PARA.TAB: Of course, he knows full well that if all this comes out into the glare of publicity there will be a party of MPs, ministers and all passing before the royal commission to have themselves judged. The difference in his situation, of course, is that he does not actually have an upper house majority against him forcing him to go through the process of some form of honourable inquiry into those matters.

This is the same office that when they decided to do this piece of log rolling did two things. Firstly, they put in place a very restrictive term of reference. Is it Mr Keating who says that it is a very restrictive term of reference? Is it me who says it is a very restrictive term of reference? Is it Dr Lawrence who says it is a very restrictive term of reference? Is it even the West Australian which says it is a very restrictive term of reference? No, it is Commissioner Marks who says it is a very restrictive term of reference. It is a man who finds very conclusive opinions on very unbalanced evidence and comes to the conclusion, midway through the inquiry, firstly, that his terms of reference are inadequate to the investigation and, secondly, that any finding he makes will invariably be interpreted by the public as politically tainted. We have been invited to address Commissioner Marks's opinions. We will. We accept his view. Any finding he arrives at is likely to be politically tainted, and we so judge it.

So far as we are concerned, Commissioner Marks's views and findings, because of the way in which the commission was established, because of the way in which his staff were briefed, because of the way in which he called witnesses, because of his inadequacies in dealing with the fact that he needed more open terms of reference to deal with the people who first raised the Easton matter in parliament—the Family Court matters were first raised in parliament by Richard Court and the Liberals—because none of that could be capable of being examined in this context, are automatically flawed.

This piece of persecution of Dr Lawrence by Richard Court is not a stand-alone item. We have had another one from the Western Australian government. It had always been frightened that it had only the one punch going, but the one punch might not hang in there, so let us get a second one going. It had running in its office—not through the police—an inquiry into the possibility that Carmen Lawrence's administration of the Aboriginal affairs portfolio might have been deficient in the area of an Aboriginal education project that went ahead.

Just by accident, this inquiry actually turned up on the computer of somebody else. In most places where government documents go missing and turn up in a way that lends itself to a bit of gathering of evidence, a police inquiry follows—a police inquiry into the perpetrators, the perpetrators being, at least as far as we know, members of Mr Court's staff but possibly higher than that. We know that there was a police investigation proceeding, but had this matter been ordered and requested by the Western Australian government to look into? Oh, heck no! Why, that would be public accountability. That would be retaining a responsible relationship with the electorate. These would be the sorts of things that an honourable, decent government would do. Perish the thought that we would!Perish the thought that we, who drag in for a couple of days before a royal commission begins with our political offices—not dealing with administrative matters—would sit them down and make sure that they have absolutely in their minds the outcome that we wish to see from this royal commission. No, no! That would be behaviour inconsistent with people who behave like that. So naturally enough we do not do it.

But we are a bit embarrassed by it—we are capable of embarrassment. So what do we do? We suddenly send all of it off to the DPP's office. We just sneak it out to the gallery and say, `You know, we have an inquiry that we have sent to the DPP's office.' `Oh,' says this opposition in Western Australia, `could we perhaps have the DPP's opinion?' `Oh, heck! What a mistake. We made a bit of a blue here. The DPP did say something about him perhaps not having a look at it, but we cannot give you that information.'

Extracted like teeth from a hen, finally the fact comes out that the DPP's office said that this is a joke, that this is just your little smearing effort, your little slander effort. It would have been nice if he had also said that it was of a piece with your royal commission. Of course, he did not say that; he is a proper man. He just stuck with what was before him. He said, `You can forget that for starters.'

So what we have here is a set of processes put in place for entirely political reasons and then a set of conclusions. They are not a balanced set of conclusions—which is what I think you would be entitled to have on the basis of evidence before you—but an absolute rot-ridden set of judgments. Having cast out on the terms of reference and having cast out on the political processes associated with it, Commissioner Marks then felt it incumbent upon himself to come to some very firm conclusions.

What was his conclusion? It is interesting that you keep citing the cabinet ministers. Not one cabinet minister went into that place and said that a petition had been presented to them. Not one cabinet minister went into that place and said that there was discussion of the matters that were the subject of the petition—not one of them. They did argue and were at variance with the memories of Dr Lawrence. The issues of the Easton petition were blasted about the parliament and the press and to everybody else who felt like taking an interest in it for the previous four years. They alleged that those issues were raised there. But a petition? No. None of them came to the conclusion that a petition had been discussed in the cabinet proceedings, spilled out by Commissioner Marks against all precedent in terms of cabinet inquiries—not one. The judgment was made on the petition.

The only person whose evidence was ignored was the bloke who wrote the petition. The only bloke whose evidence was ignored was the bloke who advised that they should do it. The only bloke whose evidence was ignored was the bloke who the day before it was produced for the first time placed it into the hands of a member of parliament, Mr Halden. That is entirely consistent with the argument that Dr Lawrence has put forward, that she could not have received it before that date. Then a judgment was made by a man obviously ignorant of parliamentary procedure that somehow there was a choice for Dr Lawrence as to whether or not it ought to be presented.

I am afraid that the judgment was too severe on the evidence presented. The judgment was erroneous on the question of the circumstances surrounding the tabling of the petition. The underpinnings of this royal commission were an absolute disgrace—an absolute disgrace from a disgraceful government. Because it was a disgraceful government putting up a disgraceful set of propositions, you got a disgraceful outcome. It ought not to take the time of this parliament for one second more. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Howard's) be agreed to.
