DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (1995-96 BUDGET MEASURES) BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer for Superannuation)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I intend to sum up in a few minutes. I thank the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) for his contribution to the debate. I have noticed that, every time he speaks in this House on veterans' issues, he is very sincere in what he says—he is a veteran himself—and I have said that on a number of occasions.

PARA.TAB: However, he continually does say that, over the years, there has been a diminution of veterans' entitlements. I just simply want to put on the record that that is not the case. It may be the way he looks at it. But, in recent years alone, there has been enormous improvements in the lot of our veterans, perhaps not in so far as making big increases in pension payments but certainly in terms of aged care services, extension of benefits and such initiatives as veterans' health week and allowing them to see osteopaths and chiropractors—there are just too many improvements to mention. I want to reject out of hand what the honourable member for McPherson continually says in this place; namely, that there has been a diminution. In fact, it has been the other way around.

I also noted with interest the comments by the member on the subject of domiciliary nursing care in New South Wales. I know that just about all members of this House and also of the New South Wales state house have been written to by the Domiciliary Nurses Association. Naturally, they are very concerned. Up until now, some 93 per cent of all domiciliary nursing in New South Wales has been carried out by the private sector, whereas in places like Western Australia it has all been done by the public sector. The public sector is just as good—and, I understand, in some cases better—than the private sector in delivering these services.

As the member for McPherson said, I did follow up the concerns expressed in this place recently and have been able to give him my assurances that veterans and war widows will continue to receive domiciliary nursing care which meets their clinical needs. The member asked how many showers per week a veteran receiving community nursing would get. I think he was implying that they will not be getting as many and therefore will not be receiving the same care as when they were nursed by private nursing services.

I have looked into this matter for him and I can assure him unequivocally that a veteran who is being nursed by community nurses and who requires assistance with showering will be showered as often as is necessary. This can be every day but I understand that, on average, it is around three times per week. I would also like to assure the member for McPherson that, if after assessment by the local community health centre a veteran or war widow is assessed as not clinically needing a registered nurse to provide services such as showering, a follow-up assessment is made to ensure that home care is provided as required, which can include assistance with showering.

In summary, I would just like to confirm that there really is no need for the honourable member to be concerned on this matter. I receive very few complaints, if any, with respect to community nursing around Australia. I have no reason to doubt that that will be the case, as new veterans come on line and receive care from community nurses in New South Wales. It is my responsibility as the minister for the government in this area to ensure that I get the best value per dollar in the area of veterans' services in so far as it relates to domiciliary nursing and I will continue to do that.

I must say, and I have said it before, that when decisions are made by government in relation to domiciliary nursing of veterans and war widows in New South Wales, those decisions will be based purely on what is the best possible treatment that can be given to the veterans and not on what is the best possible way of looking after commercial domiciliary nursing companies. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Administrator recommending appropriation announced.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Sciacca) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995Cognate bill:EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 24 August.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, which is now before the House, contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Most of the amendments have already been introduced as customs tariff proposals in this House. I will briefly outline the changes of substance.

PARA.TAB: Schedule 1 is operative from 17 March 1995 and contains an amendment to item 31 in part II of schedule 4 of the principal act. The concessional item allows the duty free importation of aircraft parts, materials and test equipment for use in the manufacture, repair or maintenance of aircraft with the exception of goods used for the servicing of aircraft. Following the government's acceptance in 1991 of recommendations contained in Industry Commission report No. 9 on the commercial tariff concession and by-law systems, the terms of item 31 in schedule 4 were revised. By a broad application of the current conditions, it has been possible to import, duty free, most goods used in aircraft.

The government has now decided to restrict the coverage of this item by excluding textiles and goods made of textiles for use on aircraft. This initiative will remove the competitive advantage previously accorded imported goods over locally sourced goods by the use of item 31. It will also encourage the use of Australian raw textile materials.

Schedule 2 of the bill is operative from 1 April 1995. Customs tariff rates of duty have been subjected to a phasing regime since July 1988. Blood packs and blood pack systems used for collecting, processing, storing and administering blood and blood components have traditionally been classified by the Australian Customs Service as infusion and transfusion sets for blood and other fluids. They were subject to 10 per cent duty prior to 1 July 1995, phasing to five per cent in 1996.

This classification was successfully challenged in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal with the result that the AAT set aside the customs classification, considering the goods to be properly classified to a duty free item. The immediate removal of the 10 per cent assistance would have had a detrimental effect on local industry and is not consistent with the intent of the government's tariff phase down program. This government is aware of the consequences to industry of sudden and large reductions in the level of protection. This amendment reinstates the intended level of assistance for the subject goods by specifically designating blood packs and blood pack systems used for collecting, processing, storing and administering blood and blood components in the tariff classification that Customs originally considered appropriate.

Schedule 3, which is operative from 10 May 1995, implements the 1995-1996 federal budget announcement of an increase of 10 per cent in the customs rate of duty for manufactured tobacco and tobacco products. The previously legislated increase of five per cent for these goods planned for August 1995 will now not proceed.

Schedule 4 is operative from 1 July 1995 and contains a number of amendments. The first inserts an additional note in chapter 27 to define `fuel oil'. In recent years, oil refineries have been producing fuel oils of lower density which are capable of being used in diesel engines. The effect of this note will be to exclude light fuel oils from the new definition of fuel oil, and in future those light fuel oils will attract the diesel fuel rate of duty.

Secondly, the rates of customs duty on aviation gasoline are increased by 0.883 cents per litre on aviation kerosene and by 1.847 cents per litre on aviation gasoline. These increases were announced by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in the 1995-1996 federal budget. The additional revenue will provide funding for aviation safety regulation and be part of the industry's contribution to the recovery of airway services costs attributable to aviation gasoline powered aircraft.

Another change inserts in chapter 73 an additional note to confirm the tariff classification of razor wire. The new additional note implements a decision of the World Customs Organisation that this wire be classified in tariff heading 7313. Other changes are of an administrative nature and have no duty implications. Summaries of the amendments contained in this bill have been prepared and are being circulated for the information of honourable members.
I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921—the Tariff Act—to incorporate into the Tariff Act excise tariff proposals Nos. 1, 2 and 3 of 1995 which were tabled in the Parliament earlier in the year. In addition, this bill proposes to implement changes in the excise treatment of condensate and topped crude petroleum oil—topped crude.
The principal changes contained in the bill relate to:
(i)the exclusion of the rate of excise duty applicable to beer produced from `micro-breweries' and `U-brews' from indexation from 1 April 1994;
(ii)the increase in excise duty on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products by 10 per cent from 10 May 1995;
(iii)the amendment of the physical characteristics of fuel oil from 1 July 1995, to effectively remove `light' fuel oil from the concessional rate of excise applying to fuel oil;
(iv)an increase in the excise duty on aviation gasoline—avgas—and aviation kerosene—avtur—from 1 July 1995;

(v)the exemption of condensate from the application of the Tariff Act where it is separately produced, or separately marketed, from stabilised crude petroleum oil—stabilised oil—from 11 October 1995; and
(vi)the removal of the transport fuel substitution potential for topped crude from 11 October 1995.

TAB.EMPHASIS: Exclusion of the rate of excise duty applicable to beer produced from micro-breweries and U-brews from indexation

PARA.TAB: Under section 6A of the Tariff Act rates of excise duty set out in the schedule to the Tariff Act may be subject to indexation in accordance with the consumer price index on 1 February and 1 August of any year. Presently, specified rates of excise duty are not subject to indexation.

On 1 April 1994, beer produced from micro-breweries and U-brews was made excisable under the Tariff Act. Under the present provisions of section 6A the rate of excise duty that applies to such beer is subject to indexation. However, this amounts to a double indexation of this rate of duty as this rate is directly linked to the rate of excise on commercially produced beer.

Clause 3 and schedule 1 of the bill propose to amend section 6A of the Tariff Act to ensure that the rate of excise duty on beer produced from micro-breweries and U-brews is not subject to indexation. This amendment is also proposed to take effect from 1 April 1994. This amendment was proposed in excise tariff proposal No. 1 of 1995 which was tabled in the House of Representatives on 8 February 1995 and took effect on and from 1 April 1994.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (II)Increase in excise duty on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products by 10 percent.

PARA.TAB: On budget night, the Treasurer announced a 10 percent increase in the rate of excise duty payable on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products with effect from 10 May 1995. While raising additional revenue, this measure also supports government health policy that is aimed at discouraging smoking. As a consequence of this 10 per cent increase, it is also proposed to remove manufactured tobacco and tobacco products from the 5 per cent discretionary increase in excise duty which was due to take effect on 1 August 1995. Clause 4 and schedule 2 of the bill propose to amend the tariff act to implement these changes.This amendment was proposed in excise tariff proposal No. 2 of 1995 which was tabled in the House of Representatives on 9 May 1995 and took effect on and from 10 May 1995.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (III) Amendment of the physical characteristics of fuel oil from 1 July 1995, to effectively remove light fuel oil from the concessional rate of excise applying to fuel oil

PARA.TAB: On budget night, the Treasurer also announced measures that were intended to close the revenue loophole allowing light fuel oil to be used as a substitute for diesel, especially in the transport area. Light fuel oil is excisable at the concessional rate of duty applying to fuel oil and diesel is excisable at a considerably higher rate of duty. It is proposed to amend the physical characteristics of fuel oil, as set out in subsection 3(4) of the Tariff Act, in order to exclude light fuel oil with effect from 1 July 1995.

The effect of this proposed amendment is that light fuel oil will no longer comply with the physical characteristics of fuel oil. As a result, light fuel oil will become excisable at the higher rate of duty applying the diesel fuel, thus removing the commercial incentive to continue to use light fuel oil as a transport fuel substitute for diesel. Clause 5 and item 1 of schedule 3 propose to amend the Tariff Act to implement this amendment. This amendment was proposed in excise tariff proposal No. 3 of 1995 which was tabled in the House of Representatives on 29 June 1995 and took effect on and from 1 July 1995.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (IV)Increase in the excise duty on aviation gasoline—avgas—and aviation kerosene—avtur.

PARA.TAB: Clause 5 and items 2 and 3 of schedule 3 propose increases in the rates of excise duty payable on avgas and avtur with effect from 1 July 1995. It is proposed to increase the rate of excise duty on avgas by 1.847 cents per litre. Of this increase, 0.883 cents will contribute to funding air safety regulation, undertaken by the new Civil Aviation Safety Authority, that benefits the travelling public and, in part, aviation industry participants. The remaining increase of 0.964 cents per litre on avgas will recover part of the airways costs that are attributable to avgas powered aircraft.

It is also proposed to increase the excise duty on avtur by 0.883 cents per litre. As with avgas, this increase will contribute to funding air safety regulation that benefits the travelling public and, in part, aviation industry participants. These increases were announced in the 1995-96 budget and form part of the government's continuing cost recovery strategy with respect to air safety regulation and the provision of airways services.
These amendments were also proposed in excise tariff proposal No. 3 of 1995 which was tabled in the House of Representatives on 29 June 1995 and took effect on and from 1 July 1995.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (V)Exemption of condensate from the application of the tariff act where it is separately produced, or separately marketed, from stabilised crude petroleum oil—stabilised oil.

PARA.TAB: This bill also proposes to remove an unintended consequence of the Tariff Act with respect to condensate that is separately produced from stabilised oil. With the first crude oil development soon to commence production from the North West Shelf project area—which is now the only offshore area subject to the excise regime—small quantities of stabilised oil will be mixed with the condensate stream. It is not technically possible to remove all the stabilised oil from the natural gas/condensate stream.

Under subsection 5B(3) of the Tariff Act, where this mixture of condensate and stabilised oil is entered for home consumption, all the condensate will be deemed to be stabilised oil and excisable at the rate of excise under sub-item 17A. This is clearly not the intention of the policy first introduced in 1977 which was designed to encourage condensate production by giving condensate concessional excise treatment.

It is, therefore, proposed to create an exception to the operation of subsection 5B(3) in respect of condensate that is separately produced from stabilised oil. As a corollary to this, it is also proposed to make condensate that is separately produced, or separately marketed, from stabilised oil excise exempt. However, condensate that is for use as a fuel will continue to be excisable under other provisions of the Tariff Act as will condensate that is produced with, and entered as a mixture with, stabilised oil. These amendments are contained in clause 6 and items 1, 2 and 4 of schedule 4 to the bill and are to take effect from 11 October 1995.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (VI)Removal of the transport fuel substitution potential for topped crude

PARA.TAB: This bill proposes to increase the rate of excise duty payable on certain topped crude from its present concessional rate to the rate applying to diesel with effect from 11 October 1995. Presently, topped crude is excisable at the same concessional rate as fuel oil. Topped crude will continue to be excise free where it is for use as refinery feedstock. Topped crude which has the same characteristics as fuel oil as defined under subsection 3(4) of the Tariff Act will also continue to be excisable at the concessional rate applying to fuel oil.

This amendment is intended to remove a potential diesel fuel substitution problem with topped crude that exists due to the excise rate differentials between topped crude and diesel. This substitution problem is similar to the light fuel oil substitution, which has also been addressed by this bill, as it is possible for some topped crudes to be used as transport fuel substitutes for diesel fuel. Therefore, by increasing the excise duty payable on topped crude not having the characteristics of fuel oil to the same rate as diesel fuel, the commercial incentive to use topped crude as a substitute for diesel, particularly in the transport area, is removed.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is contained in clause 6 and item 3 of schedule 4 to the bill.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Financial Impact Statement

SPEECH.PARA: (I) Exclusion of the rate of excise duty applicable to beer produced from micro-breweries and U-brews from indexation.
This amendment has no financial impact.
(II) Increase in excise duty on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products.
The increase by 10 per cent in the rate of excise duty on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products will result in an increase in revenue of $70 million in 1995-96 and $66 million in 1996-97.
(III) Amendment of the physical characteristics of fuel oil to effectively exclude light fuel oil.
The amendment to the Tariff Act in respect of the physical characteristics of fuel oil will result in an increase in revenue of $100 million in 1995-96 and $100 million in 1996-97.
(IV) Increases in the excise duty on avgas and avtur.

The increase of 1.847c per litre in the excise duty on avgas is balanced by an equivalent increase in the moneys appropriated to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and Airservices Australia. The financial impact is neutral.
The increase of 0.883c per litre in the excise duty on avtur is balanced by an equivalent increase in the moneys appropriated to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. The financial impact is neutral.
(V) Amendments to the excise treatment of condensate.
The amendments proposed to the excise treatment of condensate have no financial impact.
(VI)Removal of the transport fuel substitution potential for topped crude.

The amendment to eliminate the potential diesel fuel substitution problem with topped crude oil closes down a potential revenue drain of the same magnitude as the $100 million per annum light fuel oil revenue impact in paragraph (III) above. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tariff bills before the House have several components and I will take them in some orderly fashion. Commencing with schedule 1 of the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill under consideration, this will amend the Customs Tariff Act 1987 to ensure that textiles and goods made of textiles will be excluded from receiving the concession available to aircraft parts and related materials. Seat fabric used in aircraft is now considered a generic item and not of a specialised nature for use in aviation and henceforth will be subject to duty. The opposition supports this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Schedule 2 of the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill applies to blood packs and blood pack systems. These items were previously classified by the Australian Customs Service so they were subject to duty of 10 per cent, but a decision by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has reclassified the items with the effect of removing the tariff assistance. This amendment restores the rate of duty to its previous level so as to avoid the problems of a sudden loss of tariff protection for this industry. The opposition supports this amendment.

Schedule 3 of the bill gives effect to the government's budget decision to increase the excise and customs duty on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products by 10 per cent. This is generally consistent with the coalition's policy to discourage smoking and is supported by the coalition parties.

Turning to schedule 4, the first measure increases the excise on light fuel oil and forms part of the 1995 budget. Prior to 1 July 1995, the excise payable on all fuel oils was 6.7c per litre and the diesel excise was 32.5c per litre. This difference in excise of some 26c per litre encouraged some users of diesel fuel to switch to light fuel oils to avoid the higher excise. Given sufficient time, there was the possibility of a large number of diesel users changing to light fuel oil at a potential cost to government revenue of some $140 million for the 1995-96 financial year.

However, the excise on light fuel oil was increased to the same level as diesel fuel on 1 July 1995 following the tabling of excise and customs tariff proposals on 29 June this year in the parliament. At the same time, eligibility for the diesel fuel rebate scheme was extended to consumers of light fuel oil. In fact, I suspect that few of those subjected to the increase in excise on light fuel oil would be able to then claim the diesel fuel rebate, as they would generally have switched from diesel to light fuel oil because they were ineligible for the diesel rebate in the first place. It is worth noting that on 1 August 1995 automatic indexation of petroleum excises further increased the excise on diesel and light fuel oil to 33.5c per litre.

Government amendments to the original bill also increase the excise on topped crude oils used other than as refinery feedstock from 6.9c per litre to the same excise level as diesel and light fuel oil of 33.5c per litre. These topped crudes have been used as substitutes for diesel and fuel oil, raising the possibility of consumers avoiding excise by switching from diesel or light fuel oil to topped crudes. Again the government identifies a potential financial saving of up to $140 million per year based on the potential for large-scale switching from diesel and light fuel oil to topped crude oil to avoid excise.

However, this estimate is based on the simplistic assumption that all users of diesel and light fuel oil could switch to the use of topped crude oil. That is a very shaky assumption to make but, in any event, the financial cost to government revenue would have proved substantial. In consequence, the National and Liberal parties are not prepared to have excise revenue eroded by this loophole, particularly given the difficult state of the Commonwealth's budgetary position at this stage, with its much vaunted budget surplus disappearing a few months after its proclamation, and therefore we will not oppose the increase of excise on light fuel oil and topped crude oils.

Before moving on, I would like to seek an assurance from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay), who is at the table, that where there are unintended consequences of this increase in excise on topped crude oil, the government will act to remove these consequences. It is my understanding that at least one case has been drawn to the attention of the government, and I would be happy to provide further details if required. I give an assurance to the House that I will be pursuing the matter that has been brought to my attention with the government at a later date depending on the outcome of discussions the particular company has with the Customs Service.

Also covered in schedule 4 are increases in aviation fuel duties. As of 1 July this year, the duty on aviation gasoline, or avgas, was increased by 1.847c per litre and the duty on aviation turbine fuel, or avtur, increased by 0.883c per litre. These duties and excises were further increased by three per cent on 1 August as a result of the automatic CPI indexation of petroleum product excises. Currently the duty on avgas is 19.65c per litre with a component paid to Airservices Australia for air traffic services of 17.2c per litre. The remaining component of 2.45c per litre is paid to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority to fund air safety regulation. The increase in the airways services component of the avgas duty follows a recommendation earlier this year by the then Civil Aviation Authority for a 3.4c per litre increase, which was rejected by the industry and the government.

I now indicate that the proposal to increase the airways services component of the avgas duty by 0.964c per litre, raising $1.1 million per year in revenue, will be opposed by the coalition parties in the Senate. It is inequitable to use fuel duties to recover the cost of providing airways services to general aviation. Specifically, many general aviation operators and private pilots only use the system rarely but still have to pay thousands of dollars a year in duty. This is particularly true for agricultural operators, who may never use these services at all, but pay a staggering $7,800 per year on average for the privilege.

Schedule 4 also contains an amendment to clarify the customs tariff classification of various types of wire. As Australia is a signatory to the harmonised system, a recent ruling by the World Customs Organisation on these types of wire is binding and is being implemented through this amendment. Also dealt with in schedule 4 are routine amendments to clarify the tariff classification of parts of tractors for dumpers of Canadian origin, and blood packs and blood pack systems.

The final schedule, No. 5, in the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill removes an error in cross-referencing between the Customs Act 1901 and the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Naturally, the opposition supports this amendment. The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 makes corresponding amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 for the measures I have already discussed concerning tobacco, fuel oil, topped crude oil, avgas and avtur.

However, a further item excludes from indexation the excise duty on beer produced from home brewing kits. When beer produced from these kits was made excisable from 1 April 1994, it was not intended that the rate of duty be subject to indexation. This amendment removes this anomaly and appropriately is retrospective to 1 April 1994. It is good news for home brewers; and we support the amendment. A further routine amendment will exempt condensate from the application of the Tariff Act where it is separately produced, or separately marketed from stabilised crude petroleum oil. This routine measure has the support of the petroleum industry and the opposition.

In summary, when the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill reaches the Senate, the coalition will seek to amend the bill to formally remove the increase in the airways services component, 0.964c per litre, of the avgas duty. Additionally, I seek assurances from the parliamentary secretary that any unintended consequences of increasing the excise on topped crude oil will be considered favourably.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tariff legislation before us today has two purposes. The first concerns the amendment to the Excise Tariff Act, which proposes to exclude the diesel substitute, light fuel oil. This means that light fuel oil will become excisable at the same rate as diesel fuel. The second issue which I wish to address is the increase in aviation fuel duties that took effect on 1 July this year, and the impact this will have on our rural sector.

PARA.TAB: I will deal with the increase in aviation fuel duties first. There are two aircraft fuels, as the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) pointed out, to be targeted by this proposed increase—aviation gasoline, known as avgas, and aviation turbine fuel. For the benefit of the House and those who are unfamiliar with the terms, let me say that avgas is used in piston engine propeller aircraft and turbine fuel is used in jet aircraft and turbine engine propeller aircraft.

On 1 July this year, the government increased the duty on avgas by 1.847c per litre and increased the duty on aviation turbine fuel by 0.883c per litre. It is the increase in avgas prices that the coalition takes most exception to. This is because a large percentage of this increase in avgas duties will be paid for by aircraft operators who will not enjoy the benefits of it. This makes the increase grossly unfair and highly inequitable. It will hit small aircraft operators in our rural and remote communities with yet another series of costs.

As so often occurs to people in the bush, they will not enjoy the full benefits of the money they pay. As of August this year, over 19.5c from every litre of avgas goes on excise duties. Of this amount, approximately 2.5c or 13 per cent goes to help fund air safety regulation, while 17c or 87 per cent goes to Air Services Australia to pay for air traffic services used by avgas powered and other aircraft.

The increase which came into effect on 1 July this year was 1.847c per litre. This is broken up into two categories. The 0.883c per litre will contribute to the safety regulations component. The second component is the 0.964c per litre which will go to airways services. The coalition does not oppose the increase in the safety regulation component. It is the opinion of the coalition that the safety of Australian airline services needs to be improved and the increase in excise duty will contribute to this end.

It is the increase in the second component of the excise duty—that which goes to airways services—that I and the federal opposition most strongly object to. The major reason we do so is that it is fundamentally inequitable. An excise duty on fuel is being used to provide airways services for general aviation use, regardless of how often an aircraft operator uses the airways services. This is unfair because of the fact that only on rare occasions do many of the general aviation operators—particularly those in rural Australia—use the airways services, but they still have to pay thousands of dollars every year in excise duty for a service they never use.

For example, agricultural operators are now paying the equivalent of $7,800 per plane per year for services they do not use. Farmers who use planes for farming and agricultural related purposes, but who would hardly ever use airways services, are having to pay the same amount as city operators who fly the exact same aircraft but who use airways services all the time. Is it any wonder that the people of rural and regional Australia have given up on this government?

TALK.START.PARA: —And they have given up on the people of rural Australia.
—They have never understood the problems of rural Australia, let alone tried to assist the people of rural Australia.
—You boys just have a chat over there; don't worry about us.

—No, our constituents don't bother with you either. It is not only the people on the farms out there in rural Australia, but also the people in small business in rural Australia who are tired of this government's biased approach to the people who choose to make their life, bring up their families, and run their businesses out there in rural Australia. Making the situation worse, this increase in excise duty comes at a time when rural Australia is just starting to emerge from the worst drought in living memory. Many farmers have not had a decent income in five years.

PARA.TAB: I hope that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay) will at least try to understand that many of these communities that are so dependent on the agricultural sector are feeling the effects of the lack of income and the impact of the drought on our country towns and provincial cities. I imagine that even towns like the one that the parliamentary secretary makes his home in—Townsville—would be feeling the effect of the prolonged drought in Queensland.

As a result of this prolonged drought, farm debt has escalated. In 1983, when the federal Labor Party took control of government, rural debt was $7 billion. Today it is $17 billion and growing daily. Average farm debt is in excess of $145,000. Our rural producers are desperate to get a decent income again. Many of them will not survive the effects of debt and drought. This increase in excise duty is going to impact on our rural communities, on the small business sector, on our provincial cities and on the nation as a whole.

Lately we have heard the Treasurer (Mr Willis) blaming the poor current account results on the drought. Because the current account deficit is not coming down as rapidly as the government would like, the government is blaming the drought. That is clear evidence that the drought is an issue not only for regional and rural Australia but nationally. It is affecting our national economy. Yet this increase in excise duty is going to add to the cost of production and make it harder for farmers to earn a level of income which would ease their financial situation.

Private aeroplanes are an increasingly important tool in production in the farming sector. They are being used widely for fertilising, mustering and water management. They are an important method of controlling and spotting bushfires. They are also an effective way of controlling pests such as locusts and mice. Only recently, planes in my electorate that would never use these airways services were baiting a mice plague that was devastating the limited crops being grown in that area. These planes are not used for pleasure or carrying passengers; they are used for carrying herbicides, pesticides and, in this case, baits to combat the mice plague. Yet these aeroplanes have to pay this increase in fuel tax even though they will not use the airways services.
Who will this tax hurt? It will hurt the consumer because the cost will be passed on to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not right.
—He says it's not right. Why isn't it right?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland!

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite clearly, they do not understand that this is not right. No wonder we have an economy in the state that it is in at the moment. No wonder the budget surplus they were predicting only five months ago has already evaporated. They do not understand the fundamental point that these costs will be borne by the productive sector. When you increase tax—in this case, it is an aviation excise—it will be paid by someone. That interjection really amazes me. It is an amazing interjection.
—What interjection?
—That they don't have to pay. That was the import of what he said. That is what he meant.
—Order! I have already asked the member for Gippsland to restrain himself. There is no need for a conversation across the chamber. The member for Maranoa has the call.

—Quite clearly, time after time the Labor Party have proved themselves to be incompetent in managing the country's economic affairs. Time and again, we hear the government bringing in deficit budgets and then trying to balance them by selling off the silver, or the publicly owned assets. But they are not reducing the debt on those assets when they sell them. They are using those funds to pay the bills. But what are they doing now? They want to hit the productive sector that will drag this economy out of the depths of debt that it is in. This government keeps lumping these taxes on the productive sector.

PARA.TAB: I want to touch on light fuel oil, as the member for Gippsland did, because it is an important point. After 1 July this year, the excise rate on light fuel oil was increased to 32.5c a litre in order to bring it up to the same rate as diesel fuel. This was done because some business sectors use light fuel oil as a substitute for diesel fuel in order to get around the excise cost on diesel. This increase will have a serious impact on two industry sectors in particular: one is the marine tourism operator and the other is the rail freight sector.

The increase in excise will have an impact on the marine tourism industry by making tourist services more expensive and reducing their capacity to be competitive. The reason the marine tourist operators first moved to light fuel oil was that they were excluded from the diesel fuel rebate scheme. This exclusion in itself is difficult to justify because tourism is a viable and expanding international industry in this country.

In the absence of the admission to the rebate scheme, the use of light fuel oils allowed them to compete in the expanding world of international tourism. The increase in excise charges will remove that capacity to be competitive. It is only going to add another cost to tourism operators. At the end of the day, they will have to put up their charges. Who will pay? The consumer will have to pay. They will say that it is getting too expensive to see our Great Barrier Reef in North Queensland. People who come to Australia will tell their friends that things are more expensive if you go to Australia than if you go to another country. That is the bottom line with this. This is just another way of hitting a growing and valuable industry in this country which is contributing to the nation's wealth.

I want to touch on rail services, because rail is an important component of our transport industries in this country. Rail freight costs are bound to increase as a direct result of the increase in the cost of fuel. This tax increase will fall almost entirely on the rural export industries, further reducing their productive capacity and competitiveness. Once again, we see the effects of a high taxing government on the productive sector of this country.

Rail freight in this country has been a very important element in ensuring that large volumes of produce can be moved safely and quickly over long distances at competitive rates. The increase in the excise will impact on the cost of freight in this country. It will be just another tax on the productive sector. It is another tax grab from Canberra.

Another element I would like to touch on is rural electricity generation. The increase in the excise duty on light fuel will have negative consequences for many rural communities that generate their own electricity. Many electricity generators in rural regions across Australia run on light fuel oil. Unlike the exemption available to coal-fired electricity stations, no exemption on light fuel oil will be available to those electricity generators. Subsequently, any increase in production costs will only be passed on to rural people and rural businesses.

This is just another example of how the increases contained in this legislation will hit rural and regional communities. People in rural Australia wonder what they have done to deserve this. They have done nothing to deserve this. They are part of a productive sector of our economy. They choose to make their lives in rural and regional Australia. They are bringing up families in rural and regional Australia. What we see in this bill is a tax grab involving rural communities, which are our productive sectors. It will only add to their costs. There will be no benefits as a result of this. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to speak briefly on the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2). I will raise a couple of points that have been referred to by the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott). Let us be perfectly honest, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) is another attempt to fix the holes in the government's budget strategy relating to diesel fuel excise. The latest changes seek to change the definition of fuel oils so that light fuel oils attract the same rate of excise as diesel fuel oil and to increase the rate of excise duty on certain topped crude oil.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at some of the matters that speakers such as the member for Maranoa and others have raised in this debate. With the changes that are being proposed to light fuel oil and the definition of fuel oils in the Excise Tariff Act, we are going to see yet another destabilisation, yet another alteration, to the excise regime for small businesses. This evening I want to examine how businesses are affected by such a change.

Also included in this particular bill is an amendment proposed by schedule 2 which increases the rate of excise on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products by approximately 10 per cent. That increase gives effect to the government's 1995-96 budget announcement:

SPEECH.PARA: The rate of excise (and corresponding customs duty) on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products will be increased by $7.18 per kilogram (10 per cent) from midnight on 9 May 1995. This increase brings forward and replaces the previously announced 5 per cent discretionary increase in tobacco excise scheduled for August 1995. As well as raising additional revenue, this measure supports health policy aimed at discouraging smoking.

The proposed increase in excise on manufactured tobacco and tobacco products is estimated to result in an increase in revenue of $70 million in 1995-96 and $66 million in 1996-97. That is a matter that those of us who are concerned about the effects of smoking as a community health issue would have to support.

PARA.TAB: But the most contentious aspect of the bill concerns the taxation of light fuel oils. We have been told that the amendment proposed by item 1 of schedule 3 of the bill changes the definition of fuel oil in the Excise Tariff Act 1921. As noted in the explanatory memorandum, the new definition is intended to exclude light fuel oils. The exclusion of light fuel oils from the definition will result in light fuel oils attracting the higher diesel fuel rate of excise.

As we have heard already this matter is of concern to operators of equipment that is easily convertible for operation on light fuel oils, and the member for Maranoa has mentioned one of the areas particularly affected: tourism operators in areas such as the Great Barrier Reef. I understand from the material that has been circulated that this proposed exclusion of light fuel oils from the definition of fuel oil is estimated to result in an increase in revenue of $100 million in 1995-96 and $100 million in 1996-97. Again, this measure was announced in the 1995-96 budget.

The prospect of the disallowance of the measure contained in item 1 of schedule 3 relating to light fuel oil, which applies from 1 July 1995, raises questions regarding the position of a refund of the excise paid since the measure had force under excise tariff proposal No. 3 of 1995. An excerpt from the Bills Digest states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is arguable, if a disallowance by Parliament results in the measure being void, and therefore not operative at all, or voidable, which means that it will not operate from the time of disallowance, will depend on whether this issue is dealt with in the measure to disallow the proposed increase in duty.

That leads me to the main point of my speech this evening: the awful confusion that is reigning on the definition of fuel. The matters also relate to the changes being proposed or mooted in the Customs Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill, which is also designed to fix the problems that have been created by this confusion.

PARA.TAB: For one of my constituents, a constituent who operates a granite quarry near York in Western Australia's wheat belt, this is a very serious problem. His particular quarry has been a small affair which has been run until now by his son. The business was purchased in 1974, and because of access to the diesel fuel rebate it provided a very meagre profit for the owners, the Wales family. For small businesses, profit is the be-all and end-all.

We have the situation here where, because of increasing competition from overseas products, businesses are finding it more and more difficult to make a profit and keep their staff employed. That quarry business has found itself in a position where very shortly it may well have to cease operation unless it is able to compete more favourably against overseas competition. Sales of granite, for instance, have halved over the past five years with imports of granite from overseas—such as Singapore, Japan and Hong Kong—decimating the local market.

This particular small business has been getting smaller through no fault of the owners or operators. Three years ago the operation employed three men full time as well as Mr Wales's son. But, as we have been told by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), this is the best it will get for small businesses. Now, as a result of the confusion that is being created by these changes, we find ourselves in a situation where this particular small business will lose its rebate for diesel fuel, which will put it in a very precarious position.

This situation may be compared with the situation which arose with the imposition of sales tax on in situ pools, which was introduced by amendments to the sales tax legislation in 1992. The sales tax was ruled by the High Court to be invalid as a breach of section 55 of the constitution, as the act that imposed the tax dealt with more than the imposition of taxation. Consequently, the Swimming Pools Tax Refund Act 1992 was passed with the aim of ensuring that the sales tax that had been paid on such pools was refunded only to those who could show that they had actually paid the tax.

The member for Maranoa also indicated that items 2 and 3 of schedule 3 increase the rate of excise payable on aviation gasoline and kerosene. The rate of excise duty payable on aviation gasoline will increase by 1.847c per litre to 19.08c per litre and for aviation kerosene by 0.883c per litre to 2.38c per litre. The government's rationale for these increases is to contribute to assisting funding for air safety regulation.

Yet again, that is another impost on small business, and it is one that many will find themselves in a position of not being able to afford. We have only to look at the now increasingly cumbersome range of taxes impacting on small businesses to understand why when the Prime Minister repeats his now notorious phrase, `This is as good as it's going to get,' many small business operators in the nation start to pull out their remaining hair and look at some other means of making a living. The fact of the matter is that we have an increasing tax burden on small businesses as a result not only of the direct imposition of increases in tax rates but also of the increasing complexity and difficulty in being able to deal with the taxation regime from which the increased rate will be taken.

We have a situation where the whole of this fuel excise is like an uncontrolled monster devouring all in its path. The question that many small business people are asking themselves is, `Where next? What will we be faced with next? How will we be able to be taxed, or are our pips going to squeak before any more can be extracted from us?'

I return to the quarry operation that I referred to earlier. Here we have a situation where a small family business is now basically being crushed by the totality of the taxation regime under this government, ranging from the treatment of fuel excise all the way through to the other add-on costs that make it almost impossible for it to be able to compete with overseas businesses.

For instance, in recent times we have seen the types of problems that Australian industries are facing in the context of increased participation in competition with overseas operators who are exporting to Australia. Because of the Australian business tax regime, more and more of our local operators—particularly in niche markets such as the constituents are in in my electorate—are finding it increasingly difficult to compete.

So what will happen in the case of the closure of that particular quarry business? Yet another Australian will be thrown on to the scrap heap, and we will find ourselves yet again with one less business and one less employer. If we are to solve the unemployment crisis in our nation, we must recognise that small business is the key. As we well know, small business is the largest employer in the nation.

These particular tariff bills, as has been raised by previous speakers, serve to increase the complexity of the taxation arrangements. I have mentioned the extract from the Bills Digest which in itself is supposed to be a simplification of the way in which the bills will work. It is extremely complicated and difficult to understand. These sorts of costs, these extra imposts on small businesses throughout the country, add to the unprofitability or lack of competitiveness, and mean in the end that people will choose to cease operating and will find something else to do or some other way to use their valuable capital, rather than put their fellow Australians into work.

Earlier I indicated I would make some brief comments on my concern that, in relation to the definition of fuel oils as a result of that budget strategy, we find ourselves in another situation where more and more complex taxation legislation is heaped upon small business operators who are increasingly less able to deal with this taxation regime. As we know, in the case of the income tax regime, there are several thousand pages of taxes. In the case of sales tax, it is more and more complicated and difficult to understand. Increasingly, the application of sales tax is corrupted by political decisions, and I intend to deal with other aspects of that in some of the bills that will be before us in this session.

In the final analysis, a business tax regime that does nothing to ensure that the small business sector will be able to play its part in employing more Australians cannot play its part in being, I suppose, the prime mover in getting unemployed Australians back into the work force. It is unfortunate it has come to this, it is unfortunate that we find ourselves in this position, but again we find that complexity is the name of the game. At the end of the day the bureaucracy and the complexity of the taxation legislation come down to crush small businesses which are at this particular point finding it difficult to operate and to compete, even without extra taxation imposts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill is aimed at increasing the flexibility of the operations of the Industry Commission, which is the government's major advisory body on industry matters, broadly defined. The government values the major contribution of the Industry Commission as a catalyst for micro-economic reform in Australia. Its strengths are its independence, established expertise, public inquiry process, and economy-wide approach to examining issues.

PARA.TAB: The amendments contained in the bill are of a purely procedural nature and involve three basic changes: allowing commissioners to be appointed on a part-time basis, including permanent part-time employment, in addition to the current full-time basis; a consequential increase in the number of commissioners, other than the chairperson, from eight to 11; and allowing the progression of the commission's public hearings in emergency situations, where one or more commissioners may be unable to attend due to circumstances beyond their control.

The first basic change follows from the current provision in the Industry Commission Act 1989 which allows commissioners to be appointed only on a full-time basis. The government has found that this provision limits its ability to attract a more diverse range of suitably qualified people. This change will allow the government to recruit those who hold other positions and are unwilling to become full-time commissioners. Consequently, the bill has been drafted to allow the appointment of commissioners on either a full-time or part-time basis, with equal powers.

The second basic change, of increasing the maximum number of commissioners, necessarily follows the first. The commission will need to maintain the same level of resources at the commissioner level, thus requiring more commissioners in total if there are to be part-time appointees.

The third basic change is intended to provide additional flexibility to the commission in the conduct of its public hearings. Where one or more commissioners on an inquiry are unable to attend a scheduled public hearing due to unforeseen circumstances such as accident, illness or injury, the remaining commissioner will be able to preside at the public hearings.

The remaining amendments are drafting changes consequential on the above proposed amendments. The proposed amendments do not have any financial implications. However, should the number and mix of full-time and part-time commissioners increase beyond the present funding levels, an increase in funding will be sought through the normal budgetary processes.

This bill will allow the commission greater flexibility in its operations and increase its chances of attracting a more diverse range of suitably qualified people to the commission. I commend the bill to honourable members.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the Industry Commission Amendment Bill 1995 is largely a machinery provision which provides for greater flexibility in the operation of the Industry Commission, as the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) has indicated in his second reading speech, it is eminently sensible and accordingly will not be opposed by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Just to recap briefly, the amendment to allow the appointment of commissioners other than the chairperson on a part-time basis, in addition to the current full-time basis, is one which is aimed at increasing the commission's chances of attracting a more diverse range of suitably qualified people.

The second major amendment—allowing a single commissioner to act on behalf of all other commissioners on an inquiry in the absence of other commissioners but limited to public hearings and only in emergency situations—will also allow for the commission to operate in that, due to unforeseen circumstances such as accident, illness or injury, preventing one or other commissioners on the inquiry from participating in a public hearing, the remaining commissioner will be able to reside at the public hearing or part of the public hearing. It also adds some flexibility to the operation of the commission.

The final amendment of substance that requires full-time commissioners to obtain the consent of the minister to engage in paid employment outside the duties of his office and restrict part-time commissioners from engaging in paid employment that in the minister's opinion conflicts with the proper performance of the commissioner's duties also adds flexibility to the operation of the Industry Commission. For those reasons of flexibility and, as I said, the eminent sense of these amendments, the bill will not be opposed by the coalition.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
