TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure to speak on this motion because the Australia Remembers committee set up in Dunkley was, I would say, without a doubt the best Australia Remembers committee in the whole of Australia. It was a community committee. It was set up after I put a notice in the paper. I got members of the community to put up their hands and apply to join, and we had some great members.

PARA.TAB: We also had some great functions. I will go through some of the functions. The first one we had was for the war veterans at the Frankston Overport War Veterans Home. This home was set up by the RSL. It has a number of veterans there. We had a barbecue there and a bit of a singalong. We had a local band, Tommy Carter, and we were singing all these songs. It was a great day. The veterans really appreciated it.

Along with some sausages, we also had a few drinks. I can recall that some of the old diggers there would say to me, `Listen, Bob, do you reckon you can get another beer for us?' I remember the look of pleasure on their faces on that day as they were singing these songs from the war years.

After that we decided it was such a good thing to sing these songs, we produced a song book. Mr Deputy Speaker, you have probably seen this song book—it has gone all over Australia. It was published by our committee and it has all the songs from Bless'em all and Cockles and mussels to Kiss me goodnight, sergeant major. I am afraid some other member pinched this song book that we produced. However, I was not at all perturbed as long as they gave us a bit of recognition. But it was done by our committee. It is a great book and it is something that gave a lot of happy memories to a lot of people. I could just about get up and sing some of these songs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sing us a song, Bob, come on.
—I would, if you joined in. I would give you a rendition.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—The honourable member shouldn't because it's a bit hard for Hansard to record it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It contains songs like Hanging out the washing and Galway Bay, all of those songs from that era. We did not have enough of these song books to hand out. As I said, we had to run off more copies. Other people pinched a copy, ran it off on their machines and put their covers and things on it. We did not mind because it brought back the memories of those days. That song book was a great production by the committee.

PARA.TAB: The committee published another book, Fifty years on. We did not just have your normal functions like barbecues on Remembrance Day, we went all out; this committee worked hard. This book was produced by the Frankston Peninsula Ex-Servicewomen's RSL Branch and gave the stories of some of the women who were actually there. This is also a great book containing some of the stories of what they went through during the war years and what they had to put up with. That was the second book produced.

Not to stop at just two books, we produced a third book called Heroes at home and abroad. This book gave the experiences of not just people involved in the forces but also people in the Land Army, people who worked in various factories, et cetera. Some of the stories here are really good. They bring home to me exactly what the war was all about. One of the stories in it, which is very relevant to this year of Australia Remembers, shows that a lot of people went away to war and, when it finished, they were overseas and they were never really welcomed home. A member of the committee that I chaired initially and then handed over to chairman Len Streets said to me that he never got a welcome home. When you think about it, those people were away overseas and they were not around when everyone was celebrating and Australia Remembers was the first time they were welcomed home.

When I was handing out certificates to people for the service they rendered to our country, just saying thank you for what they did—we would not be here today in this House if it was not for those people—some people had tears in their eyes. For me it was a great, moving experience. I would like to read a bit here from Neil Belbin, who was an able seaman back in 1940. Talking about his experience on the Australia he says:

SPEECH.PARA: The sky was thick with planes and the guns were blazing. But the crew could do nothing to stop the suicidal pilots who so readily died for their emperor. They could only stay at their stations, scared rigid, and wait for them to come. By the time the fifth plane had hit, many were close to breakdown.
The battle finally took its toll and on January 9, the proud Australia, seriously damaged but still afloat, gave up the fight. At the end, almost 90 men had been killed and several hundred wounded.
War scarred and battle weary, the Australia limped into Sydney Harbour a month later. Only the Manly ferry was there to greet her.
There was to be no welcome for the heroic crew.

That encapsulates what many people experienced at the end of the Second World War. That book has various stories of great heroes and it is written to give a warts and all account. It is not something that was written by a historian that put only their views. This was written by the people involved. One of them, Alan Hopkins, wrote to me. He was a pilot who dropped food over the Netherlands in Operation Manna. He wrote to me to see whether he could get some funding to go back to the Netherlands or get a plane from the Australian government to take part in the celebrations in Holland. So I wrote to the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), but that could not be arranged. He also wrote to the Dutch Embassy here in Australia and he received a letter back from the Counsellor of the Royal Netherlands Embassy in Canberra. This letter brings home to you a lot of what Australian people did overseas:

In the period of April-May, 1945, I found myself as a five-year-old boy on the receiving end of Operation Manna, living at that time with my parents in the suburb of The Hague, close to the Ypenburg airfield where the food droppings took place.

Together with my father and mother and all the neighbours, we were standing on the roofs of our houses frantically waving with big sheets, towels and everything we could find to the allied planes which roared very low over our heads, their wingtips moving up and down to greet us.

And, young as I was, I will never forget the words my father said to me on that roof—that I was never to forget that day being one of the most important in my life, because now the war was almost over and these people up there in their planes were our best friends, who had come to our rescue.

As you see, I never forgot those words and I want to take this opportunity after almost 50 years, to thank you for what you did for me and the people of Western Holland who were so near to starvation.
Karel H Birkman,
Counsellor of the Royal
Netherlands Embassy, Canberra
16 June 1994
That connection was made—Alan went to Holland where he was feted and treated as a hero, as he was, by the Dutch people. So that was the third book we produced.

PARA.TAB: We also held a competition for the construction of peace gardens throughout the electorate. I am pleased to say that Frankston East Primary School won the competition. As a matter of fact, last week I had the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) in my electorate. We went up and had a look at it and he congratulated the schoolchildren, teachers and parents for what they have done there. They won the prize from all the other schools that competed.

We also had exhibitions at local shopping centres and ecumenical services. Just last Saturday we had a plaque dedication ceremony by the young people of Frankston to all those people who took part in the Second World War.

The Dunkley Australia Remembers Committee was chaired by Len Streets and the members were: Doris Baker, Tommy Carter, Clive De Jussing, Lorraine Ekin, Colin Hampton, Tom Hampton, Bert Langley, Ken Maddison, Dorothy Murphy, Lee Optiz, Michael Quayle, Dorothy Somerville, Jean Stemmer, Maree Wiles, and me. Just last week I took them to dinner with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who presented them with certificates of appreciation for what they did for those people who fought and died for our country back in the 1940s.

I was born in 1941. All I can remember is that at the end of war, in Hawthorn, where I lived, we had a bomb shelter that was always full of water and mosquitoes. My mother made clothing for the troops. I remember that we always had plenty of mosquito netting around the place—I think she might have scored a little bit there. My father was a moulder and made bombs and shells. He used to come home late and he was always dirty—I can remember that. They are about all my memories of the war. But if it were not for people like that and for the troops, we would not be here today.

Our Australia Remembers committee worked hard and tirelessly, and they are still working. We came out with a profit. I know many committees are not supposed to make a profit but we had a tremendous concert in the new Frankston cultural centre where we had 800 people singing these songs from our song book and enjoying the various plays and things that were put on.

We came out with a few dollars, and we have not decided what to do with them yet. I trust we will not have to hand them back. We will do something good with the money. We will relate it to something that has happened within the community—a lasting reminder of what these people fought and died for.

The ball we held on VP Day, 15 August, was one of the highlights. On our supper menu we had Pearl Harbour port; Pacific pate with bombardier biscuits; diggers delights, which were chook legs; San Ananda sangers, which were mixed sandwiches; Burma balls, which were meatballs with sweet and sour; comrade croquettes; Kokoda quiche; Tobruk rats, which were camouflaged as sausage rolls; bully beef; blitz stick; Salvo's brew, which was a cup of tea; and cook's mud cake.

We made a good year of it. We had good fun, people enjoyed it and we did what we set out to do, which was to celebrate the end of the war, to remember it and, above all, to make certain that our young people were educated. We also set up a team of people to go around the schools and talk to school children and answer questions. That is continuing now. It is something that I found most enlightening. Many young people did not know anything about the Second World War. They knew nothing about it at all—even my own children, who are in their 20s. They had heard me speak of my grandfather. Because they did not know of anyone actually involved in the war, they knew virtually nothing about it. This year has made certain that they are aware of it and that they do not forget the lessons of the past. Hopefully, they will make certain that it will never happen again.

The whole year, to me, has been a success. I would like to personally thank Con Sciacca, but I would like to publicly thank him here and now for what he did. He has done something that is very hard to achieve in politics: he has made it apolitical. It has never been a partisan thing. It has crossed all of the parties. Everyone has been involved in it. People have been involved as much as they have wanted to be involved. I have put a lot of work into it and my staff have put a lot of work into it. I felt that it was extremely important. It is the last chance to thank these people.

I recall talking just a few months ago to some First World War people who are still down at the war veterans home. A lot of the history that they were involved in has not been recorded. It had gone before the oral histories and those sorts of books were written. We have only a historian's view of the war. That is not right. We want the views of people who were involved in the war and the problems they encountered—warts and all. As I said, this year has allowed us to collect it all. It is going to be great when it is all collated.

I would like to thank publicly the minister, all those in his office and everyone who was involved in this great year of celebration of victory, this year of commemoration and remembrance of those involved in the war and this year of education. It has been good. The committee down in Frankston, as I said before, has probably done more and better work than any other committee in Australia. I congratulate each and every one of them, and I look forward to their continuing to work to make certain that the money that we have left over goes to a very worthy cause.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow the member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) in this debate on the Australia Remembers year. I can assure the House that the great pride that he shared with his committee is very much shared by me, plus a little bit more. This last 12 months has been an extraordinary time for the people in the electorate of Ballarat. Indeed, I am extremely proud of their endeavours over that time.

PARA.TAB: Before I do anything else, I would like to publicly acknowledge the members of the Ballarat committee. I will read out their names because their contributions were extremely important and should be recognised in this House: David Baird, Anne Beggs-Sunter, Betty Bicery, Angela Carey, who was on the committee earlier on, Norma Clack, Bruce Clifton, Jack Ellis—Bruce and Jack were a fantastic help to the chairman of the committee, Mr Peter Heinz OAM—Bill and Col Hall, from Stawell, which is in my electorate, Emil Kallio, Maurice Keating, Ted Lynes, Frank Sheehan, David Smith, Barry Traynor MLA, Stan White, Mark Broemmer and Val Elford. I had the very great honour to be asked early on to be the patron of that committee.

It is fair to say that there would be very few electorates, organisations and committees that put more into this 12 months than my committee in Ballarat. A lot of things have happened in the last six years in my time as the member for Ballarat, but none has given me more pride than this group of people. It comprised Liberal Party politicians, former state members and people from right across the board. The committee represented people from all political persuasions and from right across the community. It worked extremely well. It is a classic example of the fact that this Australia Remembers year has included people from all sides and from all communities who were anxious to ensure that Australia Remembers was a bipartisan event and a great success.

I would like to go through some of the very many events that were held in my electorate over this period. It is a large electorate. There are many communities and they all had a very active input. In no particular order, there was the Daylesford street parade and memorial service and the unveiling of a plaque at Marnoo. The Ballan Hospital presented a patient trolley with a plaque as part of the celebrations. There was a Ballarat VP Day wreath-laying memorial service at the Cenotaph and the presentation of a memorial sculpture to the city council. The sculpture was designed by Mr Peter Blizzard and it is a stunning reminder of the last 50 years. Generation after generation will be looking at that memorial sculpture. It has pride of place at Sturt Street. I know that the committee and the local community are extremely proud of it.

There was a plaque-unveiling and wreath-laying ceremony at Sebastopol and a wreath-laying ceremony at Clunes. The Ballarat committee organised a victory ball, which nearly 900 people attended. There was a victory parade and march in Ballarat from the RSL to the Town Hall, followed by an ecumenical service. There were celebrations at the Ballarat Grammar School. There was an 8/7 Battalion 137th birthday parade and a wreath-laying ceremony which commemorated the 80th anniversary of the VC awarded to William Dunstan.

The committee organised, in conjunction with Legacy, two Legacy lunches for war widows. There were over 400 people at each of those lunches. They were a fantastic success. I heard the member for Dunkley talking about the booklet that his committee put out. I am sure many of us know the songs in it. If we did not grow up with them, we would certainly know them all very much off by heart after the last 12 months. I can see the member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) nodding his head in agreement.

The Stawell sub-branch of the committee organised a VP concert, which was a fantastic night. It was held at the Stawell Secondary College. The young people there—indeed, two or three of the local performing groups—had a great input. The diggers day golf tournament was a great success in commemorating this 50th year. The Sebastopol RSL had a victory dinner, which I had the great pleasure to attend and speak at. It was a great night.

Without trying to single out any event during that time, there is no doubt that the Australia Remembers concert at Her Majesty's Theatre, at which there were 1,000 people, was a highlight. Five hundred people could not get tickets. A portion of that show was put on for the region's school children the next day, on the Monday. There was a capacity audience. The risk with these things is to try to pick out names, but it was made up basically of Ballarat or ex-Ballarat talent. There were people taking part in the concert who have performed in Melbourne, Sydney and New York. They are young men and women of whom we are extremely proud. They came back to Ballarat to do this concert, and I am sure that it will last a lifetime in the memory of every single person who was there. It was an absolutely fantastic afternoon. I cannot speak highly enough of it.

The Buninyong sub-branch of the RSL also had a wreath-laying and community lunch. Last Saturday I was out at another function at Creswick where a memorial plaque was unveiled. I am sure that there are events that I have unfortunately forgotten.
Debate interrupted; adjournment proposed and negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to make some general comments in the time left available to me. I have publicly and privately thanked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) for his significant role in the last 12 months. I and my committee were very flattered to receive a letter back from the minister saying how impressed he was with the input and dedication shown by that Ballarat electorate committee over that time.

PARA.TAB: An important part of Australia Remembers was that so many of our young people were involved in what has been a fantastic year. The salutary lesson that has come out of all this has been that our young people can look at the commemoration of the extraordinary contributions and sacrifices made by so many men and women from this great country 50 years ago, but in the context not of glorifying war but of commemorating deeds performed for this country.

In the Australia Remembers year we have finally recognised the contribution of those who remained at home and the extraordinary support that they provided to those who were required to leave our shores to defend this country. I was speaking to a digger at a function recently who said, `Quite frankly and quite simply, and I put it to you bluntly, we could not have achieved what we did without the contribution made at home by many groups.'

I do not wish to single out particular groups but the Women's Land Army was one absolutely classic example of extraordinary contributions in my electorate. If you speak to many of the women who were in the Women's Land Army and to women, now grandmothers, who in their early days were running a family farm while their men were overseas, you get some indication of the fact that it was a combined community effort 50 years ago. Of course, some paid the ultimate sacrifice and died on the battlefields outside this country, but others made their contributions at home. It is wonderful that this country has been able to recognise the gamut of people involved in the Second World War in a community sense.

There is no doubt that the approach taken by the minister ensured that this was a bipartisan effort involving all local members of parliament—every one of whom I am sure had the commonsense not to make it political but to make it a community year—and, as I have said, it has been a stunning success.

I would like to pay tribute to my staff, who have made an extraordinary contribution over the last 12 months. Our Australia Remembers thankyou certificates have been produced not in their hundreds but in their thousands, which has required an extraordinary contribution from my staff, and I publicly thank them most sincerely for making the year a great success.
Finally, I thank most sincerely the committee and the people of the Ballarat electorate who came out in their droves to make these celebrations the success that they were.
Debate (on motion by Mr Snowdon) adjourned.
Motion (by Mr Snowdon) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the big problems facing all parliamentarians in state and federal politics is the issue of fuel pricing. There is a very great concern in the community, particularly in country and regional areas, about the high cost of fuel and the variations in fuel prices between regional and remote areas and city areas. Country residents are frequently required to pay from 7c to 14c a litre more than those in the city, despite regulation of maximum wholesale prices and transport costs. Fuel consumers in the city and country do not always have access to an effective, open, transparent and competitive market that stands the test of being fair to all consumers and free of discrimination. Fair and reasonable fuel prices for all consumers should be available, and something needs to be done to ensure that such a system is put in place.

PARA.TAB: The RACV and the Victorian Farmers Federation have done some excellent work on this and I would like to thank them for their contribution and their suggestions which I will briefly summarise. This may not be precisely what they said but it is the gist of it. They call for the establishment of an oil industry voluntary code of conduct involving the introduction of a form of terminal gate pricing designed to prevent unfair discrimination between the retailers of fuel in the country and those in the city. They wish to ensure that wholesale fuel prices are published daily so that everyone knows what they are, that oil companies are able to set the price for fuel at rates that recognise the commercial reality of price differences based on volume sales and terms of payment—there have to be some variations there—and that all wholesale purchasers have access to fuel at the published rate applicable to the volume of fuel and the terms of payment involved in the transaction. It is proposed by the RACV and the VFF that this would ensure that wholesale fuel would be offered at the prices at the various terminals to customers and, furthermore, that there would not be a difference based on the geographic area in which the customer operates.

Something that I feel very strongly about is that oil terminals should be open to any potential customer with an appropriate authorised vehicle and qualified driver who is able to purchase and establish the credit that is needed in a commercial transaction to ensure normal commercial practices exist.

I believe that the RACV and the VFF, their members and many members of the public in Australia, particularly in country and regional areas, are crying out for the government to act to ensure that a new system of fuel sales is introduced into Australia and for this system to be monitored by the new Australian Competition and Consumer Commission so that, if evidence emerges of discrimination, uncompetitive practices or profiteering, this would give rise to immediate, prompt, appropriate action against those involved in such unfair and unacceptable practices. I believe that this suggestion by the RACV and the VFF should be examined by us all on a non-party political basis as it is worth while looking at. I believe the oil industry would find that this would also assist them in moving into the next few years.

But the key point is that it is no longer acceptable to see fuel being sold in country areas only a few kilometres away from, say, the city of Melbourne at 7c to 14c a litre higher than the price in the city of Melbourne. Of course, we all understand that occasionally moves are made to gain market share and some marketing techniques are used that involve discounting. But, when the fluctuations in price are so large and occur so consistently, I believe that is prima facie evidence of a market force taking place which is not competitive, is certainly not transparent and which does discriminate. I am sure it is not in the commercial interests of anyone investing in the oil industry in Australia to be associated with practices that are becoming more and more abhorrent to the consumer. A good relationship between the consumer and the companies involved is the essence of the success of any future commercial enterprise. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jeffrey Kennett, no. This is to do with the sale of Quayside, a shopping centre in my electorate. On Saturday it was advertised in the Australian and on Monday it was advertised in the Melbourne Age. It has gone into liquidation with debts of around $80 million, as far as we can ascertain. Frankston council has a 49 per cent interest in this centre, and in 1988 I warned the council against it. I said in this House that it was ill-conceived and that the council did not have the experience to be involved in this sort of venture. I have, sorrily, been proved correct.

PARA.TAB: The unelected Kennett-appointed commissioners are now making decisions that will affect the community of Frankston forever. Commissioners should be there not as people who make long-term decisions but just as caretakers. These decisions that they make really will have long-term consequences.

What is happening with Quayside? As I said, it has gone into liquidation and it is up for sale. The actual Frankston council mortgaged the land that it was built on—that was their contribution—plus three other packages of land. One package of land that they mortgaged to the Commonwealth Bank was one that had a $16 million cultural centre built on it after it has been mortgaged to the Commonwealth Bank. Anyone with any business knowledge would say that this is foolhardiness in the extreme—and that is exactly what it is—by these councillors and council officers whom I must point out gave the advice to the councillors on what they should do with this land. Anyway, it was mortgaged to the Commonwealth Bank.

I have been trying to stop the sale of one of these packages of land called Central Car Park or Lawrey's paddock. I have had negotiations with the Commonwealth Bank and with the actual council. But it seems as though all my negotiations have gone straight out of the window and that they will sell this paddock. Lawrey's paddock was actually sold to the Frankston council back in 1945. I will read something from the local paper at the time:

SPEECH.PARA: Councillor Fowler said there was a lot of commonsense in Councillor Reardon's suggestion but, unfortunately, the council was tied by the conditions under which the land was purchased.

What we are talking about there is Lawrey's paddock or Central Car Park, which was purchased as a park for the people of Frankston. It is now going to be sold, or tenders have been called for it to be developed into another shopping centre area.

PARA.TAB: We have already got shops in Frankston which have been empty for years because of this Quayside development. We have more than enough shops. People are going broke down there because of this Quayside development, which is out fighting for every dollar that they can get. Now they want to sell this land, which was bought by the Frankston council at the time as a park for the people of Frankston. Another article from back in 1945 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The only major achievement by the council he was able to recall was the acquiring of Lawrey's land for a park.

Why am I giving you the history of what happened back in 1945? Because we cannot find the contract of sale. I have been through all the council records. You would think that, with a large parcel of land, they would have the contract of sale, but it is not there. Where is it? No-one knows. We have been to the chief executive officer, but no-one can find it. I have been to have a look for it but I cannot find it anywhere in the records in relation to Lawrey's paddock. However, I have a letter here from the solicitor to Frankston council at the time, a Robert C. Taylor, which is dated 26 July 1945. It reads:
Re: the purchase from the estate of S. Lawrey.
The 19th condition of the contract of sale dated 10 February 1945 provides that—

And it goes on about the cost. What are the other 18 conditions? Why can't I find this contract of sale? The reason why I cannot find it is that I believe someone has plucked it out of those records which have been held in the council and that it has been destroyed. I am searching for it and I will make certain that I have a campaign to save that land for the people of Frankston. These commissioners are there as caretakers. They are not to sell the assets which were given to the people of Frankston to be a green space, an open space. I will fight as much as I can.

PARA.TAB: What are the other 18 conditions of this particular solicitor's letter? Why can't the council supply me with the contract of sale? I believe there has been some dirty business going on. This deal is set up to give this parcel of land to a big developer who already owns a shopping area down there, and we are looking into that closely. I hope to make more speeches on this matter in the future. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smyth Mr B.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the June session of parliament, Lake Tuggeranong College, a high school in my electorate, put students out on work experience in various offices and a Ranae Dryden worked in my office during that time. Ranae's family had spent time in Burma when she was younger. At that stage there was a private member's motion discussing Burma and, when Ranae heard of this, she asked if she could write some recollections of her stay and her feelings about Burma for me to speak on them in the House. I take this opportunity to speak on behalf of Ranae Dryden, a 16-year-old student, and to give some of her feelings about Burma. She states:

SPEECH.PARA: Burma in the 1950s was a prosperous democratic country with a freely elected government. The country was booming economically and had the freest and most progressive press in South East Asia.

This came to an end in 1962 when General Ne Win seized power in a coup d'etat. He immediately regulated the market economy and put in its place his new ideology for governing, effectively opening a doorway to gross human rights violations, brutal massacres, and a stringent military dictatorship which still exists today.
A totalitarian state developed marking the beginning of civil unrest in Burma, which led to several minor student protests, escalating into the now well known 8/8/88 riots.

General Ne Win's military refused to recognise the rights of students. Tension grew and the killings increased. What started as a minor scuffle between three male locals, eventually resulted in what is referred to today as the 1988 massacre. After days of bloodshed the Military silenced the people leaving behind 5,000—10,000 slain. This number is four times that of the Tiananmen Square Massacre in China.

The events that followed the slaughter led to a glimmer of hope for Democracy in 1990. Ne Win and his Party agreed to a nation-wide election. An election in which they were defeated by the National League for Democracy.

Angered by this, the Military declared the election void and either imprisoned, killed or forced out of the country all members of the NLD, charging them with the crime of attempting to form Government.

The founder of the NLD and Noble Prize Winner, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, was placed under house arrest in Rangoon, where she was detained for nearly six years. Aung San Suu Kyi was released on the 16th July.
With increasing international pressure, Ne Win attempted to ease this pressure and boost their reputation by releasing Suu Kyi. However, any real progressive changes are yet to be seen.

A representative of Suu Kyi has recently stated that, ". . . Suu Kyi warns that just because she has been released doesn't mean other countries should relax sanctions against the government. Suu Kyi implores Government and Non Government Organisations to tighten sanctions against SLORC in supporting her Party's efforts to free Burma from military dictatorship.

To the people of Australia and its Government. Now is the time to intervene and to do something about this Military regime. We must come together to make an impact on the present Military reign. Many Burmese have suffered and are still suffering because of the torture, rape and death that is carried out against them by the Military. The Burmese people helped our own men in the Second World War to flee from the torture of the Japanese Military, now the time has come for us to return the favour and help the civilians of Burma to flee from the grasps of their own Military Government. But let us not just try to let the Government leave, but to also make them pay for the rape and death that they have caused. What is done to others must be brought to trial.

There has been many incidents in the world which have destroyed the dreams of people of moving onto a better way of life, but eventually with great persistence and a strong will for freedom, people's dreams have turned into reality. In Africa Apartheid has been demolished, the Berlin Wall was brought down, bringing the two countries of East and West Germany together as one, and the empire of the U.S.S.R. no longer exists.

Now is the time for the dreams of the Burmese to be given a chance to come true, for the Military to lay down their guns, to let the 1990 election results stand and to let the NLD take over so that democracy may reign forever in a country that deserves its freedom and deserves our support.
I would like to congratulate Ranae for her words and for caring about the people of Burma. I commend these words to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham Mr M.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first test for any system of government, the primary test for its constitution, is that the institutions of government earn the respect of the people and at all times treat all people fairly. Mr Speaker, day by day it is becoming clearer that the House of Windsor fails this basic test. It is bad enough that Australia's head of state is not one of us. Australia's head of state is the monarch of another country. But, worse still, on all the objective evidence the institutions of the British monarchy are held out for public ridicule and public embarrassment. It is bad enough that Australia has borrowed the monarchy of another nation; worse still that the House of Windsor has shown itself to be an embarrassment in its own nation.

PARA.TAB: Around the world people have come to the realisation that Prince Charles and his consorts—whichever one he finally settles on—are not fit to rule in Britain. What then must the international community think of Australia? What must they think of Australia—a nation of 17 million people—set to prefer Prince Charles as its head of state to each and every one of our own citizens? What must they think of Australians, given that Prince Charles, under our present constitutional arrangements, is deemed to be more suitable as our head of state than any of us?

If the monarchy cannot command respect in Britain how can anyone think it is suitable for Australia? Why should we persevere with an institution which has destroyed itself through the personal manipulation, indulgence, intrigue and humiliation of the current generation of royals? Respect for Australia and our institutions demands a change to our constitution. We lose respect around the world and respect for each other when we take the monarchy of another nation as our head of state. We lose even more respect when we continue with an institution which has failed so comprehensively in its own country. Each of the members of the House of Windsor is a British citizen. Their standards of behaviour and public presentation over the past decade have shown them to be totally inappropriate to head Australia's constitution.

Not long ago the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott)—more British than the Brits, more royal than the royals, the youngest of the young fogies—described Prince Charles as `a man of international star quality'. In truth, his only starring role these days is in the world's most exposed, most tawdry, most humiliating soap opera—the House of Windsor.

I make the point that even the tories through the ages have acknowledged. The Liberal and National parties in this place have always supported a sense of social hierarchy and social order with the monarchy at the top. They like that sense of order and hierarchy and have always told the people of Australia of their belief that only good breeding would produce a head of state suitable for Australia.

How wrong they have been! How comprehensively wrong they have been! The system of hereditary monarchy is completely contrary to the belief that all people were born equal in status, dignity and opportunity. The rules of succession governing the British monarchy discriminate on the basis of religion, gender and birth. For the current generation of royals they also discriminate on the basis of capacity and suitability. There is one fundamental truth in this debate, that is, you cannot breed integrity and you cannot breed respect.

When the tories in this place defend the monarchy they are in practice saying that Prince Charles would be an appropriate head of state for Australia: we are good enough to have Prince Charles and he is good enough to have us. They are effectively holding up Prince Charles and the current generation of royals as a role model for all Australians. They are saying to young people throughout the country that they should take Prince Charles as their symbol of respect and pride in our system of government.

I could not think of anything more disrespectful to Australia or Australia's future. By supporting the monarchy the coalition is running down the respect that we have for each other as Australians and denying the Australian people the opportunity to have a head of state who is one of us—not only one of us, one that we can choose freely and fairly, based on capacity and respect, and not the current method of selection which is a failed system of inheritance.

On these matters I would have thought that the parliamentary Liberal Party at least would have reference to the opinions of Malcolm Fraser, the longest-standing patriarch of the Liberal Party. This is what he had to say in the Australian newspaper on 30 August 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: Emotionally, I have been attached to the monarchy because I believe nations should protect their past and build on it for the future. For a variety of reasons, which relate more to what has happened in Britain than what has happened in Australia, I now accept that a republic is inevitable and right.
That was Malcolm Fraser acknowledging the point about the behaviour of the royal family. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, a quite outstandingly professional report on the administration of the ACT leasehold system was tabled in the ACT Legislative Assembly. I would like to draw the attention of this House to that report because we did a report on this subject some years ago and this is a particularly fine example of what a professional public inquiry can achieve.

PARA.TAB: The inquiry examined many aspects of the leasehold system including, first of all, whether it should continue. The inquiry concluded that it should continue for very good reasons. The leasehold system avoids land speculation, it allows unearned increments to be retained by the government to defray the costs of the ACT, and it ensures orderly planning by lease purpose clauses. The committee also found that the leasehold system was very unlikely to frighten any investor off.

I regret to say that the inquiry identified major problems in the administration of the leasehold system and the planning system in the ACT. It is chapter 17 which looks into the present administration. The committee makes a whole series of criticisms. For example, it says that it is not difficult to identify sources of community frustration with the process of development when reasonable requests are refused. We see a whole series of examples of situations where, under freedom of information legislation, people have applied for access to information about why decisions have been made and have been refused on quite unreasonable grounds.

There is a lack of disclosure of the interests of officers administering the system. The committee identifies problems of people who have had senior positions in the administration of land who have gone over and worked for the development sector. That obviously creates a conflict of interest. There are problems with compliance. There is a whole series of cases where lease purpose clauses have not been enforced. There have been complaints about that for years but still a lack of enforcement has occurred.

Failure to take steps to force the lessee to comply with the lease purpose clause has meant that for 15 years there was a blatant and continuing breach occurring. One could go on. A whole series of problems has been identified. The report goes on to make some practical, reasonable and intelligent proposals for dealing with this problem. For example, the report proposes setting up a separate statutory authority for the administration of land. It proposes that planning be set up as a separate statutory authority. It proposes that all the senior positions in those two areas be declared vacant and that they be advertised around Australia in an attempt to attract the best professional people into those areas.

The report had earlier expressed concern about the low level of training of people in those areas and the lack of experience in other parts of the Public Service and in the public sector. It is obviously very important to draw in people with a wide range of experience.

I wish to conclude with a particular problem which concerns me greatly. I refer to an incident which occurred in relation to Gungahlin, an area where four suburbs have already been established. The previous ACT government clearly intended that a department would be located in that area in order to create employment opportunities.

However, in the period just before the election the public servants arbitrarily and unilaterally decided that the Department of Environment, Land and Planning would be located in Dickson, close to the centre of Canberra. That defeated the proposal which would have had the effect of increasing employment opportunities in Gungahlin. That was done entirely contrary to the declared intention of the former government and before a new government could be elected. It was an absolutely improper action by the public servants. The committee stated that on the basis of that example alone it is possible to conclude that a major planning decision was made in direct contradiction to government policy and political direction at the highest level.
It was disgraceful. It is important that the people who were involved in that decision are made to explain it and, if necessary, be expected to resign.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House a group of dedicated ACT public servants who are members of the ACT Fire Brigade. I wish to refer to two officers in particular who have added to this service through their studies. Senior firefighter Patrick Jones has just completed a Churchill Fellowship visit to the United Kingdom and Hong Kong. District officer Paul Evans has just completed a study tour of the United States.

PARA.TAB: Senior firefighter Patrick Jones, whilst in the United Kingdom and Hong Kong, visited and was received in the most favourable light by the local authorities. He was seen as a true diplomat and ambassador for the whole of the Australian fire service. He is a true reflection of his brigade's training and support to its members.

District officer Paul Evans has been a firefighter for 16 years. Mr Evans is a highly qualified officer whose dedication to the fire service is reflected in his enthusiasm and commitment to the community. During his study tour to the United States he undertook a number of visits to various fire services in major cities. He also participated in the executive fire officer development course in the American national academy at Maryland. I would like to thank the ACT Fire Brigade for their services and I thank the House for this opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott The Hon R.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ELLIOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: Superannuation is the central pillar of the government's strategy to boost retirement incomes and raise national savings.

PARA.TAB: As a result of government reforms, most working Australians are now covered by superannuation. Regular contributions being made today will generate higher retirement incomes in the future. The growth of superannuation savings is encouraged by generous tax concessions.

The government's decision to promote superannuation brings important responsibilities for the financial sector. Financial institutions and advisers must explain the benefits of long-term investment in a diversified portfolio. To encourage the industry to take a longer-term view on investments, the government now requires that funds report their average returns for the past five years, as well as individual figures for each of those years. Most importantly, fund managers must justify the government's decision to have superannuation managed in the private sector by investing responsibly and delivering strong fund performance over time.

The government's commitment to improving superannuation coverage and the adequacy of end benefits is matched by an equally strong commitment to enhancing the security of member entitlements. A sound regulatory framework of `checks and balances' is essential for maintaining public confidence in superannuation and ensuring the long-term success of the government's retirement incomes policy.

The government's prudential framework is embodied in the superannuation industry supervision, or SIS, legislation. The SIS regime makes it clear that trustees are legally responsible for running their funds in the best interests of fund members. A key duty of trustees under SIS is to implement an investment strategy which takes account of the fund's circumstances. The strategy must have regard to the trade-off between risk and return, the benefits of having a diversified investment portfolio, and the fund's capacity to meet its liquidity needs and future liabilities.

The government considers that the trustee's role is a central one and has made great efforts to educate trustees about their responsibilities. This program of education is continuing, and will continue in the future.

In many cases, trustees retain fund managers to invest superannuation money. The government considers that fund managers need to find ways to invest in a broader range of businesses, rather than concentrating their equity investments on blue-chip stocks. For example, fund managers should consider placing a portion of their investments in small, innovative businesses. This will potentially yield better returns for investors, as well as contributing to the economic wellbeing of all Australians.
The main purposes of this bill are:

SPEECH.PARA: .to expand and strengthen the jurisdiction of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal;
.to ensure that fund auditors certify that funds comply with certain provisions of the SI(S) Act and regulations; and
.to transfer various modification orders made by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner into the body of the SI(S) Act.
I would now like to expand on each of these elements of this bill.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Superannuation Complaints Tribunal

PARA.TAB: Integral to the SIS regime is the requirement that members have access to both their fund's internal complaints handling arrangements and the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. The government set up the tribunal last year to provide fund members with low cost, informal and speedy dispute resolution.

The tribunal has made sound progress in its first year. In the 12 months ending June 1995, the tribunal received a total of 416 written complaints that were within its jurisdiction. Around a quarter of these were resolved, with the balance still in the statutorily-based inquiry and conciliation phases as at the end of the financial year.

Unfortunately, the tribunal has been subject to some criticism relating to the statutory limits on its jurisdiction. These limits have caused a large number of complaints to be excluded by the tribunal on the grounds that they could not be handled under existing legislative constraints. Included amongst these were complaints about disability benefits involving the assessment of medical evidence and certain complaints about life office superannuation products. This bill aims to improve the effectiveness of the tribunal by clarifying and strengthening its jurisdiction over these kinds of complaints.

Complaints about disability claims are set to be handled by the tribunal from 1 November 1995, when the regulation excluding the consideration of `medical evidence' expires. This bill will enhance the effectiveness of the tribunal handling medical evidence complaints in two important ways.

Firstly, it will protect the members of funds that arrange disability cover through an external insurer, by enabling the tribunal to make orders directly against the insurer. This means funds will not face the unfunded liabilities which could otherwise arise where a fund is ordered to pay a disability benefit that has been rejected by its external insurer.

Secondly, the bill puts in place various time limits to prevent the tribunal's being swamped with intractable `old' disability complaints where the trail of medical evidence has gone cold: that is, where the illness or injury which led to a claim may have been obscured by subsequent complications or a new condition.

Broadly, the tribunal will not be able to consider complaints about disability claims decided by fund trustees before 1 November 1994. Given that I announced the tribunal would deal with `medical evidence' complaints in October 1994, the amendments are essentially prospective.

To further enhance the tribunal's efficiency in this area, the government will also support the development of `best practice' guidelines for disability claims handling by the superannuation industry. The peak industry associations are consulting closely with the tribunal and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to develop these guidelines, which will be published by way of a circular. Although compliance with these guidelines will be voluntary, it is expected that they will promote better decision making by funds and insurers, thereby minimising the volume of `medical evidence' complaints made to the tribunal.

With regard to life office superannuation, it was always the government's intention that the tribunal should have coverage over all superannuation products, including those offered by life offices. Unfortunately, the legislation did not give full or certain effect to this intention, and the tribunal has been unable to effectively deal with a common source of complaint, namely, allegations about life office agent misrepresentation.

The bill rectifies this problem by enabling the tribunal to deal with complaints about superannuation-related annuity products and life office agent misrepresentation. Where the sale of a life office superannuation policy was unfair or unreasonable, the bill enables the tribunal to order the cancellation, variation or repayment of the policy.

The amendments to cover life office superannuation are fully prospective, in that the tribunal's new jurisdiction will apply only to life products purchased after royal assent. People with complaints about life products purchased before that date can pursue their concerns through the life industry complaints scheme, as at present.

The government recognises that life offices have a strong presence in the highly competitive retail superannuation market, and that allegations of life agent misrepresentation have been a source of particular concern. However, they are not the only public offer superannuation providers, and it is important that all market players be treated equally before the tribunal, to the extent that that is appropriate and practicable. To this end, further amendments will be made at the earliest opportunity in 1996, to ensure that, as far as possible, the new remedies for sale misconduct are extended to all public offer superannuation providers and intermediaries.

Expanding the tribunal's jurisdiction through the amendments in this bill will add considerably to the tribunal's overall workload. In anticipation of this, the bill provides for the creation of a new full-time deputy chairperson position and two additional part-time member positions. Together with the recent upgrading of the tribunal's secretariat, these measures demonstrate the government's strong commitment to ensuring that the tribunal is able to fulfil its charter.

The government has carefully examined the High Court decision of Brandy v. Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, handed down in February this year, and is satisfied that the existing legislation and the proposed amendments will not involve the tribunal's exercising judicial power.

Amendments which I will move during the debate will remove age limits for the chairperson and deputy chairperson of the tribunal, in line with the government's recently announced general approach in this area.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Compliance audits

PARA.TAB: The second main element of the bill is amendments to enhance the prudential supervision of the superannuation industry.

The bill amends the SI(S) Act to require that fund trustees arrange for a qualified auditor to carry out yearly compliance audits. A fund's auditor will be required to certify that the fund complies with certain requirements of the SI(S) Act and regulations. The trustee is then required to pass on that report to the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

This external check builds on existing audit requirements in the SIS regime. Auditors are already required to sign off on a fund's financial statements. They are also subject to whistleblower provisions which force auditors to report suspected breaches of the law to the ISC.

The tougher audit rules are supplemented by the ISC's own program of audits to check that funds comply with prudential rules and are run in the best interests of fund members. The ISC conducted nearly 800 fund audits around Australia in 1994-95. Taken together, these measures will help protect the interests of fund members.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Transfer of modification orders

PARA.TAB: The bill transfers into the SI(S) Act various modification orders made by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner under part 29 of the act. Many of the modification orders that are being transferred are temporary orders expiring on 30 June 1996. Accordingly, unless they are transferred into the body of the SI(S) Act they will cease to have effect on that date, causing substantial disruption to industry.

The modification orders are generally made to deal with transitional or technical problems in the legislation which are having unintended effects on industry. They provide an avenue for the commissioner to appropriately respond to such problems in the interim period before parliamentary amendments to the legislation can be made. The modification orders being transferred relate to a number of varied matters, and their inclusion in the body of the SI(S) Act will improve the clarity and effectiveness of the legislation.

The transfer of these modification orders into the SI(S) Act reflects the government's belief that modification orders made by the commissioner should be incorporated into the body of the act at the earliest possible opportunity.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Financial impact

PARA.TAB: Turning to financial implications, the bill provides for the creation of a deputy chairperson and two part-time members of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal, to deal with the increased workload the tribunal will have. In a full year, the cost of these positions is estimated to be about $270,000.

In addition, a further resource bid will be brought forward for consultation, as required, with the Department of Finance in the additional estimates process. The full, ongoing yearly cost of the bid is expected to be of the order of $500,000. Further one-off costs, including a new case management system, would be a further $210,000.

In conclusion, superannuation has a vital role to play in Australia's economic future. This bill demonstrates the government's commitment to ensuring that there is a strong and effective supervisory framework for superannuation. The amendments will improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the ISC and the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal and, consequently, protect member entitlements and maintain public confidence in the superannuation system.
I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is probably my final speech on the subject of superannuation in this parliament. It is a field that I entered back in about 1981 when the then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, appointed me as the chairman of a task force to examine a number of important reports which had been tabled on superannuation reform. Unfortunately, the election in March 1983 interrupted the Fraser government's examination of my report. Mr Keating—now Prime Minister—came forward with his proposals in June of the same year. So, while it was claimed by the government that they were the founders of the major changes in superannuation policy, it is important to point out that some basic work was done prior to the change of government which of course they were able to benefit from.

PARA.TAB: The coalition is not opposing the substance of these amendments. They are quite significant in their own right, and I support the view of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) that issues relating to the regulatory framework for superannuation are of primary importance. It is also, of course, quite relevant that the major issue of superannuation is clearly going to be a subject for continuing debate leading up to the next election. The fact that the government has appointed the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Con Sciacca, to be involved in this exercise demonstrates that it takes this matter as seriously as the opposition does. I would say to Mr Sciacca, who is not in the chamber, that I think he will find dealing with the esoterics of superannuation considerably more difficult than selling Australia Remembers.

This legislation—the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995—does contain four major areas of review: expanding the jurisdiction and improving the effectiveness of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal; transferring various modification orders made by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner into the body of the SI(S) Act; requiring audits of superannuation entities to cover compliance with certain provisions of the SI(S) Act and its regulations; and making other miscellaneous amendments to the SI(S) Act, the SRC Act and the SET Act, primarily aimed at improving the effectiveness and efficiency of those acts and the system of prudential supervision of the industry.

The amendments in relation to the extension of the SCT jurisdiction expand the jurisdiction of the complaints tribunal. This is very important because it is important to consider the reality that medical evidence is of particular significance in many cases where people have complaints with their superannuation intermediaries or companies, and matters relating to decisions taken in that context will be covered by these amendments.

The existing tribunal opened in July 1994 to hear complaints about procedural fairness, with the intention that it would be exempted from hearing cases involving the interpretation of medical evidence. This was in line with the recommendation made by the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation in October 1993. The concern was that the tribunal would be swamped by complaints involving conflicting medical evidence which could not be readily resolved, thereby bogging down the tribunal's progress.

In August 1994, opposition senators voted to disallow the regulation exempting medical evidence cases on the basis that the regulation unfairly prevented people with disabilities from having access to a low cost dispute mechanism, and following a review by the Senate select committee which concluded that it was not convinced that there was not a role for the tribunal to play in the consideration of medical complaints.

In October, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer announced that the SCT would be able to handle medical complaints from 1 May 1995, following consultations with interested parties concerning possible approaches. The coalition agreed to provide the government with this six-month period of grace. In April 1995 an agreement was reached to extend the period for a further six months, following uncertainty about the SCT powers in relation to disputes following the High Court's decision in Brandy v. Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and Others. In the light of Brandy, the bill amends the act to remove a number of grounds on which a complaint could be made which could have been construed as judicial in character. The jurisdiction of the SCT is limited by the bill to deciding whether a decision is, or was, unfair or unreasonable.

The bill enables the SCT to review complaints relating to the payment of disability benefits if the trustee's decision was made on or after 1 November 1994. There have been some suggestions that the date should be prospective. An extension of jurisdiction to cover life office products is also an important area of reform. Last October, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer indicated that legislation would be expedited to ensure that the SCT had jurisdiction to deal with complaints involving life office superannuation products.

The bill inserts a new subsection 14A(1) which enables a person who has an interest in a life policy fund to complain to the SCT that the decision of the trustee to admit the person to the fund was unfair or unreasonable. This has the effect of allowing persons who have suffered misconduct—for example, misrepresentation at the hands of life office agents—to obtain redress. The issue came to a point a few years ago when unsatisfactory policies were being sold to Aborigines on Palm Island in Queensland and demonstrated the type of issues which can arise in this context.

It was always the government's intention that the SCT would have this power but doubts existed as to whether the tribunal was able to apply them in the context of drafting the legislation. However, there is no equivalent right to complain to the tribunal in the event of mis-selling or undue influence, et cetera, in association with the sale of a non-life insurance superannuation product.

As the parliamentary secretary is no doubt aware, brokers and financial planners are increasingly marketing superannuation products through master trusts. The question therefore does have to be asked: why was the extension of the tribunal's jurisdiction in this case limited to life offices? Has the government seen the amendments proposed by the Life, Investment and Superannuation Association of Australia, LISA, and, if so, what is the government planning to do with the amendments?

I am well aware of the fact that there is not total agreement between the financial industry or financial intermediaries and their representatives as to what the content of any further amendments ought to be. We have agreed to allow the passage of the legislation despite the fact that there are some areas yet to be covered. We believe it is essential that issues specifically relating to the marketing of superannuation products, through master trusts and elsewhere, should be closed off at the first available opportunity. This is at least a step in the right direction, but I place on record that we believe further work has to be done in this particular area.

I turn to the question of jurisdiction extended to cover annuities. The bill also inserts a new subsection 15A(1) enabling a person who has an interest in an annuity policy to complain to the SCT that the conduct of the insurer or representative of the insurer during the sale process was unfair or unreasonable. For a long time annuities were not regarded as being part of the superannuation system but it is fair to say that that is no longer the general view. In a generic sense, annuities are certainly regarded within the industry and by consumers as part of superannuation. It is only consistent, therefore, that they should be treated in the same context.

In regard to other changes in this particular area, there have been some changes to the tribunal arrangements so that the workload will be adequately covered by an additional deputy chairperson. As the parliamentary secretary is well aware, I have already identified the fact, as he has recently done, that we would also like to move an amendment eliminating the reference to age. It is quite absurd that people should be prevented from serving as chairpersons, representatives or part-time or full-time members of the SCT, especially in a context of the fact that the opposition, through my own efforts in the lower House, and in the Senate, has now put forward no fewer than four bills to remove age discrimination. Those bills have passed through the Senate and they have had their first reading in the House of Representatives but they have gone no further, because the government has refused to act on them.

A few weeks ago I was pleased to note that the cabinet finally decided that it was time to remove age discrimination from public sector employment. I intimated this to the parliamentary secretary's office and I am pleased to see that he has also drafted an amendment to achieve the same object. I suppose it is a case of who gets there first, but I want to place on record that it was my amendment, even if the representative of government gets up there first.

TALK.START.PARA: —We'll give you credit for it.

—That is very kind. In terms of the modification orders, part 29 of the SI(S) Act empowers the commissioner to grant exemptions from and to make modifications to certain provisions of the act and its regulations. This will enable the commissioner to quickly address problems as they arise and he may issue either a modification declaration or a temporary modification declaration. However, the latter will have no effect after 30 June 1996 and the subject matter of a temporary modification declaration order can only be retained after this date after it is legislated. It will be interesting to see how that applies in fact.

PARA.TAB: There is also the question of temporary modification to declaration No. 14, which generated some concern when it was released. This declaration allows the commissioner to consider the case in favour of a person who has received a minor conviction some years previously—for example, smoking pot at university—and who would therefore be unable to become a superannuation trustee, and determine, given the minor nature of the offence and the fact that any reasonable observer would conclude that the conviction is not relevant to the likelihood of the person acting imprudently and dishonestly in the future, that the `disqualified person' provisions should be waived. We do not disagree with that. Presumably, in many cases, the punishment has fitted the crime and a person should not be held accountable indefinitely.

On a related matter, I have, at various stages, raised the question of whether trustees should be paid. I think this is an area that needs further examination. In some cases they do receive small emoluments but overall there seems to be a tendency not to remunerate trustees except in terms of costs incurred. The problem I see is simply that we are now reaching a situation where some of the larger funds—CBUS and others—will have a million or more contributors and they will be controlling well in excess of $1 billion worth of assets.

In many respects the question of the training of trustees, and their overall fitness to conduct the operations, will be a matter of growing importance and significance. Therefore, I think there needs to be a serious examination of the trustee codes, with particular reference to the appointment of outsiders. At the moment, it is restricted so that the trustees must be people who have a direct association with the trust. There may well be a case in the future to consider the expansion of this concept. Just as we appoint experts as directors of companies, the same principle may well have to be applied when appointing trustees of super funds.

I turn now to the question of compliance audits. The bill requires trustees to arrange for an auditor to give the trustee a report of the operations of the fund in the approved form. This must include a statement by the auditor that the fund complies with certain provisions of the SI(S) Act and regulations. The bill enables the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to disqualify any auditor who fails to adequately and properly perform any of their SI(S) functions. The amendments also empower the commissioner to refer a matter to an auditor's professional association for appropriate disciplinary action. This amendment gives the commissioner an option, other than or in addition to a disqualification, to deal with auditors who in the commissioner's opinion have failed to carry out their duties. Relevant professional associations are also provided with a mechanism whereby they can reprimand auditors. These amendments ensure that auditors are more likely to do their job properly but, again, that remains to be seen.

It is terribly important to emphasise the fact that, to date, fortunately, there have not been any serious failures of superannuation funds. One would be taking an extraordinary risk if one was to assume that that situation will continue indefinitely. That is why the issues of fiduciary relationship and overall compliance are of fundamental importance. One of the issues, and the SI(S) Act establishes the framework to achieve this, is the need to ensure that the regulatory framework, which is essential for public confidence in superannuation, is applied as rigorously as possible while, at the same time, it does not create unnecessary difficulties for those who have to manage superannuation funds, with all the onerous responsibilities which they carry with them.

There has been considerable debate in recent times about trustees and fund managers. The Prime Minister has attacked fund managers, calling them `lemmings' and `donkeys' for failing to adopt a more adventurous approach to investment for superannuation funds. I foreshadow that I will be moving an amendment relating to these attacks.

Those attacks by the Prime Minister lie rather strangely with statements he has made over many years with regard to the management of superannuation funds. His attack has ignored a number of fundamental truths. Superannuation fund trustees have a fiduciary duty to fund members. They are accountable for forming an investment strategy that has regard to all aspects of the particular fund. Trustees have the sole responsibility of representing member interests and, consequently, fund managers who fail to perform are—and should be—sacked. But it is essential to remember that trustees are required to invest solely for the purpose of providing a retirement benefit for fund members, and fund members only.

Superannuation fund money is not a commodity or public asset, and there is neither a legal nor a moral right of control over superannuation assets by anyone other than fund members and their trustees. The `sole purpose' obligation of trustees under the SI(S) Act requires superannuation investments to be made only for the purpose of providing retirement benefits for fund members.

Any deflection therefore of superannuation investment from its primary purpose in order to achieve a social or any other worthwhile goal has the potential to negate the ability of superannuation to realise the retirement income policy objectives on which it is founded. Normal strategy is for trustees to give fund managers general directions. They invest in bonds, both domestic and overseas, in shares in Australian or overseas industries, resource stocks with a heavy emphasis on blue-chip stocks, cash for investment in the money market, and, more recently, in home mortgages.

Trustees normally give specific mandates for investment with heavy emphasis on protecting contributors. Fund managers endeavour to trade in Australian equities and to do better than the market. That is why there is a great emphasis on blue chips, which are also highly transferable and assist managers to keep management fees low.

The principal players and intermediaries in SMEs are the direct private investors, the so-called `business angels', institutional investors and the specialist intermediaries in SME based investments, for example, venture/development capital funds. These formal funds are dealing with other people's money and are therefore subject to fiduciary responsibilities, due diligence requirements and, in the case of the major institutional investors, prudential supervision by the ISC.

I noted the comment made by the parliamentary secretary about the fact that trustees and fund managers should be more adventurous; they should look for a spread of investments to small and intermediate investments. Again, it is fine to be able to stand up here in parliament and make those observations when you are not actually responsible for the outcome, when you do not actually have to face up to the trustees and explain why it was that your investments in SMEs or in investments other than blue chip did not return what you regard as an adequate level of benefit at that time. Unfortunately, the trustees do not see it necessarily in that light, even if they set the guidelines against which the investment policy should be based.

These `angels' that I referred to are dealing essentially with their own money. As a consequence, `angels' tend to rely on their own judgment, and are willing to invest in the earlier stages of SME development and small investment opportunities. However, the venture/development capital funds are forced by their higher cost structures to seek investments in excess of at least $1 million to $2 million and have moved increasingly towards latter stage investments which carry lower risk and less uncertainty.

In an article published in the April edition of Superfunds, it was suggested that the development capital industry is suffering from a lack of the type of information which gives trustees confidence in other investments. Development capital needs better long-term, consistent and independently researched data to reassure conservative trustees because development capital has some odd characteristics.

For example, development capital can be imprecise in terms of valuations. There can be frequent slowness in delivering financial returns in the early stages of investment. Trustees need to be reassured that this is not unusual and is still consistent with their initial expectation of superior risk adjusted returns. Scepticism about investment development capital is often related to the absence of signposts such as short-term performance figures or benchmarks which trustees have become used to in their dealings with more traditional asset classes.

One of the fundamental differences between investing in so-called blue-chip investments and investing in these more speculative areas is simply this. You can ring up, at a moment's notice, any reputable broker in Australia and they can give you a detailed analysis of all the major companies on the Australian Stock Exchange list. But, if you want to make investments in, as they say, more speculative areas, immediate information in most cases simply does not exist. One of the only sources you have is those companies or those brokers who were specifically involved in the launch of a new project, where there is often a tendency to gild lilies, to say the least.

There is quite clearly a fundamental difference in terms of the availability of accurate information upon which those financial judgments can be made which must be taken into account. Leaving aside the glib rhetoric from prime ministers or ministers here representing the government, it is not easy for a fund manager to make those decisions, because that is where the buck stops.

In this context, superannuation funds are also seeking investment opportunities in private investments, an asset class that includes infrastructure, development capital and direct investments in resources and other projects.

Let me give you an example of this. The largest investor company in Australia, as we know, is the AMP. It has committed $500 million to investment in infrastructure and has an additional $150 million from other funds. The AMP has also established a business development fund of $100 million to invest directly in unlisted small and medium enterprises. One can legitimately criticise $500 million or so in the overall total of the AMP's $36 billion of funds; it does seem to be rather low. Nevertheless, let us look at the breakdown of those funds. Under management the AMP has $12 billion invested in Australia equities, $3.2 billion in foreign equities, $6 billion in property, $7.3 billion in fixed interest, $1.8 billion in inflation index linked securities, $3.8 billion in cash and $1.7 billion in direct resource investments. This aggregate allocation reflects the individual asset allocation strategies applied in each of the separate funds managed by the AMP. In other words, a client can come in and explicitly say, `That is the range of investments I want,' and they can buy into a fund on that basis. Equally it follows that they have to accept the responsibility that the fund may or may not perform in accordance with expectations.
