I believe that the Prime Minister, and others who wish to speak rather loosely in this area, would do well to read the report of the private infrastructure task force, which points to the emergence of specialist infrastructure investment funds offering a spread of project risks, to the development of the inflation indexed bond market and to the first public listing of an infrastructure project, which was the M2 motorway in Sydney. Clearly there are going to be far more infrastructure projects in the future, and with all of these projects, as we understand how they operate and how they can be funded and so forth, there will be new opportunities arising both for information about them and to help trustees make decisions.

Finally in this particular context, a report from the National Investment Council entitled Financing growth, released in August of this year, noted that, while SMEs generate around 40 per cent of Australia's private sector output and account for about half of private employment, there are significant impediments which limit the effective flow of funds to SMEs. Rather than a shortage of capital for infrastructure investment, there is a shortage of projects which meet the hurdle rates of return and risk characteristics for suitable investments. So fundamentally we come back to that issue: can you get a better return from putting your money in blue chips, which are transferable almost at a moment's notice, or is it worth taking these additional risks in a quest for infrastructure investments and for other suitable investments?

The report found that only about 10 per cent of SMEs aspire to significant growth and only about 30 per cent of those are willing to take external equity. Furthermore, most growth firms seeking equity are not looking for investment. They are not `investment ready'—that is, they fail to meet fundamental requirements to be attractive to external investors. For instance, they have not separated their business and personal affairs, they depend on one key individual or they have not established a sustainable market niche. Many SMEs are not aware of what is required to be investment ready. In a recent BRW article entitled `Where none but angels dare to tread'—a very appropriate title—a financier stated that the problem has little to do with money but lies with the inability of the typical owner-manager of an SME to communicate, that business plans are often ineffective and that much of what is in them cannot be delivered.

Perhaps the point which also needs to be re-emphasised is that the evidence is quite clear that most small operators are seeking cheap borrowing capacity. They are not seeking equity. I repeat: they are not seeking equity. There needs to be a re-education at both ends of the spectrum, in terms of the SMEs so they understand that there are alternative forms of financing, including equity financing or partial equity financing, which should be looked at, as well as the issue of greater information in the hands of the trustees and the fund managers. Consequently, out of all of this, the National Investment Council recommended that SMEs must be assisted to become more investment ready.

A study conducted by Catalyst Investment Managers Pty Ltd, an established development fund manager, which was undertaken to test the feasibility of a regionally focused investment fund that would assist the growth of some 3,500-plus small and medium sized manufacturers in the greater western suburbs of Sydney—and I am sure that the parliamentary secretary will be well aware of this—highlighted a substantial demand for capital. However—and this is a point I have just made—most of the respondents favoured non-institutional sources of capital. Only 23 per cent would consider raising equity from an institutional source. Consequently, the question has to be asked: could the government do any better?

Three years ago the government launched the pooled development fund scheme as part of an economic package to pull the economy out of recession. Earnings from funds invested in a registered PDF would be taxed at a concessional rate, so we were told. To qualify, investment companies had to agree to invest the money they raised in small developing companies. But, sadly, it is fair to say that this scheme has not reached its expectations, nor would most people regard it as having been a success overall. The tax concession was too small and the constraints on the type of investments that PDFs could make in the scheme were clearly unattractive. Very few companies applied for PDF registration and, of those that did, many struggled to find funds.

Let us look at some of the solutions. Rather than directing members' funds or fiddling with tax concessions and making yet more radical changes to the superannuation system, the quality and diversity of superannuation investments would improve if member choice was extended. Ian Chalmers, in a paper entitled `Yours, mine or ours?: Is there a case for directed superannuation investment?' stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Beneficiary Investment Choice provides the option for individual fund members to select investment strategies most suited to their own circumstances, preferences and longer term retirement funding objectives. Within these constraints, the availability of BIC "social investment" options, provided they satisfy the fiduciary obligations of fund trustees, may facilitate an increased flow of investment capital to public benefit projects, without undermining the inalienable right of fund members to obtain the maximum economic return from the investment of their retirement saving.

In addition, funds which do not offer BIC fail to fully accommodate the differing risk/return requirements of their members. This inevitably exposes those well short of retirement to an investment approach of unnecessary (and ultimately costly) conservatism, or alternatively, those closer to retirement to investments of inappropriate volatility.

Furthermore, while accountability and reporting standards have improved, many fund members are denied the right to shift their savings from a fund with which they are dissatisfied to an alternative superannuation fund of their choice. This absence of choice prevents fund members from moving to a fund which complies with the members' particular requirements.

PARA.TAB: I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: "whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Prime Minister for his recent attacks on superannuation fund managers and notes that his vehemence has threatened public confidence in superannuation and the ability of trustees of superannuation funds to perform their functions".

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to contribute to the debate upon the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill before the House today. Superannuation is one of those issues which are very important to us all, and certainly to the broader Australian community. The bill has four main purposes, which have been well canvassed earlier by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott). Those purposes cover expanding the jurisdiction and improving the effectiveness of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal; transferring various modification orders made by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner into the body of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993; requiring audits of superannuation entities to cover compliance with certain provisions of the SI(S) Act and the regulations; and making other miscellaneous amendments to the SI(S) Act, the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993 and the Superannuation Entities (Taxation) Act 1987, amendments which are primarily aimed at improving the effectiveness and efficiency of those acts and the system of prudential supervision of the superannuation industry.

PARA.TAB: The financial impact of these proposed amendments, which totals approximately $980,000, would see the creation of a deputy chairperson and two part-time members for the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal, the introduction of a new case management system and further additional resources for the tribunal. These amendments will supplement the prudentially sound regulatory framework that this Labor government has put in place over the past 12 years as part of its development of a comprehensive national superannuation scheme. Since its election in 1983, the Labor government has radically transformed retirement savings in this country to a point where the comprehensive system now in place will, in the long term, increase retirement incomes and national savings. The work of this government is something of which Australians can be very proud, and I myself am certainly pleased to be part of that process.

Prior to 1983, as I am sure you would be well aware, superannuation was the preserve of a minority of Australians. The vast majority of Australian workers did not have access to superannuation to supplement their retirement incomes. This government, in pursuit of a fair and equitable retirement income policy for all Australians, has to a large extent remedied this situation through a number of key policy initiatives. The 1985 Accord with the ACTU played a pivotal role in this process, through a universal three per cent employer-provided superannuation benefit in lieu of an equivalent productivity based general wage rise. That is one point that is often forgotten in the superannuation debate. It was the workers themselves who actually started off their contribution with that three per cent, by forgoing a wage rise. I think we need to continue to remind some of those opposite that that contribution was made by the workers of this nation.

The award based superannuation system, which emanated from the subsequent national wage case decision in 1986, saw access to superannuation extended from a base of 39 per cent in 1983 to one of 72 per cent of employees by July 1991. To supplement the development of award based superannuation, the government introduced in the 1991 budget the superannuation guarantee, to further extend the coverage of superannuation for employees and to ensure compliance amongst employers in meeting their superannuation obligations to employees. The combination of award based superannuation and the superannuation guarantee has increased coverage to over 90 per cent of the Australian work force as at October 1995. Indeed, by the year 2002, under the superannuation guarantee schedule of rates, workers will receive an employer superannuation support equivalent to nine per cent of their salary.

When the honourable members opposite last sat on the Treasury bench, only 39 per cent of the work force was covered by superannuation. I think you would agree, Mr Deputy Speaker, that that is a damning indictment of the opposition's retirement income policy at that time. Clearly, it did not require the powers of a soothsayer to see the potential of superannuation in the future direction of retirement income and savings policy in Australia.

In the government's 1995-96 budget, further initiatives were put in place to build upon our comprehensive retirement income and national savings plan for the future. In this context, from 1997, variations to awards will see the introduction of employee contributions to superannuation paid out of future wage rises. Contributions amounting to three per cent of average weekly ordinary time earnings will be phased in over three years. This phasing-in period will reduce undue pressure on wages and cost and should see no discernible reduction in disposable income.

To complement the three per cent phased employee superannuation contributions, the government will match, dollar for dollar, employee contributions with direct payments to workers' superannuation accounts, by paying the second round of the One Nation tax cuts in this form. The matching payments will be capped at three per cent of average weekly ordinary time earnings, and a means test will gradually withdraw support to the salary in the range of up to $65,000 per annum. Consequently, by the year 2000, it is estimated that the government will be paying around $4.5 billion per year into the superannuation accounts of workers. By the year 2020, the government's superannuation plan will add $18 billion each year to the national savings. In this context, employees will be saving 15 per cent of their salary through superannuation contributions, which will result in higher retirement incomes in the long term and will certainly ensure that Australians are assured of a sound retirement—something that we all aim for in our later years.

At the present time, the Australian superannuation industry has assets of approximately $190 billion. This savings pool is a basis for the future expansion of this nation's economy, which will be critical if we are going to be able to compete in the international marketplace. We are all well aware of this government's commitment to that end, and certainly of the efforts of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) over the last week or so to ensure Australia's place, particularly in our own region, in an international marketplace. Over the next five years, by the year 2001, the combined effect of all the government's superannuation measures to date will boost national savings by an estimated two per cent of GDP, or $8.2 billion. It is estimated that the savings impact of superannuation by the year 2006 will be approximately $12.4 billion, or three per cent of GDP and, by the year 2021, four per cent of GDP, which will be $16.6 billion.

Under the government's current policy settings, superannuation assets are projected to increase tenfold in the next 25 years. This is a substantial savings pool in anybody's language. With workers' hard-earned savings being invested by superannuation funds to secure increased returns on their retirement savings, the government has, as I said earlier, put in place the regulatory framework to ensure that the funds operate in a prudentially sound manner. To this end, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill, which is before the House today, will add to the overall effectiveness of the legislation already enacted by this parliament.

The major amendments to the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 primarily encompass the audit requirements of superannuation entities, the application of Corporations Law provisions and the powers of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. Under the new amendments, key enhancements to audit requirements will provide for copies of audit certificates, rather than originals, to be provided to the commissioner when an annual return is lodged; for a statement of cash flows to be prepared for superannuation entities to allow auditors' reports to relate to more than the accounts and statements currently referred to in part 13; for the auditor's report to include the auditor's opinion on the compliance of the entity with specified provisions of the act and the regulations; and for clarification of the circumstances in which an auditor may be disqualified and in which an auditor or actuary must tell the trustee that they believe there is a contravention of the act or that the financial position of the entity is, or may become, unsatisfactory.

Complementing the amendments relating to the audit requirements of superannuation entities, elements of Corporations Law practice are also incorporated into the act. These include provision for the SI(S) Act to become consistent with the terminology relating to official management used in part 5.3A of the Corporations Law; the prohibiting of `disqualified persons' from being `responsible persons' of bodies corporate which are trustees, investment managers or custodians of superannuation entities, unless a waiver has been granted by the commissioner; and the requirement that all investments by superannuation entities be maintained on an arms-length basis.

In terms of the powers of the commissioner under the SI(S) Act, the amendments will provide for the commissioner to refer an actuary or auditor to a professional body for disciplinary action; for the commissioner to make an application to the court for an order to be made against a trustee for the protection of beneficiaries, without the need for an investigation, prosecution or civil proceedings to have begun; and for approved deposit funds with the consent of the commissioner to become regulated superannuation funds without losing their taxation concessions. Supplementing these changes to the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, the bill before the House today will also make a number of important amendments to the operation of the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993, which of course was put in place by the government to deal with complaints about the operation of the superannuation industry in a fair and equitable manner.

To this end the changes which flow from the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill will supplement the powers of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal in dealing with problems which are brought to its attention. In this context the key amendments will reinforce the powers of the tribunal by enabling the tribunal to review and make determinations in respect of insurance decisions relating to death and disability benefits and ensure they are provided through regulated superannuation funds.

The amendments will empower the tribunal to review life office conduct and decisions in relation to the sale and management of superannuation related annuity products, allow the tribunal to review decisions as to whether and to what extent a person is totally and permanently disabled, and provide for the appointment of a deputy chairperson and two additional part-time members to assist the tribunal in dealing with the increased volume and complexity of complaints which are expected as a result of these amendments.

Complementing these changes, amendments to both the Insurance Act 1973 and the Life Insurance Act 1973 will see the bodies corporate authorised to carry on insurance business and life insurance complaints being required to comply with determinations of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal through the modification of the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993.

You will agree, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the government's hard work in the area of superannuation has ensured that a whole new generation of Australians will have access to a superannuation system which is not only prudentially sound but one which will also ensure that they are going to be financially independent when they enter retirement. Indeed, if we believe what the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) has been saying in recent weeks, it would now seem that even the opposition parties have finally seen the light and are supportive of the government's superannuation policies.

But given that the coalition has previously described the government's superannuation policies as being vicious, mindless social and economic disasters, a confiscation of assets and a tax on jobs, one must wonder about their change in attitude. I have seen enough reports in the media over recent weeks to make me wonder whether they are really fair dinkum about what they are saying. I wonder whether they have really seen the light after all or whether it is just a cynical attempt to disguise a more sinister set of policies which would seek to dismantle the comprehensive national savings system we have put in place.

Australia has seen before what the coalition has managed to do when it talks about not dismantling things. Go back to the days of the Fraser government. Look what they promised about Medicare in those days. Have they got the same thing in mind for superannuation? Given the coalition's previous track record, the second of these scenarios would seem more likely. Indeed, if you look at the superannuation proposals floated by the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and the member for Higgins in relation to allowing the banks to directly compete in the superannuation marketplace, the effects upon the comprehensive system already in place would be deleterious to say the least.

Some of the comments by people in the media and people in the industry itself over recent weeks have been quite interesting. If the coalition were, unfortunately for the Australian people, ever to get hold of the Treasury bench again, then the criticisms that have come forward from a lot of the commentators about that would be quite interesting. On face value the proposals sound very nice and sound a very easy way to operate, but on close analysis it is seen that they really are flawed, and very much so.

Last Sunday I was reading the Queensland Sunday Mail, a paper that is not known to be one of the great supporters of the Labor government. I was reading Noel Whittaker's article. Noel Whittaker is a very highly regarded investment adviser and I have known Noel for many years. We actually worked in the same bank together at one stage. If I remember rightly, I bought a car from him, and an insurance policy. The headline of his article in the Sunday Mail was `Super policy has good and bad news'. The article said:

SPEECH.PARA: Last week we had the good and the bad news on superannuation.
Opposition Treasury spokesman Peter Costello released the Federal Coalition's "Approach to Superannuation".
I have already mentioned that. The article continued:

PARA.TAB: The good news is that it is going to leave the system almost unchanged. The bad news is it has endorsed those silly little investments called Retirement Savings Accounts (RSAs).
The notion of RSAs has been floated for years. The reasoning is that there are casual and low-paid workers who receive little compulsory superannuation—it gets eaten up by fees. . .

SPEECH.PARA: We all know about the banks with their fees. The article continued:

PARA.TAB: Instead of placing this money with funds managers it could go into special bank accounts styled RSAs and fees could be avoided. It may also appeal to those who see bank deposits as the only risk free-investment.

The fact is there is no such thing as a risk-free investment. For example, if you keep your money in bank accounts all your life you run the high risk the earnings on it will be insufficient to give you a decent retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Whittaker actually gives an example here. The article continued:
For example, two workers:

PARA.TAB: One invests $2,000 a year for 45 years at 4% in an RSA—

SPEECH.PARA: retirement savings account—
the other invests $2,000 a year at 9% in a normal super fund. The first ends up with $242,000, the second $1,052,000—
something like 75 per cent more—
That's the way compound interest works and that's the main reason RSAs won't work.
I commend Mr Whittaker for drawing this to the attention of the readers of the Sunday Mail. He continued:

PARA.TAB: The case against RSAs is so strong the all-party Senate Select Committee on Superannuation recommended they not be allowed.
In the judgment of that committee the returns would be so low that RSAs did not justify the tax concessions offered to superannuation funds.
Furthermore, the new regulations that prohibit fees, but not taxes, being taken from balances under $1000 mean there is now no need to design a fee-free vehicle for small balances.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, that is another initiative taken by this government, and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) was instrumental in that legislation. I congratulate him on that. Mr Whittaker then went on a bit further in the same article to simply tear apart any notion along that line.

PARA.TAB: I turn quickly to the other points the coalition was talking about in regard to allowing banks into superannuation. At first glance, that makes a lot of sense too but, on the other side of the coin, banks are already into that field through their own subsidiaries and there is no real need to go down that path. If those sorts of funds were in the banking system, they would all be subject to the normal bank lending criteria and they would not come under the control that is offered by the protection of the superannuation industry that we are debating today, a protection further enhancing the safety of members' funds.
The Australian Institute of Superannuation Trustees probably summed it up best in an information paper it prepared where it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The banks' drive to gain access to Australia's growing pool of superannuation savings is a matter of great public concern. Their success would put at risk many of the protections which seek to make superannuation operate for the benefit of workers who contribute to it.

When the member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) was speaking earlier about his amendment, which I reject out of hand and I know the government does as well, he chose to attack the Prime Minister for trying to encourage some fund managers to invest more wisely in this country. The honourable member's suggestion that it is the members' funds that we should be considering really makes a joke of what he is saying in his amendment because the risk is found in the opposition's own proposed policies. It is important that funds are invested and that the risk is spread. That is what the Prime Minister has been trying to encourage a lot of Australian investors to do. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer to only one matter raised by the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), that is, where he referred to Mr Noel Whittaker's column. One thing to remember about Mr Whittaker is that he is a professional adviser whose income derives from advising people how to invest their funds. If RSAs became part of the total retirement income scheme of things, Mr Whittaker would not be in a position to make much money out of them. He said in his column that RSAs were to be deplored and he gave an interesting example. He quoted a return of four per cent on an RSA and compared that with nine per cent in a super fund. Blind Freddy knows that if you are going to get four per cent on an RSA it is not going to match nine per cent in a super fund, except that, if you look at the super funds these days, they are not returning four per cent after Labor's up-front 15 per cent tax. They are going backwards in many cases and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott) knows it. I have recorded some typical examples in Hansard in other contexts.

PARA.TAB: We have this nonsense from Mr Whittaker. The honourable member for Oxley had the cheek to refer to fees the banks charge. Have a look at the fees the super funds charge. Super fund charges would make anyone blush, and to say bank fees are bad—by God! The super funds more than outmatch them in that regard.

The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill was introduced into the chamber on 19 October, 1995. It sets out to amend four principal acts, namely the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act of 1993, the SI(S) Act, the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Act 1993, the S(RC) Act, the Superannuation Entities (Taxation) Act 1987, the SE(T) Act, the Insurance Act 1973 and the Life Insurance Act 1995.

As the explanatory memorandum points out, the bill has four main aims. The first of those is to expand the jurisdiction and improve the effectiveness of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. The second involves the transfer of various modification orders made by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner, briefly known as the commissioner in my later remarks, into the body of the SI(S) Act. Then come the provisions which intend to require audits of the superannuation entities to cover compliance with certain provisions of the SI(S) Act and the regulations and, fourth and last, provision to make other miscellaneous amendments to the SI(S) Act, the S(RC) Act and the SE(T) Act, primarily aimed at improving the effectiveness and efficiency of those acts and the system of prudential supervision of the superannuation industry.

We are told the financial impact of the bill will result in an increase in outlays of approximately $1 million. The proposed amendments provide for the creation of a deputy chairperson and two part-time members of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. In a full year the cost of these positions is estimated to be about $270,000 of which about $223,000 will be for salary or in the form of salary related costs.

Also, we are informed, a resource bill will, as required, be brought forward for consultation with the Department of Finance in the additional estimates progress. The full year costs of this bid are expected to be of the order of $500,000, of which $340,000 would be for salary or for salary related expenditure. Further one-off costs, including a new case management system, would add a further $210,000.

Clause 42 of schedule 4 of the bill requires trustees to arrange for an auditor to give the trustee a report of the operations of the fund in an approved form. An approved form must include a statement by the auditor that the fund complies with certain provisions of the SI(S) Act and regulations.

A trustee who intentionally or recklessly fails to make the necessary amendments will become liable to a penalty of up to two years imprisonment. An auditor who intentionally or recklessly fails to provide the report by the prescribed time will be liable to a penalty of up to six months imprisonment. Clauses 65 and 66 of schedule 4 of the bill enable the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to disqualify any auditor who fails to adequately and properly perform any of their assigned SIS functions.

The amendments also empower the commissioner to refer a matter to an auditors' professional association for appropriate disciplinary action. I would have thought that, rather than prison terms, that might have been the best way to go. But these amendments aim to ensure that auditors are more likely to do their job properly, I suppose—and so they should. I would have thought that auditors would be professional enough to meet their obligations and perform audits in a professional manner which meets the requirements of the SI(S) Act without the threat of penalties, including imprisonment. However, this amendment should provide a bit of stick to ensure that auditors do meet their obligations.

Part 29 of the SI(S) Act empowers the commissioner to grant exemptions from and make modifications of certain provisions of the act and its regulations. This power enables the commissioner to quickly address problems as they arise. The commissioner may issue either a modification declaration or a temporary modification declaration. However, I understand that the latter will have no effect after 30 June 1996. The subject matter of a temporary modification declaration order can only be retained after 30 June 1996 if it is legislated.

Incorporating these declarations within the act also provides an opportunity for me to comment on the subject matter. For the S(RC) Act, the amendments expand the jurisdiction of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal, the SCT, to consider medical evidence if the decision to which the complaint relates was made on or after 1 November 1994. Previously there was a concern that the SCT would be swamped by complex conflicting medical opinion, which would be difficult to resolve. A regulation was drafted to limit the hearing of medical disputes by the SCT, but this was disallowed in the Senate in September last year. It was disallowed, I understand, because it was felt that people with disabilities should have access to a low cost dispute mechanism.

The government changed its position in October 1994 to allow the SCT to be able to handle medical complaints from 1 May 1995, following consultations with interested parties about possible approaches. However, this matter was thrown into some confusion after the High Court ruled on the Brandy case. The Brandy decision has had only a very minimal impact on the operations of the SCT because, unlike the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, the HREOC, the SCT does not have enforcement powers, nor does it set out to usurp judicial powers. It is hard to believe that the powers of the HREOC remained unchallenged for so long. It is very clear that the Boilermakers case of 1956 set a precedent, and led to the splitting of the Arbitration and Conciliation Court into the Arbitration Commission, now the IRC, and the industrial division of the Federal Court, now the Industrial Relations Court.

The High Court held in its Brandy decision that judicial power is to be only exercised by courts and bodies established and constituted under the constitution. The nub of judicial power is that it involves the determination of existing rights. It is not, however, an exercise of judicial power to create new rights. There is a potential jurisdictional problem with the SCT, so this bill amends section 14(2) of the S(RC) Act to remove `in excess of the powers of the trustee' and `was an improper exercise of the powers of the trustee' as grounds on which a complaint may be made to the SCT.

In October 1994, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer indicated that legislation would be expedited to ensure the SCT had jurisdiction to deal with complaints involving life insurance superannuation products. The bill inserts a new subsection 14A(1), which enables a person who has an interest in a life policy fund to complain to the SCT that the decision of the trustee to admit the person to the fund was unfair or unreasonable.

This has the effect of allowing people who have suffered misconduct, such as misrepresentation from life office agents, to obtain redress. The tribunal will be able to hear only such complaints as relate to those who are admitted to a fund on or after the day on which this bill receives the royal assent. Consumers with complaints made prior to that date can access the Life Insurance Complaints Board.

The Life Insurance Federation of Australia has made the valid criticism that this bill provides that only products sold by life insurance companies and their agents are covered by this method of redress. There is no equivalent right to complain to the tribunal where there is misconduct associated with non-life insurance superannuation products.

For example, superannuation unit trusts operated by financial organisations, such as the Bankers Trust, will not be covered by the SCT. Their products are not sold by agents, but are usually sold by independent financial planners of the ilk of the columnist to whom I referred earlier. This effectively means that any amendment to extend coverage of the SCT to other financial organisations will need further, wide ranging amendments.

I am led to believe that the government intends, provided an election does not intervene, to introduce amendments next year if it is still in government. It might even go ahead after that election. But, no doubt, come the election of the coalition the ISC will still be proposing the amendments. In any event, these future amendments are most likely to receive bipartisan support.

The bill also makes amendments to both the Insurance Act 1973 and the Life Insurance Act 1995, requiring general insurance companies and life offices to comply with determinations of the tribunal. The commissioner will be able to apply to the Federal Court for an injunction where determinations have been flouted.

The bill provides for the addition of a deputy chairperson and two part-time members of the tribunal. However, clause 16 amends subsection 8(1) of the S(RC) Act to provide that a person who has reached 65 years of age cannot hold office as the deputy chairperson. That seems to be in breach of what we understand to be the anti-discrimination objectives shared by both sides of the parliament. As far as I am concerned, this age discrimination should be removed from the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have foreshadowed that.

—I accept that and I thank the parliamentary secretary. Of course, this measure would have contradicted the government's stated intention to abolish the compulsory retirement age for Commonwealth public servants.

PARA.TAB: The superannuation industry has been in the news recently, with the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) attacking the large superannuation funds. What has he been saying? Many things. According to the Prime Minister, fund managers are wine-quaffing donkeys and lemmings. Why would this be so, in the twisted mind of our dear Prime Minister?

Essentially, the Prime Minister is critical because the funds are perceived by him as having too short an outlook, and because they are not prepared to put money into smaller firms and infrastructure projects. To some degree, the Prime Minister is right. It is a fact that the superannuation funds charge too much by way of charges and fees. Their outlook is too short. Some people even believe the super funds are parasitic, bloodsucking leeches.

If only it were that simple. We should ask ourselves why the super funds behave the way they do. For a start, super funds have a fiduciary responsibility to their members to maximise their returns. This is their primary motivation, and we should not lose sight of that. But, just as importantly, it is this government which has created the environment in which the super funds operate. It is this government which has constantly changed the regulatory framework that the super funds have had to keep pace with.

EMPHASIS.TAB: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 2.21 p.m. to 5.30 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the government which constantly changes the regulatory framework which the super funds have to keep pace with and meet the compliance costs of, and they have to attempt to predict which changes the government will make next. It is small wonder then that the super funds take the shorter view. To adopt a longer investment schedule requires a degree of stability, predictability and certainty which simply is not available under the present regime. They are practices which Labor simply has not facilitated.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that the government saw fit to spend $12.5 million—

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 5.31 p.m. to 5.43 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is instructive to note that the government has undertaken a $12.5 million advertising campaign to promote its superannuation system. How can such an education campaign be taken seriously when the government has to reassure all workers who contribute to its compulsory superannuation that their money is well invested in a sound system that will provide them with a blissful retirement? Laura Tingle in the Australian of 24 October put it aptly when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: Keating's resentment against the big investment institutions reflects Labor's increasing frustration that the much-touted, magic superannuation wand has not delivered the manna to workers that has now been promised for a decade.
She went on:
And as the opposition quite rightly put to the Prime Minister in question time: why put donkeys in charge of compulsorily invested life savings?
Further she said:

But one thing worth remembering in all the noise we are likely to hear about superannuation is that the big powers in superannuation now are the industry funds—established by Labor itself—rather than the institutions like AMP who simply manage their money.

Now the Prime Minister is talking about more changes to the system and attacking the very fund managers whom we are supposed to have so much faith in. Many superannuation funds have been poor performers, as we all know. Poor performing fund managers do not deserve their big salary packages. Competition in the industry is essential if the in-built overheads of the large super funds are to be reduced and better returns paid to fund members.

PARA.TAB: The government should also be brought to account for its use of superannuation as a milch cow to try to plug our structural budget deficit. If the up-front, 15 per cent Labor tax on employers' contributions was reduced or abolished, superannuation accounts would be able to provide something like reasonable retirement benefits.

The government needs to seriously evaluate what it wants to do with superannuation because to date Labor's policies in this area have been simply ad hoc. In fact, they please very few people except the union movement whose leaders now get to play with the retirement dollars of hundreds of thousands of Australian workers. Given the events of the past week and the union movement's demonstrated lack of faith in the Hawke-Keating regime, even a Labor government may come to rue the day it gave the power that goes with the control of huge super funds to its former mates among the union bosses. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to participate in the debate on the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, because there have been numerous amendments made by the government to superannuation over a long period of time and it is getting quite irritating for the opposition to have an endless, seemingly unconnected series of decisions made on superannuation.

PARA.TAB: The fact that discretionary savings are falling and savings are being pushed, in a non-discretionary way, into compulsory savings processes is something that many Australians resent. It has brought about a situation wherein the savings and superannuation policy of this government has reduced national savings from 24.1 per cent—the rate when they came to office—to 16.3 per cent. They have driven down, in fact, the commitments made to savings by our fellow Australians.

The lack of confidence in markets has been, perhaps, a reason for it. The behaviour of some of our `entrepreneurs' may be another reason. But I suspect that the real reason is a lack of confidence in the whole process of superannuation, and that it is a lack of confidence in Australia's future that is discouraging people from saving.

There is a further factor. It is the psychological impact of a compulsory superannuation system whereby people are compelled to save or their employers are compelled to save for them. People think that that is enough. They think they have done enough: `Whatever the government requires is enough savings for us. We have got a compulsory process in place and, therefore, we do not have to make any additional effort.'

On top of that is the appalling mismanagement of the whole economy that the government has shown. That really has put so much pressure on Australian families that not only do they have less disposable income, but they also have greatly diminished discretionary savings.

So it is a combination of the poorly managed economy, uncertainty about jobs and uncertainty about commitments to flexible payouts such as mortgage rates on housing—where we have seen, over the last two or three years, people suddenly hit for huge increases in their weekly payouts to keep their mortgages covered. It is all of those things: the unexpected rises in mortgage rates, the compulsory savings program of the government through superannuation, the lack of certainty about Australia's future, and the inclination of Australians to not save when there is such strong economic pressure on them and such uncertainty about their own futures and the futures of their family members in regard to employment and employment opportunities.

To look at the underlying factors that have produced this process, one has only to look at the government's inflationary policy, which is very hard to assess and predict. The government's inflationary policy was supposed to retain inflation in the band of two to three per cent. It is over that right now; in real terms it is 3.1 per cent. Underlying inflation has hit 3.1 per cent and the headline rate is now 5.1 per cent. So there is a discouragement, straight away, because the cost of living is going ahead of the pace at which people can keep up.

At the same time, the government has no monetary policies that would encourage a belief that there is going to be a fall in interest rates. In fact, the International Monetary Fund has said to the government, `Do not dare manipulate interest rates down before the next election.' Now, to my knowledge, that is the first time the International Monetary Fund has come in and given a directive to an Australian government. The fund has made the comment that we should not reduce interest rates, artificially or in any other way, before an election unless there are the economic circumstances that will force interest rates down. I think it is a tragedy that we have this international body starting now to intervene in the Australian economy. It is all the work of the Australian Labor Party and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The next step, of course, if there is increased certainty, will be that they will take over the total management of the economy.

So the uncertainty of the fall in interest rates produced by the government's monetary policy is something that is of deep concern to many Australians. Most Australians do not understand the Labor Party's tax policy. They do not know what they are going to be hit for next because this has been a government of big grabs in taxation. This has been the government that has said, `We are not going to have a goods and services tax,' but which, as soon as it could possibly do it, after the last elections, instigated a widespread, far-reaching wholesale sales tax which bumped up the price of goods and services. It is built into nearly everything. It is built into transport, packaging and the whole box and dice. In fact, food is taxed currently.

The spread and the change in taxation, and the uncertainty in the taxation policy, are factors that are working against the community's preference to save. There is no micro-economic reform policy that is worth thinking about. It does not affect many people but it does mean that the built in costs and the overheads of day-to-day living are not declining, but increasing. All of these factors, which are built into the government's assessment of the economy, have worked to have the government rely solely on the superannuation industry for its method of creating a savings environment in Australia. It is far too narrow.

No person in Australia would know more about superannuation policy and savings policy than my colleague the member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). He has put much of his time in parliament into the development of policies. It is a privilege to pay tribute to the work that he has done. The government keeps picking up the ideas of my colleague but, at this point, it is about five years behind him.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have kept him in parliament.
—That is interesting that the member should say that. But the government is five years behind the proposition that—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—It is the tradition of this chamber that we do not have disputes on any matter before the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is complete unanimity here!
—No, I tell the honourable member for Mitchell that, as I tell the other two members present, and that stands.
—Thank you. We are following your advice to the letter.
—They are rules, not advice.
—We are on the same wavelength though; we believe that David should stay.

—And I know that Mr Deputy Speaker does also, but I cannot speak for him. The fact is that, as we are well aware, the government's processes, its whole policy framework and its whole attitude towards superannuation have proved disastrous for many Australians. Let me reiterate that the massive decline in savings has meant that the government has borrowed overseas, and then, when it was criticised for that, it got more into the Australian market and borrowed more expensive money from Australia, but a smaller amount is available because much of it is no longer saved. The government is forcing up interest rates on the Australian domestic market because of the money that it needs to borrow. Everything that this government does seems to work against its proposals for savings. It goes and sticks taxes on top of something that it is trying to encourage. I think it is the weirdest thing the government has ever done. We are going to have a positive program of encouraging people to save—
—They are making the poor poorer.

—As my colleague says, it makes the poor poorer, then it goes and taxes them. It forces them to save and then it goes and taxes them for saving. There are itinerant fruit pickers and some other itinerant workers—TAFE teachers are a classic—working for short periods at different times through the week or through the year, depending on the course. Compulsory savings are going out of their super. You do not know what to do because those small amounts decline by the imposition of taxation and charges made by superannuation funds. Eventually, of course, the people involved notionally finish up owing the superannuation funds money for looking after their accounts.

PARA.TAB: My colleague the member for Bradfield has got some great processes to overcome that. He has enunciated them. I just happen to have in front of me a speech made by the shadow Treasurer, the member for Higgins (Mr Costello), in which he talks about the processes that can be used for these small amounts, particularly for women who may have an intermittent work history. He talks about retirement savings accounts. I think it is a real innovation and is something that Australians will welcome, where they can add into the same account successive amounts. In contrast with the current system, the money does not have to be directed into a multiplicity of funds all over the countryside so that when a person finishes their working life, maybe after 40 years work, they cannot even remember who was responsible for deducting their first compulsory superannuation. They do not know what fund they stuck that into. They can hardly remember what job they were doing at the time. You have got these scattered funds being used up by superannuation funds all over the country, of no benefit to anybody and certainly not meeting the government's objectives as far as retirement is concerned.

We have got this alternative and it is going to be something that I think is going to warm the hearts of many Australians. It is sensible, it is modest, it gives them an advantage and it allows them to set funds aside over a long period of time for their retirement. It is something like a bank account rather than a superannuation fund in the strict sense, but the concessions are there and the opportunities are there. It is going to provide incentive for people to save, unlike what the government is doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tax office takes it on for you.

—No way. The disgusting idea of thinking those people in the Australian Taxation Office are suddenly going to turn themselves into beneficent investors on behalf of their clients! I have never heard anything so ridiculous. Most people that I know, especially in the small business community around western Sydney, generally have a good relationship with the tax office, but occasionally there are problems. I do not think there is any more disliked group in our community than tax officers applying the rigours of the law over-enthusiastically. That is the image that the Australian community tends to have of people in the Australian Taxation Office, as people who are rigorous in the application of the law, people who are relentless in pursuing the government's dollars, people who have a charge direct from the Prime Minister to rip out of the community every dollar that they can possibly get.

PARA.TAB: To think of that group of people as being kindly disposed towards savers, kindly disposed towards understanding the money markets and investment and kindly disposed towards the ultimate retirement of people is absolutely unlikely, because it is the government's own proposal that on retirement you are taxing the superannuation funds. That never used to happen but you are doing it. I am not saying that we are going to remove it—you are so far down the track into taxing things that it is very difficult for an incoming government to make too many changes to unscramble the massive grab for money that you guys have gone into.

I have spoken in general terms on superannuation but I would just like to spend a little time covering the specific legislation. The superannuation industry has expressed its comments about the jurisdiction to hear superannuation complaints involving all intermediaries, including life brokers and their representatives and security dealers and their proper authority holders. The industry recognises that there need to be some changes to supervision processes, but we understand that there is no clear-cut view. I think the attitude here is that nobody likes increased rigour in supervision but, if there is a reasonable argument, let us try it. But the government needs to be flexible enough to wind back the supervisory processes if they are too onerous.

The main purposes of this legislation are to expand the jurisdiction and improve the effectiveness of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal. I guess that is reasonable in that there are a lot of complaints about the performance of funds, and I understand that. But with increased flexibility in retirement packages being offered and a greater range of opportunity for retirement savings, I think some of these complaints will vanish as people start to select the type of retirement package that best suits their circumstances, whether they be male or female, full-time or part-time worker, salary or wage earner. The government has failed to do that because it has a prescriptive approach. It is the coalition's view that, provided people are saving for their retirement, as we offer more flexibility the complaints that we currently see against funds will tend to diminish.

Other purposes of this legislation are the transferring of various modification orders made by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner into the body of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act, requiring audits of superannuation entities to cover compliance with certain provisions of the act, and the making of other miscellaneous amendments primarily aimed at improving the effectiveness and efficiency of superannuation legislation and the system of prudential supervision of the superannuation industry.

Having said that we need greater supervision, let me make a few comments about the Prime Minister because I think he provides a very suitable place to finish my comments on superannuation. Here is the member of parliament who is the first among all ministers and the person who did the deal on superannuation. Here is the man who went into the tax summit saying that there would be no tax on superannuation and came out with a tax on superannuation. Here is the man who said that we must have a savings regime for Australia.

Here is the man who did the deal with the superannuation funds and gained the support of those great financial institutions, election after election, as they promised and could see additional money flowing into their coffers. Not one of these great institutions was critical, or has ever been critical, of something the government has done. They have played the government's game very effectively because they have seen, and have been encouraged to believe, that there will be an increasing flow of funds into their coffers and they will have an enhanced opportunity to invest in Australia.

Here is the Prime Minister who engineered, encouraged and devised this program. And this same Prime Minister who has charged those very people with the responsibility of looking after the funds of all of the workers in Australia—whether they be in the building, metal trades or any trade union driven superannuation fund, or in the larger, more amorphous funds—is now saying to every member of those funds, `You have got donkeys looking after your investment.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Or lemmings.

—Yes—lemmings charging over the cliff at the latest fad. I cannot believe that we have a Prime Minister who, having devised a program over a period of five or six years, legislated to put it in place, instigated and then been instrumental in the establishment of the Superannuation Insurance Commission as a supervisory body, comes through and says, `I have taken your hard-earned cash—the proceeds of the deal that I did with the ACTU, the wage increases you had to forgo, the l-a-w law tax cuts that have not arrived—and we are going to put it into super funds on your behalf. But, by the way, the people who are managing those funds are donkeys.'

PARA.TAB: It is often interesting that people, from time to time, when talking about retirement income policies, turn to what is happening in Singapore with the Central Provident Fund, where quite large percentages of income are placed in a superannuation type fund. For contributions for workers up to 55 years, it is 40 per cent—20 per cent contributed by the employee and 20 per cent by the employer. This is a large pool of money. As one of the aims of the fund they say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government helps by exempting CPF earnings from tax and guaranteeing payment of CPF savings. We—
that is the CPF—

on our part will, where we can, make our assets and services available to help meet Singapore's social and economic objectives, thereby improving the quality of life of all Singaporeans and CPF Members.

If we are going to have criticism of what the funds are doing with their investments, it has got to be seen that it is in that context. It is in a context that we now have these pools of investment greatly developing in size and that it is quite right for the community and the government to enter into a discussion about how we might best place those funds.

PARA.TAB: In question time today there was a reference to a speech made by Minister Sciacca yesterday, perhaps again attempting to misconstrue slightly the way in which he put his comments about the potential that can be achieved with appropriate investment. I would just like to refer to his speech. He was talking to trustees about the bill that this piece of legislation amends, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The act is there to protect you—
the trustees—
and the savings of working Australians from outside influences which could comprise the direction of your financial investments.
He went on to say:
This includes the government of the day. Despite the odd rumour that gets legs, this government has no intention of directing investments.
He then went on to say:

Having said that, all of us in government experience the frustration of seeing the dollar value of super funds build up as a direct result of government policy, yet see example upon example of young Australian companies and Australian ideas going offshore because long term venture capital is difficult to attract domestically.
Later in his speech he said:
We have to develop a better understanding of emerging small and medium sized enterprises. Some will be too risky but we should judge them through knowledge of their operation, not ignorance.
Further—this was perhaps what was perceived to be the most controversial—he said:

Likewise established Australian firms have an obligation, in my view, as offshore loans are being renegotiated from time to time, to package those loans in such a way as to make it financially attractive for domestic super funds to purchase that debt and keep the interest payments in Australia rather than going to Asia, Europe or the Americas.

So who was his message for? His message was for those Australian firms when renegotiating offshore loans. That seems a very laudatory comment to be made as a contribution to a very important debate. He then said:

If we do our job well, creatively, boldly, while still protecting the accruing retirement income of working Australians, then I am sure this will occur. There is little point of creating a new national savings pool if in the end it simply means we add wealth to our competitors overseas.

One of the real problems is that, when we have the debates and there is some form of suggestion that we might be trying to influence, indicate, `direct' the way in which superannuation fund managers look at their investments, it is thought, `Here we go, it is capital "I" intervention.'

PARA.TAB: I will admit that I do not shy away from saying that government should intervene where appropriate. I am quite happy to be labelled an interventionist. It continually saddens me that, when we talk about whether governments should get involved in investment schemes, from time to time the performance of the Victorian state government is raised in connection with this debate. If it is—to use the example of some of the things that occurred in the time of the VEDC in Victoria—that we are then to scuttle what is basically a good idea, I reject that.

There were many things that happened during that era in Victoria that should not have happened, but there were many great successes. Some of those successes include organisations such as AMRAD. With the number of medical institutions and Victorian universities that were involved in biotechnology, the Victorian Labor government of the time wondered why it was that, when any of these ideas were to be developed, such institutes had to go offshore. So it decided to set up a mechanism to ensure that those things could be developed onshore for the benefit of Australia.

I know that it is a problem to grab desperately at one good example when people trot out a whole host of bad examples. But the problem in Victoria was that decisions about appropriate investments were made without the context of appropriate industry policies. I admit that one of the first cornerstones that we have to see, before we try to influence the way in which managers make their investment decisions by giving them alternatives and procedures that will enable them to go forward into those areas that I have spoken about, is that this should happen in the context of proper industry policy.

Another unfashionable thing to do in debate is to refer to Australia reconstructed, a tripartite report of several years ago and one of the many reports that from time to time end up gathering a great deal of dust on the bookshelf. Because it took the Scandinavian model, it is pooh-poohed around the place at the moment, but it still has a great deal of relevance and is something which Australia might revisit and have a look at. Australia reconstructed talked about national development funds and about portions of the developing superannuation funds perhaps being directed towards such a fund. Its recommendation No. 1.5 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Increased investment must therefore be `led' and industry policy is a principal vehicle for `leading' investment. Governments should not only deliver the correct macroeconomic environment, but also complement this with an aggressive and comprehensive (sectoral-specific) trade and industry development strategy, a network of `active' labour market and training programs and a set of comprehensive supporting policies.

That is a suggestion that should be revisited, so that we can open up different options for the trustees. In his second reading speech earlier today, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer said:

In many cases, trustees retain fund managers to invest superannuation money. The government considers that fund managers need to find ways to invest in a broader range of businesses, rather than concentrating their equity investments on blue-chip stocks. For example, fund managers should consider placing a portion of their investments in small, innovative businesses. This will potentially yield better returns for investors, as well as contributing to the economic wellbeing of all Australians.

I reject the basis of the second reading amendment. I welcome the fact that the Prime Minister has engendered a bit of debate about this matter and I welcome the comments that Minister Sciacca made yesterday and the comments that the parliamentary secretary has made in his second reading speech. Obviously, speaking just as a backbencher of the government party, I wish we were going further. I do not mind doing that. We have the potential to be small `i' interventionist in a whole host of ways that will contribute to the overall economic and social wellbeing of Australia as a nation.

PARA.TAB: The second matter I flagged that I wished to raise concerns some of the real problems that we might have with inequity of the present system. I refer to a paper by Alison McClelland and Peter Davidson from the Brotherhood of St Laurence who have raised a number of the matters that I have had some concern with over a long time. I think that these are things that, as we continue to develop our superannuation policy, we should keep having a look at so that we can best direct a successful superannuation system over time. In their paper, they said:

SPEECH.PARA: The combined impact of tax assistance for superannuation and the proposed new government contribution is to exacerbate rather than reduce their inequities.
They indicate that:

. . . there can be little doubt that the compulsory superannuation, at the point of contribution, will have a greater adverse impact on the disposable incomes of low income earners than on those earning above average incomes. Low income earners are much less likely to be saving through superannuation already and much more likely to need all their income for current expenditure.
Whilst I do not totally share their doom and gloom, because I think that at some stage you have got to break into the system and make a conscious decision, I recognise that these are problems.

PARA.TAB: I have spoken also in the past about the way we deal with the taxation of contributions—that it does give higher income earners a greater deal of benefit than it does at the lower end. As I said, I support the compulsory superannuation scheme because it has given greater access to superannuation to lower income earners and it is an entree into the system. But as the amounts of money that are being put into the funds on behalf of individuals become greater, perhaps we will have to look at some of the options that are displayed in some of the overseas schemes.

Yesterday in his speech to the trustees, Minister Sciacca went to the notion that is being revisited by the coalition that perhaps we could open up some of the individuals' superannuation funds to be used for housing deposits. As Minister Sciacca said, this is something that the government had a look at and has decided not to proceed with. He quite rightly indicated in his speech that—if you use the example of Singapore again—because there is a combined 40 per cent contribution between the employer and employee in Singapore it allows workers to draw on super for housing deposits, education, top-up parental retirement incomes and the like.

Whilst rejecting them at this stage on the basis, as the minister has put it, that we are really talking about chalk and cheese in the size of the funds, these are something that McClelland and Davidson have talked about in their paper and described as `life cycle' savings. Now that has some element of the Singapore scheme in that there is a guaranteed part of their provident fund pool that is set aside most definitely for the retirement income aspects, but there are other parts of the pool that allow use of the funds by the individuals and the families for housing, for the education of their children, for topping up their parents' retirement income and for investing in other forms of investment—some forms of shares, et cetera—to top up their potential retirement income.

It may be, as our superannuation scheme develops, and as we have large amounts being set aside for individuals, that we recognise that there are differing pressures on families at different stages of the families' development and that we could, as the amounts of money involved get larger, in a sense, be able to give alternatives for the families. As has been said often, we are talking at the moment about very small amounts. To toy with giving these choices that would allow the families to move these small amounts in and out would not mean that the totality of the overall funds would not continue to grow and continue to be of a size such that we can make worthy investments on a national scale.

As I said, I do not wish to be misconstrued, because the present compulsory superannuation scheme of this government has my full support. It is something that forms a very solid base and I believe that, if we look at it carefully and look at it in appropriate fashion, it can be made even stronger.

TALKER.NAME: Mr GEAR
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me thank all those who took part in the debate on the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 today. There are a few summing up points that I have got.

PARA.TAB: First of all, on super fund investments, we agree with opposition speakers that trustees—not fund managers, not the government and, thankfully, not the coalition—are responsible for fund investment strategies. We stand by the views of the government and would like to see more imaginative investments by funds.

I am told that the member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) outlined some of the difficulties that small business has in raising capital. That has been discussed widely around this place for a long time. I can tell him that the government will be setting out its plans to address this issue in the forthcoming innovation statement. That will spell out what we are doing. You might learn something if you get a copy; we will send you a copy.

I turn to the complaints about the super tribunal and its jurisdiction. Some members have raised the question of the Superannuation Complaints Tribunal's jurisdiction over sales of non-life public offer super products. As an indication of the government's good faith on this issue, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission is already preparing a discussion paper canvassing the options.

On superannuation policy generally, we note that the opposition, of course, has done an about-face on superannuation. It was the worst thing in the world when we brought it in. When we raised it to 15 per cent, you would have thought the sky had fallen in. But now, all of a sudden, it is their policy too.

As with the FBT, capital gains tax and Medicare—everything we have brought in—it is a case of `Me too!' It is always `Me too!', and here it is on superannuation policy as well. At the next election, the voters will have a real choice. There is the Labor government, which has been setting up these superannuation policies and schemes to boost retirement incomes and look after national savings, and the coalition, which just says, `Me too!' but in the past has never done anything other than give a tax break to the wealthy.
With those few words, I commend the bill to the House.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. As an amendment to this, the honourable member for Bradfield has moved that all words after `That' be omitted, with a view to substituting other words. The immediate question is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.
Question unresolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —As it is necessary to resolve this question to enable further questions to be considered in relation to this bill, in accordance with standing order 277 the bill will be returned to the House for further consideration.

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 27 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALKER.NAME: Mr GEAR
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill amends the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992—the principal act. The primary purpose of the bill is to amend the principal act to remove certain restrictions on the restructuring of ownership of projects eligible for the development allowance so that a more consistent approach is available to the various types of prospective applicants for the development allowance.

PARA.TAB: Where all other criteria in the principal act were met, these amendments would allow the transfer of the development allowance benefit where ownership of a project was transferred to another entity after application for the development allowance but before registration.

Secondly, the amendments would allow the transfer of the development allowance benefit where ownership of a project was transferred from one entity structure to another type of entity structure after application for the development allowance.
To maximise the effectiveness of the amendments, they will be retrospective and will apply from 1 January 1993, which is the date applications for the development allowance closed.

The amendments will also provide that any applications for registration of plant expenditure that were refused, or granted in respect of an amount of expenditure that was less than the amount of expenditure whose registration was sought in the application, may be granted in full if they would have been granted in full if the amendments proposed in this bill had been in force when the principal act received royal assent.

Moreover, the amendments will provide that any application for registration of plant expenditure that was withdrawn may be taken not to have been withdrawn if an application for transfer of the benefits of the application for registration could have been made if the amendments proposed in this bill had been in force when the principal act received royal assent.

The amendments will also grant the Development Allowance Authority—the DAA—a power to determine that an application by an entity for registration of plant expenditure has lapsed, in certain limited circumstances. The opportunity is also taken to make some minor administrative adjustments and to correct certain apparent drafting errors.

The cost to revenue of the proposed amendments is expected to be approximately $10 million per annum. Over the nine years from 1993-94 to 2001-02, the total cost to revenue of the amendments is expected to be approximately $92 million.This revenue cost relates only to unregistered projects that had already restructured or had developed an intention to restructure before registration. There is no reliable estimate of the prospective cost of allowing all types of restructuring after registration, but the cost is unlikely to be more than $3 million per annum.

It is arguable whether the additional cost to revenue should be viewed as merely restoring the revenue cost of having the development allowance initiative operate with the economic effect that the government originally intended.
I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The development allowance is a special allowance, broadly based on the former investment allowance, that applies to certain capital expenditure after 26 February 1992. The allowance is in addition to depreciation and is set at 10 per cent. It applies only to qualifying projects with a capital cost of $50 million or more.

PARA.TAB: Only expenditure which has pre-qualified under the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992 is eligible for the allowance. Expenditure will pre-qualify where the taxpayer holds a qualifying certificate issued under the principal act and has incurred expenditure on plant in carrying out the project specified in the certificate.

The allowance ceases with effect from 1 July 2002. Expenditure on property which is not first used, or installed ready for use, by 30 June 2002 will not qualify. However, in order to obtain the concession, there must be substantial commitment to completion of the project prior to 1 July 1996 and it must be completed by the year 2002.
This allowance was announced in the One Nation statement, for selected large-scale investments. The object of the allowance was to promote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . an early upturn in investment in new plant and equipment for projects which offer benefits for our competitiveness in world markets.
The government estimated that the allowance would cost $40 million in 1994-95, rising to $70 million in 1995-96.

PARA.TAB: The coalition opposed the passage of the principal act, arguing that it discriminated against projects with a capital cost of less than $50 million, would not be available for investment in plant and equipment in all areas of the economy and did not apply to projects which commenced prior to 31 December 1992.

This principal act has been amended several times since its passage in 1992. In 1992, it was amended to allow applicants for the allowance to elect to aggregate two or more joint venture projects for specified projects and to allow long-term leased equipment within the tests for eligibility. In 1993, it was amended to extend the allowance to certain projects in the motor vehicle and print media industries, to honour the government's commitment made during the 1993 election campaign. It was amended again in 1994, to extend the allowance to property for use in the transport of minerals and quarry materials.

I am informed that projects representing some $67.7 billion have already been registered for the allowance. In Western Australia, projects totalling $26 1/2 billion have been registered for the allowance, $15 billion in the mining sector. As the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) pointed out, this bill amends the principal act to remove some restrictions on the restructuring of projects eligible for the development allowance so that a more consistent approach is available to the various types of prospective applicants for the allowance.

The changes were announced by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on 13 July 1995, in his words `to provide greater scope for restructuring of projects while retaining eligibility for the development allowance'. The Treasurer estimated that the amendments would boost investment figures further, allowing additional projects of at least $1.8 billion to be eligible for the allowance. The bill allows the transfer of the development allowance benefit where ownership is transferred to a new entity after application for the allowance, or from one entity structure to another type of entity structure after registration but before pre-qualification for the allowance.

The amendments allow project restructures both before and after registration of any type of ownership structure to any other type of ownership structure, provided the new owners and project continue to meet the conditions of eligibility. Under the current legislation, where, for example, a single entity is replaced by a joint venture, the applicants cannot transfer the benefits of the application to the new structure.
