A result of the amendments is that any applications for registration of plant expenditure that were refused or granted in respect of an amount of expenditure that was less than the amount of expenditure whose registration was sought in the application may be granted in full if the amendments had been in force when the principal act received royal assent.

The amendments also provide that any application for registration of plant expenditure that was withdrawn will be taken not to have been withdrawn if an application for transfer of the benefits of the application could have been made if the amendments had been in force when the principal act received royal assent.

Because the effect of these amendments is, in summary, to make more flexible the application of the allowance, the opposition does not oppose these amendments to the act, as outlined by the Assistant Treasurer in his second reading speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to make a contribution to the debate on the Development Allowance Authority Amendment Bill 1995, because just last week BHP, which operates the Port Kembla steelworks in my electorate of Throsby, had its new No. 6 blast furnace approved for the development allowance. This project is worth in excess of $400 million, so the bill before the House this evening has particular timely relevance for me.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to amend the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992 so as to allow certain projects to be restructured to be eligible for the development allowance. The amendments also have a retrospective element allowing them to operate as from 1 January 1993. The amendments will remove certain restrictions on access to the development allowance in terms of the ownership of the project. At the present time, the benefit of the development allowance cannot be transferred in some cases where ownership of a project is also transferred following a commercial restructure. In other words, a single owner could not transfer the project to a joint venture or a joint venture could not transfer the project to a single owner and still be eligible for the development allowance.

The government, after being approached by various industry groups that argued that this measure was causing difficulties because, for commercial and technical reasons, it might be necessary to restructure a project during its development stage, commissioned a review by the Development Allowance Authority, the Australian Taxation Office and the Treasury, and the results are to amend the legislation to provide more scope for the restructure of a project during development and its still being eligible for the development allowance.

One of the government's goals has always been to strengthen business investment so that we could underpin strong but sustainable economic growth. In 1994-95 business investment grew by an outstanding 16 per cent. Business investment has been at this level because interest rates have fallen and there is a downward pressure on them. Inflation is at historically low levels, below five per cent for almost four years, and will remain low. Company profits are at an all-time high and continue to grow strongly. Business confidence has also picked up and remains high.

I also make the point, notwithstanding the events with the CRA dispute over the last days, that cooperative industrial relations has contributed significantly to the increase of business investment in Australia. Business investment is also growing strongly because the taxation system encouraged productive investment. The government has established considerable taxation concessions for business which include accelerated depreciation, the general investment allowance, this development allowance, infrastructure bonds, and research and development concessions.

It is also worth mentioning that the government has reduced the rate of company taxation to 36 per cent, which is significantly lower than when the opposition occupied the Treasury bench. Together, all of the taxation concessions I have mentioned will provide business in Australia with a benefit of approximately $3 billion in 1995-96. The cost of these amendments alone will be $10 million per year and the total cost over the nine years from 1993-94 to 2001-02 is expected to be about $92 million.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced the introduction of a development allowance in the One Nation statement on 26 February 1992. The development allowance provides for a taxation deduction of 10 per cent of the capital expenditure incurred on the acquisition or lease of new plant or equipment for projects with capital expenditure of $50 million or more. I know that there has been some discussion about whether it should have been lower than $50 million or not, but that is the figure that they have settled on. The introduction of the development allowance encouraged investment in large projects, stimulated micro-economic reform and encouraged international competitiveness.

The act established a Development Allowance Authority which is a one-member statutory authority which determines the eligibility of projects for the development allowance. I understand that well over 500 applications were received to be granted a development allowance involving capital expenditure of well over $100 billion. So far, 270 of these projects, involving some $75 billion in capital expenditure, have been registered. Of these, 31 projects have been approved, involving expenditure of over $6 billion.

One of these projects approved for the development allowance, as I mentioned earlier, was BHP for its No. 6 blast furnace at the Port Kembla steelworks. This is the first BHP project to fulfil the requirements of the Development Allowance Authority's `competitiveness test'. The No. 6 blast furnace is an over-$400 million project which involved more than 3,000 people, mostly from the Illawarra, to work at various times throughout the construction phases of the project. The current peak construction work force is approximately 900 people.

Once the No. 6 blast furnace is commissioned in March next year, the two smaller existing furnaces, No. 4 and No. 2, will be decommissioned. The result will be increased efficiency and increased capacity which is required in the supply of steel to export markets in the Asia-Pacific region. The new No. 6 blast furnace will lead the world in metal quality, productivity and environmental controls. High levels of automation and mechanical aids will significantly improve working conditions, increase efficiency and safety, and minimise repetitive intensive workloads. I am also pleased that the No. 6 blast furnace is aiming at achieving zero accidents.

If there is one area that really needs to be carefully examined in workplaces it is safety, accidents and injury. The New South Wales government is again revisiting the issue of workers compensation and there are a few unsavoury points which I view with concern. But the real message is that, rather than attack workers compensation entitlements, workplaces need to be made safer places for workers. It is therefore disappointing that the New South Wales government has appointed former Premier Barry Unsworth to the New South Wales Work Cover Authority to oversee various proposals for change which, if one relies on media reports, will again attack workers compensation entitlements—as he did in 1988. My union colleagues have expressed concern to me that, given the former Premier's inability to listen to arguments on this issue in 1988, he will go much further this time in his new position.

This new BHP blast furnace is the first blast furnace to be constructed in Australia since 1972. Occasionally, in the past, I have had my disagreements with BHP management at Port Kembla steelworks over a few issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —No!

—It is surprising; I have had a few disagreements over a few issues. The Hansard would have a few of my speeches which have been dedicated to BHP. I congratulate BHP on obtaining this development allowance, and it is not the first time that I have congratulated them. I believe that BHP has shown confidence in the Illawarra by constructing this world class blast furnace at Port Kembla. In fact, they have given the Illawarra a vote of confidence.

PARA.TAB: I must admit that I was concerned that there might be a slight backlash against BHP for having a development allowance approved, given its profit statement, which I think gives a very good indication of the health of the business environment. BHP did meet all the guidelines for this allowance to be approved, and I stress that. As they have met all the guidelines, they are entitled to it.

In welcoming the announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) last week, I said in my own media statement that I would now expect BHP to continue to show its confidence in the region by investing the $14.4 million it received through the approval of this development allowance in other projects which will be of significant benefit not only to the Illawarra but also to Australia.

The BHP Port Kembla steelworks group general manager, Paul Jeans, has agreed with my expectation and committed BHP to projects in the Illawarra totalling more than $1 billion. The No. 6 blast furnace is the most significant, but there is also the $300 million upgrade expansion of the tin plate manufacturing facility and the $90 million project to increase the steelworks output to five million tonnes per year by 1998.

I also want to mention the contribution of the Illawarra's combined trade unions and BHP's work force. The competitiveness test, as set out in the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992, requires applicants for the development allowance to demonstrate that their labour relations substantially reflect world best practice. The Illawarra has always been portrayed as a union town. It is a union town and it will always be one. It is also leading the way in workplace relationships, and that was recognised recently when a report by the regional development taskforce was tabled.

In the Illawarra Mercury today, there is a report which says that BHP has told its 300 workers at its Unanderra Stainless Products plant that closure is one option being investigated because of an expected drop in profit levels. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The company stresses to its employees and unions that if this happened, no-one would be retrenched . . .

Company officials made presentations to employees and union leaders last Friday and AWU-FIMEE Port Kembla branch president, Graham Roberts, said that the company was quite frank and open in explaining its difficulties and was taking a positive approach.

PARA.TAB: Especially in the Illawarra, this would have been unthinkable a few years ago, but it is another example of how the Illawarra trade unions, BHP and the workers have improved their industrial relations agenda. The approval of this development allowance reflects more than positively on them, as indeed it does on BHP. I have much pleasure in commending this legislation to the House, and I am pleased that the opposition is not going to oppose it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Duncan)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: STUDENT AND YOUTH ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT (YOUTH TRAINING ALLOWANCE) BILL (No. 2) 1995Cognate bill:STUDENT AND YOUTH ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT (YOUTH TRAINING ALLOWANCE) BILL (No. 3) 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 18 October.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill will make changes to the youth training allowance provisions of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973. Late last year these provisions were incorporated into part 8 of the act and modelled on those for jobsearch allowance found in the Social Security Act 1991. As the youth training allowance and jobsearch allowance are closely aligned, it is important that any changes to one are mirrored in the other and commence at or about the same time.

PARA.TAB: The youth training allowance is just one part of the youth training initiative. To those leaving school early, the youth training initiative offers more than an income support payment. It offers case management, training and jobs. Young people who leave school at the end of this school year can be eligible for this assistance, not six months or a year down the track but at the same time as their former classmates are beginning a new year of school.

Young people now realise that if they want to have a good, well paid job they need to stay on at school, look for an apprenticeship or a traineeship, or pursue further vocational training. Jobs that are full time, well paid and stable increasingly require education, training and skills. If we are to help early school leavers who are unemployed, we need to give them the training and skills that will open the doors to full-time quality jobs. That is what the youth training initiative aims to do and that is why we pay 15- to 17-year-olds youth training allowance rather than jobsearch allowance.

Several of the amendments that are proposed in this bill will contribute directly to the main aim of the youth training initiative—improving the job prospects of early school leavers. The remaining amendments will foster efficient administration of the youth training allowance by keeping it aligned with the common provisions of the Social Security Act 1991.

The amendments in schedule 1 close a minor loophole in the calculation of youth training allowance for those who receive a periodic compensation payment paid as a lump sum. The treatment of compensation payments to a couple where one member of the couple receives youth training allowance and the other a benefit under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 is also amended to ensure consistency across Commonwealth income support measures.

The amendments in schedule 2 have two objectives. The first is to allow 15-year-olds who are assessed as `independent' to qualify for YTA immediately, even if they do not meet the work force requirements. Currently these people can only be paid special benefit. The second objective is to allow 15-year-olds who have a work force history, and who live with parents who are in receipt of Commonwealth income support, to qualify immediately for youth training allowance.

The amendments in schedule 3 will allow youth training allowance overpayments to be offset against any student assistance payments, such as Austudy, which a person may subsequently be entitled to receive. This will lead to a more consistent debt management function.

The amendments in schedule 4 will mean that part of a waiting period served for youth training allowance or sickness allowance will be transferable should a client move from one to the other during the waiting period. It is possible at the moment for a client to apply for one allowance, begin to serve a waiting period, claim the other allowance and then be required to serve a second waiting period.

Schedule 5 enhances the provisions dealing with the waiver and recoverability of debts. The amendments will permit partial waiver of a debt in certain circumstances, as well as clarifying when it is more cost effective to waive some smaller debts. The amendments will allow for more flexible negotiated settlements to avoid unnecessary and costly administrative appeals. They also give a mechanism for considering an up-front part-payment to quit a debt based on commercial considerations. The amendments will permit the non-recovery of a debt where there are special circumstances that make recovery inequitable. Furthermore, the amendments will allow debts subject to Administrative Appeals Tribunal proceedings to be settled in the same manner as an `out of court' settlement of a matter before a civil court.

Schedule 6 makes some minor clarifications regarding the time a client has to nominate a bank account once approval of youth training allowance is made, and what allowance might be back-paid if the client does not nominate an account within a prescribed time.

The amendments in schedule 7 will increase by $5 a fortnight the amount of rent that must be paid before rent assistance may be offered. It also increases by $5 a fortnight the maximum amount of rent assistance that may be paid to a family. These changes will improve the targeting and effectiveness of rent assistance.
The amendments in schedule 8 make minor technical corrections to the principal act. Among these is a clarification of the definition of `protected information'.I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: STUDENT AND YOUTH ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT (YOUTH TRAINING ALLOWANCE) BILL No.3 1995

PARA.TAB: This bill will make changes to the youth training allowance provisions of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 that are found in part 8 of the act. These were incorporated into the Student and Youth Assistance Act late last year and modelled on the jobsearch allowance provisions contained in the Social Security Act 1991. As the youth training allowance and jobsearch allowance are closely aligned it is important that any changes to one are mirrored in the other, and commence at or about the same time. These amendments follow amendments proposed to the Social Security Act 1991 by the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill 1995.

The youth training allowance is just one part of the youth training initiative. To early school leavers this initiative offers more than just an income support payment; it offers case management, training and jobs. Case management at 13 weeks makes sure that early school leavers are not lost in the crowd. A young person's case manager works with them individually to map a pathway out of unemployment. Case managers can immediately offer a wide range of training, education and work experience options.

Early access to training, education and work experience opportunities is vital for early school leavers. Young people who enter the labour market without post-secondary qualifications or work experience find it difficult to get full-time permanent jobs. Skills, qualifications and experience are more important now than at any time in the past. The youth training initiative offers a way out of the no job, no experience, no qualifications trap.

This initiative is an active response to youth unemployment. Income support should not aim to treat the symptoms of unemployment; it should work to tackle the causes. This bill will make sure that the income support component of the youth training initiative, the youth training allowance, operates smoothly as part of an integrated package of assistance.

The amendments in schedule 1 mirror amendments proposed to the Social Security Act 1991. They are intended primarily to ensure the consistency of Commonwealth income support measures and prevent anomalies arising between income support payments. These amendments simplify the rules applying to financial investments. At present there are many different and complex rules for calculating the income from financial investments. These amendments will mean that those rules will no longer apply and financial investments will be assessed under one set of simple rules.

The amendment in schedule 2 will provide for unemployed clients who are temporarily unable to work because of illness or injury to remain in receipt of youth training allowance, instead of being required to transfer to sickness allowance. By remaining on youth training allowance they will continue to access eligibility for the full range of assistance available to the unemployed. This access will encourage them to pursue education or training activities as they recover.

The amendments in schedule 3 make changes to the earnings credit scheme. This scheme operates to provide an incentive for a person to undertake part-time or casual employment. When the ordinary income test is applied for the purposes of calculating a person's fortnightly rate of a benefit, short periods of remunerative work could have the effect of reducing the person's rate of benefit.

Currently, recipients of youth training allowance can accrue an earnings credit from which they can offset earnings for remunerative work before the income test is applied. A person may offset an amount of earnings up to the person's earnings credit balance, which is a maximum of $500. Earnings credits are not accessible if the person's fortnightly rate of ordinary income exceeds an amount that reduces the rate of the person's assistance to nil. The proposed amendments will allow a person to access earnings credit notwithstanding that the person's ordinary income amount would, if the income test were applied, reduce the rate of the assistance to nil. Further adjustments to the application of earnings credits are also made.

Amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 amalgamate the jobsearch allowance, JSA, and newstart allowance, NSA, into one payment type called newstart allowance. The amendments in schedule 4 are consequential amendments arising from this change.
I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Dr D.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the first thing that needs to be said about this piece of legislation is that it is yet another bill which has had to be introduced into the parliament because of the decision by the government to take over the youth training allowance or to invent a new payment, the youth training allowance, which substitutes for jobsearch in relation to young people and to assume control over this allowance from the Department of Social Security.

PARA.TAB: The reason for this has never been adequately explained. The necessity for it has never been adequately justified. Consequently, a great deal of new legislation is required simply to mirror provisions in social security legislation. In other words, the parliament is being put to a great deal of extra work solely to gratify, apparently, the imperial ambitions of the Department of Employment, Education and Training to have under its control the payment of a significant allowance.

The second thing that should be said about this legislation is that, as the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) has pointed out, it is part of the government's youth training initiative. The whole purpose of the measures for youth in the white paper Working Nation as set out by the government, was to assist unemployed youth get back into employment and particularly to assist long-term unemployed youth to get back into employment.

The people of Australia will be asking at this stage, almost 17 months since the commencement of the Working Nation program, whether this youth training initiative has been effective. They will be asking, `What is now the position of young people in Australia as a result of the measures brought down by the government?' The answer is a very sorry answer indeed. Any reference to the official statistics will reveal the fact that youth unemployment in Australia is now higher than it was when Working Nation commenced operation. Not only has the youth training initiative failed to bring down unemployment amongst young people but teenage unemployment has actually increased since Working Nation began. The very age group which is the recipient of the youth training allowance and the supposed beneficiary of the youth training initiative is in more dire straits now than it was when Working Nation commenced.

This is an incredible failure on the part of the government and it needs to be brought firmly into the public limelight because there is no doubt that youth unemployment is one of the most serious social and economic problems which Australia faces today. It has not escaped the attention even of certain media proprietors that this has become a major area of failure by the government. People will want to know why it is that Working Nation has failed young Australians so comprehensively.

The government, of course, does not want people to focus on this issue at all. It will be a matter of continuing shame that the minister has directed his department to cease the publication of the regional youth unemployment statistics, which were readily available to all members of parliament until the last publication—and then the chopper came down. We are getting too close to an election, Mr Deputy Speaker, for these statistics to be allowed to continue to come out in the public domain.

I have noticed in the departmental publications the somewhat disingenuous statement that the decision to halt the publication of these statistics on youth unemployment was a departmental decision. I can just imagine the officers of this department saying to the minister, `Minister, we have decided to cease the publication of these regional youth unemployment statistics,' and the minister putting up a tremendous fight to keep these statistics in the public domain only to be overruled by Derek Volker and his minions.

It stretches credibility too far to imagine that this was a decision taken by the department to the surprise and horror of the minister. Oh, no! We all know that the reality is that the minister was only too eager to halt the publication of these statistics. He came very close to misleading the parliament when a question was asked of him in question time. He said, `Oh, these statistics are still available. All you have to do is to go over to the Bureau of Statistics and they will draw them out for you.' So much for open access to information—vital information—about the state of Australian society today.

We have a government whose programs have failed and which has tried to suppress information which might give clear evidence of the extent of that failure and the large number of areas of regional Australia suffering rates of youth unemployment of over 50 per cent. The national rate of youth unemployment—that is, unemployment amongst teenagers looking for full-time work, which is the commonly accepted measure of youth unemployment—is 29 per cent. But the figures that were released before the chopper came down, before the censorship was imposed, showed that in a number of areas of regional Australia youth unemployment was well over 50 per cent. In some places, such as in inner and western Melbourne, it was over 60 per cent. And the total unemployment rate in these areas—the overall unemployment rate—was over 20 per cent.

I can hardly refrain from saying that these areas where unemployment is so high are areas which have been represented for a long time typically by the Labor Party. If you travel to these areas and see the social desolation that the policies of this government has caused with these incredible unemployment rates, with young people clustered around the pinball parlours or in the foyers of overcrowded magistrates courts, you cannot help asking yourself how it is that this party has failed its constituency so comprehensively. What have the members been doing over more than a decade in power? What have they been doing over the last 13 years when they have been in government? Where are the great efforts they have been making to bring industry and jobs to these areas, to their constituents? Where are the policies that will encourage small business in these areas to employ people? Where are the effective regional employment programs that might have a chance of alleviating this appalling scene? They are not there.

What do these Labor members say when they go back to their constituents? They say, `Watch out for the coalition because they will take away your welfare benefits. We have put you all on welfare, sure. But that is even better than a coalition government could do.' They mislead their constituents remorselessly. Indeed, you can see why so many Australians have become cynical about politics and about the Labor Party, and why they say, `Well, really, the Labor Party is the party of poverty.' It is because the Labor Party's principal electoral tactic is to first of all push their constituents into poverty and then frighten them that they will lose their benefits if they change government—if they change to a government which has a magnificent historical record of creating employment right across the Australian community.

The Labor Party ought to hang its head in shame at the situation which its policies have created. They go out to the Australian people and tell them, `Yes, but look at the great things we have done. The youth training initiative, the youth training allowance, the traineeship scheme, the entry level training places. Look at these wonderful initiatives. We are actually helping young people.' Let us forget the fact that youth unemployment has actually gone up, and let us look at these schemes that the government has introduced—the schemes that they say are going to help young people.

It is a fact that many, many thousands of these unemployed young Australians would give their right arm to have an apprenticeship or a traineeship that will lead them into employment. They would love to have that opportunity. I was at a dinner only a couple of weeks ago, put on by the council of the Heavy Engineering Manufacturers Association. The chairman of that association told the guests at the dinner that his company had recently advertised some 30 apprenticeship vacancies. They got over 900 applications for these 30 apprenticeships.

If we look at these opportunities, it is obvious that there are not nearly enough opportunities for young people who want them. Indeed if we look at the statistics and ask what has been the record of this government over 13 years, we find that the number of young people in apprenticeships and traineeships as a proportion of the work force is the lowest for three decades.

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training and doubtless the minister at the table, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free), go around Australia saying `Look at the increasing numbers we have got in traineeships and apprenticeships. Look at the increases in commencements.' What they do not tell you—and this is just a simple matter of statistical propriety—is that we have to look at these figures in the context of the size of the work force. Of course, the number has gone up! The work force has increased; the population is growing. There are probably a hundred times the number in traineeships than there were in apprenticeships back in the 1920s—but what does that mean? As a proportion of the work force, the number of opportunities is the lowest for three decades. That is what matters to those young people who are clamouring for these opportunities.

The government says, `You know that we have given a tremendous emphasis to training over the last 13 years. No government has thought more about training.' We go back to the origins of the Australian traineeship system in 1985, when there were big ambitions to add to the apprenticeships available. It was intended to have an enormous number of new traineeships. Indeed the target at the time was 75,000 commencements in traineeships a year. What happened? The figure never got above 15,000. Mostly, it did not get above 9,000.

What was the wonderful traineeship target of Working Nation—this beacon of hope to young Australians! It had a target of 26,500 traineeships in its first year. This was 10 years after the commencement of the Australian traineeship system. What did they achieve? How many traineeships actually came through, out of this incredibly generous total of 26,500? They managed 16,000 in the first year. What a pathetic performance! This Working Nation, which is supposed to be lifting young Australians up and giving them hope and opportunity, was barely able to get over half its very low target in the first year.

There is no guarantee at all that it will reach its target in the second year. Its target, of course, is based on commencements. Does the government ever tell you that 50 per cent of the commencements drop out? They do not stay. How can we wonder at the fact that the number of young people going for apprenticeships and traineeships is so low and that Australian industry is crying out for skills that are not coming through?

Go around this country, as I am sure the minister does and as I do, and talk to small businesses and chambers of commerce and ask them why they are not taking on apprentices and trainees. The answer comes through, loud and clear: the government's scheme is so complex, so difficult to understand and so embedded in the industrial relations system. This last has been the great problem with it, and the real reason is that, for the last 13 years, there has not genuinely been an agenda to create training opportunities for young Australians. There has been an agenda to make sure that whatever training opportunities are created do not interfere with the centralised award system so beloved of the ACTU.

Training has been appendix X to the industrial relations policy of the government. The whole focus, the whole priority, has been on attempting to preserve the positions of privilege of the government's trade union bosses—its mates, the people who have governed the country alongside the government for 13 years. It has been designed to preserve their position, and young Australians have been betrayed for, and sacrificed to, the preservation of those interests. That is why the performance has been so pathetic. There has not been a training agenda for the past 13 years which has had young people as its principal focus.

The gulf between reality and rhetoric has been colossal under this government. It is no wonder that we find youth unemployment so high. There is a very significant proportion—not a majority, but a significant proportion—of young people, perhaps 25 per cent of the senior secondary group and of 19-year-olds, who want workplace based training and who do not intend to go on through TAFE or university. Of course, during most of the 1980s, they had some other options. They had the option of attending a college of advanced education, with vocationally oriented courses.

As recently as 1988, seven years ago, the government—in the person of John Dawkins—was out destroying the colleges of advanced education as vocational institutions, yet now, of course, that is the very thing we need. But then they were not the slightest bit interested in TAFE or the colleges of advanced education, or in vocational education. No! Everyone had to go on to universities. Why did the government adopt that policy? Was that their deep and abiding concern for young Australians? Of course not. The reason they adopted the policy of destroying those vocationally oriented institutions was because the unions wanted to have the same employment conditions and the same salary conditions as university staff had. The whole tertiary education and training system was up-ended again to suit the interests of the government's mates in the unions, and young people once again were sacrificed.

When we see this legislation coming into the parliament, one bill after another concerned with the youth training allowance, putting the legislation for DEET on all-fours with the social security legislation, and when we hear the government telling us time after time how much of an effort it is making for young people, I am sure that the young people of this country see only too clearly what their real situation is. They are a generation which has been more disadvantaged than the generation of almost any other Western country.

Australia has the second lowest proportion of senior secondary students in vocational education and training of any industrialised country. It is for this reason that the coalition will be moving an amendment to this bill, a second reading amendment, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the failure of the Government's measures to assist young unemployed people".

That expresses our view very succinctly. We are not going to be fooled by the rhetoric that comes out of the government and by the bureaucratic manoeuvres that it undertakes. We look very clearly, and the young people of Australia look very clearly, at the performance and the reality. They see the fraud, the misjudgments and the incompetence involved in Working Nation, some of which have already been admitted, not openly but by new decisions recently announced by the government.

PARA.TAB: One of the most destructive things that Working Nation did in its first year of implementation was to require young people just out of school and looking for jobs to wait around for 12 months until they were long-term unemployed before they qualified for assistance under Working Nation. Working Nation promised that 189,000 of them, mainly young people, would get subsidised employment assistance through the jobstart program.

What did it achieve? It undershot that target by 94,000. Why did it do that? Not for the reasons the minister gives in explaining that incredible bungle—that employers prefer employees who have been through the training programs. It is plausible. The only problem was that the training programs he is referring to have lower employment outcomes than the jobstart program. If employers prefer it, why are the employment outcomes lower? That is not the reason. The reason is that there was an extraordinary bungle and they choked off the program that had the most employment outcomes. That was the best guarantee of getting a job, and 94,000 unemployed young people suffered as a result of that.

Working Nation told them, `Wait around. When you are long-term unemployed you will fit within our strategy.' Of course, we all know how destructive it is for highly motivated young people to be asked to sit around doing nothing, going to the pinball parlour, getting into trouble for 12 months. The problem and the difficulty of helping them is so much greater after 12 months than it was when they were highly motivated and first entering the work force.

Of course, the government has now changed the entry requirement, the guideline for the subsidised employment programs. There was no fanfare, no acknowledgment to the opposition that it was right 12 months ago, no apology to Australia's young people and no admission of culpability on behalf of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. He knew this a year before he changed the entry guidelines into the program and did nothing because, like Carmen Lawrence, I suppose, he was too proud to ever admit a mistake. It has just got him into trouble because, as the government approaches the election, unemployment is rising again, and long-term unemployment is rising again.

If Working Nation was about anything it was about helping the long-term unemployed. If the minister had listened to the constructive comments of the coalition well over a year ago then none of this need have happened. If he had listened then so many more thousands of unemployed Australians and unemployed young people could have been effectively helped, but they were not. So do not give us the cant, minister, that the government, by introducing this legislation, is somehow or other helping young Australians. You have not effectively offered any help to young people, because the problem is getting worse, growth is slowing and jobs are scarcer under your policies. Putting your constituents on welfare and frightening them with the claim that a change of government is going to make their position even worse is surely the ultimate abrogation of your responsibility.

How can you claim any standing when that is the way in which you communicate with the electorate? It is time you got your act together and looked at policies that created the real jobs that young people are looking for. Instead of backing strikes in the way that you do to ensure your electoral support from the ACTU and its senior officials in the coming election campaign and instead of kowtowing constantly under the terms of the accord, you should give some attention to the needs of small business to employ people. You should offer traineeships and apprenticeships to young people and really set about boosting their opportunities. If you did that then you might have some credibility, but at the moment you have none.
Debate (on motion by Mr Wakelin) adjourned.
